14 replace_notes_in_docstring)

16from scipy import integrate 

17from scipy import interpolate 

18import scipy.special as sc

21from scipy._lib._util import _lazyselect, _lazywhere

31# In numpy 1.12 and above, np.power refuses to raise integers to negative 

32# powers, and `np.float_power` is a new replacement. 

33try: 

34 float_power = np.float_power 

35except AttributeError: 

36 float_power = np.power 

37 

38 

39def _remove_optimizer_parameters(kwds): 

40 """ 

41 Remove the optimizer-related keyword arguments 'loc', 'scale' and 

42 'optimizer' from `kwds`. Then check that `kwds` is empty, and 

43 raise `TypeError("Unknown arguments: %s." % kwds)` if it is not. 

44 

45 This function is used in the fit method of distributions that override 

46 the default method and do not use the default optimization code. 

47 

48 `kwds` is modified in-place. 

49 """ 

50 kwds.pop('loc', None) 

51 kwds.pop('scale', None) 

52 kwds.pop('optimizer', None) 

53 if kwds: 

54 raise TypeError("Unknown arguments: %s." % kwds) 

55 

56 

57## Kolmogorov-Smirnov one-sided and two-sided test statistics 

58class ksone_gen(rv_continuous): 

59 r"""General Kolmogorov-Smirnov one-sided test. 

60 

61 This is the distribution of the one-sided Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS) 

62 statistics :math:`D_n^+` and :math:`D_n^-` 

63 for a finite sample size ``n`` (the shape parameter). 

64 

65 %(before_notes)s 

66 

67 Notes 

68 ----- 

69 :math:`D_n^+` and :math:`D_n^-` are given by 

70 

71 .. math:: 

72 

73 D_n^+ &= \text{sup}_x (F_n(x) - F(x)),\\ 

74 D_n^- &= \text{sup}_x (F(x) - F_n(x)),\\ 

75 

76 where :math:`F` is a CDF and :math:`F_n` is an empirical CDF. `ksone` 

77 describes the distribution under the null hypothesis of the KS test 

78 that the empirical CDF corresponds to :math:`n` i.i.d. random variates 

79 with CDF :math:`F`. 

80 

81 %(after_notes)s 

82 

83 See Also 

84 -------- 

85 kstwobign, kstest 

86 

87 References 

88 ---------- 

89 .. [1] Birnbaum, Z. W. and Tingey, F.H. "One-sided confidence contours 

90 for probability distribution functions", The Annals of Mathematical 

91 Statistics, 22(4), pp 592-596 (1951). 

92 

93 %(example)s 

94 

95 """ 

96 def _pdf(self, x, n): 

97 return -scu._smirnovp(n, x) 

98 

99 def _cdf(self, x, n): 

100 return scu._smirnovc(n, x) 

101 

102 def _sf(self, x, n): 

103 return sc.smirnov(n, x) 

104 

105 def _ppf(self, q, n): 

106 return scu._smirnovci(n, q) 

107 

108 def _isf(self, q, n): 

109 return sc.smirnovi(n, q) 

110 

111 

112ksone = ksone_gen(a=0.0, b=1.0, name='ksone') 

113 

114 

115class kstwobign_gen(rv_continuous): 

116 r"""Kolmogorov-Smirnov two-sided test for large N. 

117 

118 This is the asymptotic distribution of the two-sided Kolmogorov-Smirnov 

119 statistic :math:`\sqrt{n} D_n` that measures the maximum absolute 

120 distance of the theoretical CDF from the empirical CDF (see `kstest`). 

121 

122 %(before_notes)s 

123 

124 Notes 

125 ----- 

126 :math:`\sqrt{n} D_n` is given by 

127 

128 .. math:: 

129 

130 D_n = \text{sup}_x |F_n(x) - F(x)| 

131 

132 where :math:`F` is a CDF and :math:`F_n` is an empirical CDF. `kstwobign` 

133 describes the asymptotic distribution (i.e. the limit of 

134 :math:`\sqrt{n} D_n`) under the null hypothesis of the KS test that the 

135 empirical CDF corresponds to i.i.d. random variates with CDF :math:`F`. 

136 

137 %(after_notes)s 

138 

139 See Also 

140 -------- 

141 ksone, kstest 

142 

143 References 

144 ---------- 

145 .. [1] Marsaglia, G. et al. "Evaluating Kolmogorov's distribution", 

146 Journal of Statistical Software, 8(18), 2003. 

147 

148 %(example)s 

149 

150 """ 

151 def _pdf(self, x): 

152 return -scu._kolmogp(x) 

153 

154 def _cdf(self, x): 

155 return scu._kolmogc(x) 

156 

157 def _sf(self, x): 

158 return sc.kolmogorov(x) 

159 

160 def _ppf(self, q): 

161 return scu._kolmogci(q) 

162 

163 def _isf(self, q): 

164 return sc.kolmogi(q) 

165 

166 

167kstwobign = kstwobign_gen(a=0.0, name='kstwobign') 

168 

169 

170## Normal distribution 

171 

172# loc = mu, scale = std 

173# Keep these implementations out of the class definition so they can be reused 

174# by other distributions. 

175_norm_pdf_C = np.sqrt(2*np.pi) 

176_norm_pdf_logC = np.log(_norm_pdf_C) 

177 

178 

179def _norm_pdf(x): 

180 return np.exp(-x**2/2.0) / _norm_pdf_C 

181 

182 

183def _norm_logpdf(x): 

184 return -x**2 / 2.0 - _norm_pdf_logC 

185 

186 

187def _norm_cdf(x): 

188 return sc.ndtr(x) 

189 

190 

191def _norm_logcdf(x): 

192 return sc.log_ndtr(x) 

193 

194 

195def _norm_ppf(q): 

196 return sc.ndtri(q) 

197 

198 

199def _norm_sf(x): 

200 return _norm_cdf(-x) 

201 

202 

203def _norm_logsf(x): 

204 return _norm_logcdf(-x) 

205 

206 

207def _norm_isf(q): 

208 return -_norm_ppf(q) 

209 

210 

211class norm_gen(rv_continuous): 

212 r"""A normal continuous random variable. 

213 

214 The location (``loc``) keyword specifies the mean. 

215 The scale (``scale``) keyword specifies the standard deviation. 

216 

217 %(before_notes)s 

218 

219 Notes 

220 ----- 

221 The probability density function for `norm` is: 

222 

223 .. math:: 

224 

225 f(x) = \frac{\exp(-x^2/2)}{\sqrt{2\pi}} 

226 

227 for a real number :math:`x`. 

228 

229 %(after_notes)s 

230 

231 %(example)s 

232 

233 """ 

234 def _rvs(self): 

235 return self._random_state.standard_normal(self._size) 

236 

237 def _pdf(self, x): 

238 # norm.pdf(x) = exp(-x**2/2)/sqrt(2*pi) 

239 return _norm_pdf(x) 

240 

241 def _logpdf(self, x): 

242 return _norm_logpdf(x) 

243 

244 def _cdf(self, x): 

245 return _norm_cdf(x) 

246 

247 def _logcdf(self, x): 

248 return _norm_logcdf(x) 

249 

250 def _sf(self, x): 

251 return _norm_sf(x) 

252 

253 def _logsf(self, x): 

254 return _norm_logsf(x) 

255 

256 def _ppf(self, q): 

257 return _norm_ppf(q) 

258 

259 def _isf(self, q): 

260 return _norm_isf(q) 

261 

262 def _stats(self): 

263 return 0.0, 1.0, 0.0, 0.0 

264 

265 def _entropy(self): 

266 return 0.5*(np.log(2*np.pi)+1) 

267 

268 @replace_notes_in_docstring(rv_continuous, notes="""\ 

269 This function uses explicit formulas for the maximum likelihood 

270 estimation of the normal distribution parameters, so the 

271 `optimizer` argument is ignored.\n\n""") 

272 def fit(self, data, **kwds): 

273 floc = kwds.pop('floc', None) 

274 fscale = kwds.pop('fscale', None) 

275 

276 _remove_optimizer_parameters(kwds) 

277 

278 if floc is not None and fscale is not None: 

279 # This check is for consistency with `rv_continuous.fit`. 

280 # Without this check, this function would just return the 

281 # parameters that were given. 

282 raise ValueError("All parameters fixed. There is nothing to " 

283 "optimize.") 

284 

285 data = np.asarray(data) 

286 

287 if not np.isfinite(data).all(): 

288 raise RuntimeError("The data contains non-finite values.") 

289 

290 if floc is None: 

291 loc = data.mean() 

292 else: 

293 loc = floc 

294 

295 if fscale is None: 

296 scale = np.sqrt(((data - loc)**2).mean()) 

297 else: 

298 scale = fscale 

299 

300 return loc, scale 

301 

302 

303norm = norm_gen(name='norm') 

304 

305 

306class alpha_gen(rv_continuous): 

307 r"""An alpha continuous random variable. 

308 

309 %(before_notes)s 

310 

311 Notes 

312 ----- 

313 The probability density function for `alpha` ([1]_, [2]_) is: 

314 

315 .. math:: 

316 

317 f(x, a) = \frac{1}{x^2 \Phi(a) \sqrt{2\pi}} * 

318 \exp(-\frac{1}{2} (a-1/x)^2) 

319 

320 where :math:`\Phi` is the normal CDF, :math:`x > 0`, and :math:`a > 0`. 

321 

322 `alpha` takes ``a`` as a shape parameter. 

323 

324 %(after_notes)s 

325 

326 References 

327 ---------- 

328 .. [1] Johnson, Kotz, and Balakrishnan, "Continuous Univariate 

329 Distributions, Volume 1", Second Edition, John Wiley and Sons, 

330 p. 173 (1994). 

331 .. [2] Anthony A. Salvia, "Reliability applications of the Alpha 

332 Distribution", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, Vol. R-34, 

333 No. 3, pp. 251-252 (1985). 

334 

335 %(example)s 

336 

337 """ 

338 _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask 

339 

340 def _pdf(self, x, a): 

341 # alpha.pdf(x, a) = 1/(x**2*Phi(a)*sqrt(2*pi)) * exp(-1/2 * (a-1/x)**2) 

342 return 1.0/(x**2)/_norm_cdf(a)*_norm_pdf(a-1.0/x) 

343 

344 def _logpdf(self, x, a): 

345 return -2*np.log(x) + _norm_logpdf(a-1.0/x) - np.log(_norm_cdf(a)) 

346 

347 def _cdf(self, x, a): 

348 return _norm_cdf(a-1.0/x) / _norm_cdf(a) 

349 

350 def _ppf(self, q, a): 

351 return 1.0/np.asarray(a-sc.ndtri(q*_norm_cdf(a))) 

352 

353 def _stats(self, a): 

354 return [np.inf]*2 + [np.nan]*2 

355 

356 

357alpha = alpha_gen(a=0.0, name='alpha') 

358 

359 

360class anglit_gen(rv_continuous): 

361 r"""An anglit continuous random variable. 

362 

363 %(before_notes)s 

364 

365 Notes 

366 ----- 

367 The probability density function for `anglit` is: 

368 

369 .. math:: 

370 

371 f(x) = \sin(2x + \pi/2) = \cos(2x) 

372 

373 for :math:`-\pi/4 \le x \le \pi/4`. 

374 

375 %(after_notes)s 

376 

377 %(example)s 

378 

379 """ 

380 def _pdf(self, x): 

381 # anglit.pdf(x) = sin(2*x + \pi/2) = cos(2*x) 

382 return np.cos(2*x) 

383 

384 def _cdf(self, x): 

385 return np.sin(x+np.pi/4)**2.0 

386 

387 def _ppf(self, q): 

388 return np.arcsin(np.sqrt(q))-np.pi/4 

389 

390 def _stats(self): 

391 return 0.0, np.pi*np.pi/16-0.5, 0.0, -2*(np.pi**4 - 96)/(np.pi*np.pi-8)**2 

392 

393 def _entropy(self): 

394 return 1-np.log(2) 

395 

396 

397anglit = anglit_gen(a=-np.pi/4, b=np.pi/4, name='anglit') 

398 

399 

400class arcsine_gen(rv_continuous): 

401 r"""An arcsine continuous random variable. 

402 

403 %(before_notes)s 

404 

405 Notes 

406 ----- 

407 The probability density function for `arcsine` is: 

408 

409 .. math:: 

410 

411 f(x) = \frac{1}{\pi \sqrt{x (1-x)}} 

412 

413 for :math:`0 < x < 1`. 

414 

415 %(after_notes)s 

416 

417 %(example)s 

418 

419 """ 

420 def _pdf(self, x): 

421 # arcsine.pdf(x) = 1/(pi*sqrt(x*(1-x))) 

422 return 1.0/np.pi/np.sqrt(x*(1-x)) 

423 

424 def _cdf(self, x): 

425 return 2.0/np.pi*np.arcsin(np.sqrt(x)) 

426 

427 def _ppf(self, q): 

428 return np.sin(np.pi/2.0*q)**2.0 

429 

430 def _stats(self): 

431 mu = 0.5 

432 mu2 = 1.0/8 

433 g1 = 0 

434 g2 = -3.0/2.0 

435 return mu, mu2, g1, g2 

436 

437 def _entropy(self): 

438 return -0.24156447527049044468 

439 

440 

441arcsine = arcsine_gen(a=0.0, b=1.0, name='arcsine') 

442 

443 

444class FitDataError(ValueError): 

445 # This exception is raised by, for example, beta_gen.fit when both floc 

446 # and fscale are fixed and there are values in the data not in the open 

447 # interval (floc, floc+fscale). 

448 def __init__(self, distr, lower, upper): 

449 self.args = ( 

450 "Invalid values in `data`. Maximum likelihood " 

451 "estimation with {distr!r} requires that {lower!r} < x " 

452 "< {upper!r} for each x in `data`.".format( 

453 distr=distr, lower=lower, upper=upper), 

454 ) 

455 

456 

457class FitSolverError(RuntimeError): 

458 # This exception is raised by, for example, beta_gen.fit when 

459 # optimize.fsolve returns with ier != 1. 

460 def __init__(self, mesg): 

461 emsg = "Solver for the MLE equations failed to converge: " 

462 emsg += mesg.replace('\n', '') 

463 self.args = (emsg,) 

464 

465 

466def _beta_mle_a(a, b, n, s1): 

467 # The zeros of this function give the MLE for `a`, with 

468 # `b`, `n` and `s1` given. `s1` is the sum of the logs of 

469 # the data. `n` is the number of data points. 

470 psiab = sc.psi(a + b) 

471 func = s1 - n * (-psiab + sc.psi(a)) 

472 return func 

473 

474 

475def _beta_mle_ab(theta, n, s1, s2): 

476 # Zeros of this function are critical points of 

477 # the maximum likelihood function. Solving this system 

478 # for theta (which contains a and b) gives the MLE for a and b 

479 # given `n`, `s1` and `s2`. `s1` is the sum of the logs of the data, 

480 # and `s2` is the sum of the logs of 1 - data. `n` is the number 

481 # of data points. 

482 a, b = theta 

483 psiab = sc.psi(a + b) 

484 func = [s1 - n * (-psiab + sc.psi(a)), 

485 s2 - n * (-psiab + sc.psi(b))] 

486 return func 

487 

488 

489class beta_gen(rv_continuous): 

490 r"""A beta continuous random variable. 

491 

492 %(before_notes)s 

493 

494 Notes 

495 ----- 

496 The probability density function for `beta` is: 

497 

498 .. math:: 

499 

500 f(x, a, b) = \frac{\Gamma(a+b) x^{a-1} (1-x)^{b-1}} 

501 {\Gamma(a) \Gamma(b)} 

502 

503 for :math:`0 <= x <= 1`, :math:`a > 0`, :math:`b > 0`, where 

504 :math:`\Gamma` is the gamma function (`scipy.special.gamma`). 

505 

506 `beta` takes :math:`a` and :math:`b` as shape parameters. 

507 

508 %(after_notes)s 

509 

510 %(example)s 

511 

512 """ 

513 def _rvs(self, a, b): 

514 return self._random_state.beta(a, b, self._size) 

515 

516 def _pdf(self, x, a, b): 

517 # gamma(a+b) * x**(a-1) * (1-x)**(b-1) 

518 # beta.pdf(x, a, b) = ------------------------------------ 

519 # gamma(a)*gamma(b) 

520 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, a, b)) 

521 

522 def _logpdf(self, x, a, b): 

523 lPx = sc.xlog1py(b - 1.0, -x) + sc.xlogy(a - 1.0, x) 

524 lPx -= sc.betaln(a, b) 

525 return lPx 

526 

527 def _cdf(self, x, a, b): 

528 return sc.btdtr(a, b, x) 

529 

530 def _ppf(self, q, a, b): 

531 return sc.btdtri(a, b, q) 

532 

533 def _stats(self, a, b): 

534 mn = a*1.0 / (a + b) 

535 var = (a*b*1.0)/(a+b+1.0)/(a+b)**2.0 

536 g1 = 2.0*(b-a)*np.sqrt((1.0+a+b)/(a*b)) / (2+a+b) 

537 g2 = 6.0*(a**3 + a**2*(1-2*b) + b**2*(1+b) - 2*a*b*(2+b)) 

538 g2 /= a*b*(a+b+2)*(a+b+3) 

539 return mn, var, g1, g2 

540 

541 def _fitstart(self, data): 

542 g1 = _skew(data) 

543 g2 = _kurtosis(data) 

544 

545 def func(x): 

546 a, b = x 

547 sk = 2*(b-a)*np.sqrt(a + b + 1) / (a + b + 2) / np.sqrt(a*b) 

548 ku = a**3 - a**2*(2*b-1) + b**2*(b+1) - 2*a*b*(b+2) 

549 ku /= a*b*(a+b+2)*(a+b+3) 

550 ku *= 6 

551 return [sk-g1, ku-g2] 

552 a, b = optimize.fsolve(func, (1.0, 1.0)) 

553 return super(beta_gen, self)._fitstart(data, args=(a, b)) 

554 

555 @extend_notes_in_docstring(rv_continuous, notes="""\ 

556 In the special case where both `floc` and `fscale` are given, a 

557 `ValueError` is raised if any value `x` in `data` does not satisfy 

558 `floc < x < floc + fscale`.\n\n""") 

559 def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds): 

560 # Override rv_continuous.fit, so we can more efficiently handle the 

561 # case where floc and fscale are given. 

562 

563 floc = kwds.get('floc', None) 

564 fscale = kwds.get('fscale', None) 

565 

566 if floc is None or fscale is None: 

567 # do general fit 

568 return super(beta_gen, self).fit(data, *args, **kwds) 

569 

570 # We already got these from kwds, so just pop them. 

571 kwds.pop('floc', None) 

572 kwds.pop('fscale', None) 

573 

574 f0 = _get_fixed_fit_value(kwds, ['f0', 'fa', 'fix_a']) 

575 f1 = _get_fixed_fit_value(kwds, ['f1', 'fb', 'fix_b']) 

576 

577 _remove_optimizer_parameters(kwds) 

578 

579 if f0 is not None and f1 is not None: 

580 # This check is for consistency with `rv_continuous.fit`. 

581 raise ValueError("All parameters fixed. There is nothing to " 

582 "optimize.") 

583 

584 # Special case: loc and scale are constrained, so we are fitting 

585 # just the shape parameters. This can be done much more efficiently 

586 # than the method used in `rv_continuous.fit`. (See the subsection 

587 # "Two unknown parameters" in the section "Maximum likelihood" of 

588 # the Wikipedia article on the Beta distribution for the formulas.) 

589 

590 if not np.isfinite(data).all(): 

591 raise RuntimeError("The data contains non-finite values.") 

592 

593 # Normalize the data to the interval [0, 1]. 

594 data = (np.ravel(data) - floc) / fscale 

595 if np.any(data <= 0) or np.any(data >= 1): 

596 raise FitDataError("beta", lower=floc, upper=floc + fscale) 

597 

598 xbar = data.mean() 

599 

600 if f0 is not None or f1 is not None: 

601 # One of the shape parameters is fixed. 

602 

603 if f0 is not None: 

604 # The shape parameter a is fixed, so swap the parameters 

605 # and flip the data. We always solve for `a`. The result 

606 # will be swapped back before returning. 

607 b = f0 

608 data = 1 - data 

609 xbar = 1 - xbar 

610 else: 

611 b = f1 

612 

613 # Initial guess for a. Use the formula for the mean of the beta 

614 # distribution, E[x] = a / (a + b), to generate a reasonable 

615 # starting point based on the mean of the data and the given 

616 # value of b. 

617 a = b * xbar / (1 - xbar) 

618 

619 # Compute the MLE for `a` by solving _beta_mle_a. 

620 theta, info, ier, mesg = optimize.fsolve( 

621 _beta_mle_a, a, 

622 args=(b, len(data), np.log(data).sum()), 

623 full_output=True 

624 ) 

625 if ier != 1: 

626 raise FitSolverError(mesg=mesg) 

627 a = theta[0] 

628 

629 if f0 is not None: 

630 # The shape parameter a was fixed, so swap back the 

631 # parameters. 

632 a, b = b, a 

633 

634 else: 

635 # Neither of the shape parameters is fixed. 

636 

637 # s1 and s2 are used in the extra arguments passed to _beta_mle_ab 

638 # by optimize.fsolve. 

639 s1 = np.log(data).sum() 

640 s2 = sc.log1p(-data).sum() 

641 

642 # Use the "method of moments" to estimate the initial 

643 # guess for a and b. 

644 fac = xbar * (1 - xbar) / data.var(ddof=0) - 1 

645 a = xbar * fac 

646 b = (1 - xbar) * fac 

647 

648 # Compute the MLE for a and b by solving _beta_mle_ab. 

649 theta, info, ier, mesg = optimize.fsolve( 

650 _beta_mle_ab, [a, b], 

651 args=(len(data), s1, s2), 

652 full_output=True 

653 ) 

654 if ier != 1: 

655 raise FitSolverError(mesg=mesg) 

656 a, b = theta 

657 

658 return a, b, floc, fscale 

659 

660 

661beta = beta_gen(a=0.0, b=1.0, name='beta') 

662 

663 

664class betaprime_gen(rv_continuous): 

665 r"""A beta prime continuous random variable. 

666 

667 %(before_notes)s 

668 

669 Notes 

670 ----- 

671 The probability density function for `betaprime` is: 

672 

673 .. math:: 

674 

675 f(x, a, b) = \frac{x^{a-1} (1+x)^{-a-b}}{\beta(a, b)} 

676 

677 for :math:`x >= 0`, :math:`a > 0`, :math:`b > 0`, where 

678 :math:`\beta(a, b)` is the beta function (see `scipy.special.beta`). 

679 

680 `betaprime` takes ``a`` and ``b`` as shape parameters. 

681 

682 %(after_notes)s 

683 

684 %(example)s 

685 

686 """ 

687 _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask 

688 

689 def _rvs(self, a, b): 

690 sz, rndm = self._size, self._random_state 

691 u1 = gamma.rvs(a, size=sz, random_state=rndm) 

692 u2 = gamma.rvs(b, size=sz, random_state=rndm) 

693 return u1 / u2 

694 

695 def _pdf(self, x, a, b): 

696 # betaprime.pdf(x, a, b) = x**(a-1) * (1+x)**(-a-b) / beta(a, b) 

697 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, a, b)) 

698 

699 def _logpdf(self, x, a, b): 

700 return sc.xlogy(a - 1.0, x) - sc.xlog1py(a + b, x) - sc.betaln(a, b) 

701 

702 def _cdf(self, x, a, b): 

703 return sc.betainc(a, b, x/(1.+x)) 

704 

705 def _munp(self, n, a, b): 

706 if n == 1.0: 

707 return np.where(b > 1, 

708 a/(b-1.0), 

709 np.inf) 

710 elif n == 2.0: 

711 return np.where(b > 2, 

712 a*(a+1.0)/((b-2.0)*(b-1.0)), 

713 np.inf) 

714 elif n == 3.0: 

715 return np.where(b > 3, 

716 a*(a+1.0)*(a+2.0)/((b-3.0)*(b-2.0)*(b-1.0)), 

717 np.inf) 

718 elif n == 4.0: 

719 return np.where(b > 4, 

720 (a*(a + 1.0)*(a + 2.0)*(a + 3.0) / 

721 ((b - 4.0)*(b - 3.0)*(b - 2.0)*(b - 1.0))), 

722 np.inf) 

723 else: 

724 raise NotImplementedError 

725 

726 

727betaprime = betaprime_gen(a=0.0, name='betaprime') 

728 

729 

730class bradford_gen(rv_continuous): 

731 r"""A Bradford continuous random variable. 

732 

733 %(before_notes)s 

734 

735 Notes 

736 ----- 

737 The probability density function for `bradford` is: 

738 

739 .. math:: 

740 

741 f(x, c) = \frac{c}{\log(1+c) (1+cx)} 

742 

743 for :math:`0 <= x <= 1` and :math:`c > 0`. 

744 

745 `bradford` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 

746 

747 %(after_notes)s 

748 

749 %(example)s 

750 

751 """ 

752 def _pdf(self, x, c): 

753 # bradford.pdf(x, c) = c / (k * (1+c*x)) 

754 return c / (c*x + 1.0) / sc.log1p(c) 

755 

756 def _cdf(self, x, c): 

757 return sc.log1p(c*x) / sc.log1p(c) 

758 

759 def _ppf(self, q, c): 

760 return sc.expm1(q * sc.log1p(c)) / c 

761 

762 def _stats(self, c, moments='mv'): 

763 k = np.log(1.0+c) 

764 mu = (c-k)/(c*k) 

765 mu2 = ((c+2.0)*k-2.0*c)/(2*c*k*k) 

766 g1 = None 

767 g2 = None 

768 if 's' in moments: 

769 g1 = np.sqrt(2)*(12*c*c-9*c*k*(c+2)+2*k*k*(c*(c+3)+3)) 

770 g1 /= np.sqrt(c*(c*(k-2)+2*k))*(3*c*(k-2)+6*k) 

771 if 'k' in moments: 

772 g2 = (c**3*(k-3)*(k*(3*k-16)+24)+12*k*c*c*(k-4)*(k-3) + 

773 6*c*k*k*(3*k-14) + 12*k**3) 

774 g2 /= 3*c*(c*(k-2)+2*k)**2 

775 return mu, mu2, g1, g2 

776 

777 def _entropy(self, c): 

778 k = np.log(1+c) 

779 return k/2.0 - np.log(c/k) 

780 

781 

782bradford = bradford_gen(a=0.0, b=1.0, name='bradford') 

783 

784 

785class burr_gen(rv_continuous): 

786 r"""A Burr (Type III) continuous random variable. 

787 

788 %(before_notes)s 

789 

790 See Also 

791 -------- 

792 fisk : a special case of either `burr` or `burr12` with ``d=1`` 

793 burr12 : Burr Type XII distribution 

794 mielke : Mielke Beta-Kappa / Dagum distribution 

795 

796 Notes 

797 ----- 

798 The probability density function for `burr` is: 

799 

800 .. math:: 

801 

802 f(x, c, d) = c d x^{-c - 1} / (1 + x^{-c})^{d + 1} 

803 

804 for :math:`x >= 0` and :math:`c, d > 0`. 

805 

806 `burr` takes :math:`c` and :math:`d` as shape parameters. 

807 

808 This is the PDF corresponding to the third CDF given in Burr's list; 

809 specifically, it is equation (11) in Burr's paper [1]_. The distribution 

810 is also commonly referred to as the Dagum distribution [2]_. If the 

811 parameter :math:`c < 1` then the mean of the distribution does not 

812 exist and if :math:`c < 2` the variance does not exist [2]_. 

813 The PDF is finite at the left endpoint :math:`x = 0` if :math:`c * d >= 1`. 

814 

815 %(after_notes)s 

816 

817 References 

818 ---------- 

819 .. [1] Burr, I. W. "Cumulative frequency functions", Annals of 

820 Mathematical Statistics, 13(2), pp 215-232 (1942). 

821 .. [2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dagum_distribution 

822 .. [3] Kleiber, Christian. "A guide to the Dagum distributions." 

823 Modeling Income Distributions and Lorenz Curves pp 97-117 (2008). 

824 

825 %(example)s 

826 

827 """ 

828 # Do not set _support_mask to rv_continuous._open_support_mask 

829 # Whether the left-hand endpoint is suitable for pdf evaluation is dependent 

830 # on the values of c and d: if c*d >= 1, the pdf is finite, otherwise infinite. 

831 

832 def _pdf(self, x, c, d): 

833 # burr.pdf(x, c, d) = c * d * x**(-c-1) * (1+x**(-c))**(-d-1) 

834 output = _lazywhere(x == 0, [x, c, d], 

835 lambda x_, c_, d_: c_ * d_ * (x_**(c_*d_-1)) / (1 + x_**c_), 

836 f2 = lambda x_, c_, d_: (c_ * d_ * (x_ ** (-c_ - 1.0)) / 

837 ((1 + x_ ** (-c_)) ** (d_ + 1.0)))) 

838 if output.ndim == 0: 

839 return output[()] 

840 return output 

841 

842 def _logpdf(self, x, c, d): 

843 output = _lazywhere( 

844 x == 0, [x, c, d], 

845 lambda x_, c_, d_: (np.log(c_) + np.log(d_) + sc.xlogy(c_*d_ - 1, x_) 

846 - (d_+1) * sc.log1p(x_**(c_))), 

847 f2 = lambda x_, c_, d_: (np.log(c_) + np.log(d_) 

848 + sc.xlogy(-c_ - 1, x_) 

849 - sc.xlog1py(d_+1, x_**(-c_)))) 

850 if output.ndim == 0: 

851 return output[()] 

852 return output 

853 

854 def _cdf(self, x, c, d): 

855 return (1 + x**(-c))**(-d) 

856 

857 def _logcdf(self, x, c, d): 

858 return sc.log1p(x**(-c)) * (-d) 

859 

860 def _sf(self, x, c, d): 

861 return np.exp(self._logsf(x, c, d)) 

862 

863 def _logsf(self, x, c, d): 

864 return np.log1p(- (1 + x**(-c))**(-d)) 

865 

866 def _ppf(self, q, c, d): 

867 return (q**(-1.0/d) - 1)**(-1.0/c) 

868 

869 def _stats(self, c, d): 

870 nc = np.arange(1, 5).reshape(4,1) / c 

871 #ek is the kth raw moment, e1 is the mean e2-e1**2 variance etc. 

872 e1, e2, e3, e4 = sc.beta(d + nc, 1. - nc) * d 

873 mu = np.where(c > 1.0, e1, np.nan) 

874 mu2_if_c = e2 - mu**2 

875 mu2 = np.where(c > 2.0, mu2_if_c, np.nan) 

876 g1 = _lazywhere( 

877 c > 3.0, 

878 (c, e1, e2, e3, mu2_if_c), 

879 lambda c, e1, e2, e3, mu2_if_c: (e3 - 3*e2*e1 + 2*e1**3) / np.sqrt((mu2_if_c)**3), 

880 fillvalue=np.nan) 

881 g2 = _lazywhere( 

882 c > 4.0, 

883 (c, e1, e2, e3, e4, mu2_if_c), 

884 lambda c, e1, e2, e3, e4, mu2_if_c: ( 

885 ((e4 - 4*e3*e1 + 6*e2*e1**2 - 3*e1**4) / mu2_if_c**2) - 3), 

886 fillvalue=np.nan) 

887 return mu, mu2, g1, g2 

888 

889 def _munp(self, n, c, d): 

890 def __munp(n, c, d): 

891 nc = 1. * n / c 

892 return d * sc.beta(1.0 - nc, d + nc) 

893 n, c, d = np.asarray(n), np.asarray(c), np.asarray(d) 

894 return _lazywhere((c > n) & (n == n) & (d == d), (c, d, n), 

895 lambda c, d, n: __munp(n, c, d), 

896 np.nan) 

897 

898 

899burr = burr_gen(a=0.0, name='burr') 

900 

901 

902class burr12_gen(rv_continuous): 

903 r"""A Burr (Type XII) continuous random variable. 

904 

905 %(before_notes)s 

906 

907 See Also 

908 -------- 

909 fisk : a special case of either `burr` or `burr12` with ``d=1`` 

910 burr : Burr Type III distribution 

911 

912 Notes 

913 ----- 

914 The probability density function for `burr` is: 

915 

916 .. math:: 

917 

918 f(x, c, d) = c d x^{c-1} / (1 + x^c)^{d + 1} 

919 

920 for :math:`x >= 0` and :math:`c, d > 0`. 

921 

922 `burr12` takes ``c`` and ``d`` as shape parameters for :math:`c` 

923 and :math:`d`. 

924 

925 This is the PDF corresponding to the twelfth CDF given in Burr's list; 

926 specifically, it is equation (20) in Burr's paper [1]_. 

927 

928 %(after_notes)s 

929 

930 The Burr type 12 distribution is also sometimes referred to as 

931 the Singh-Maddala distribution from NIST [2]_. 

932 

933 References 

934 ---------- 

935 .. [1] Burr, I. W. "Cumulative frequency functions", Annals of 

936 Mathematical Statistics, 13(2), pp 215-232 (1942). 

937 

938 .. [2] https://www.itl.nist.gov/div898/software/dataplot/refman2/auxillar/b12pdf.htm 

939 

940 .. [3] "Burr distribution", 

941 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burr_distribution 

942 

943 %(example)s 

944 

945 """ 

946 def _pdf(self, x, c, d): 

947 # burr12.pdf(x, c, d) = c * d * x**(c-1) * (1+x**(c))**(-d-1) 

948 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, c, d)) 

949 

950 def _logpdf(self, x, c, d): 

951 return np.log(c) + np.log(d) + sc.xlogy(c - 1, x) + sc.xlog1py(-d-1, x**c) 

952 

953 def _cdf(self, x, c, d): 

954 return -sc.expm1(self._logsf(x, c, d)) 

955 

956 def _logcdf(self, x, c, d): 

957 return sc.log1p(-(1 + x**c)**(-d)) 

958 

959 def _sf(self, x, c, d): 

960 return np.exp(self._logsf(x, c, d)) 

961 

962 def _logsf(self, x, c, d): 

963 return sc.xlog1py(-d, x**c) 

964 

965 def _ppf(self, q, c, d): 

966 # The following is an implementation of 

967 # ((1 - q)**(-1.0/d) - 1)**(1.0/c) 

968 # that does a better job handling small values of q. 

969 return sc.expm1(-1/d * sc.log1p(-q))**(1/c) 

970 

971 def _munp(self, n, c, d): 

972 nc = 1. * n / c 

973 return d * sc.beta(1.0 + nc, d - nc) 

974 

975 

976burr12 = burr12_gen(a=0.0, name='burr12') 

977 

978 

979class fisk_gen(burr_gen): 

980 r"""A Fisk continuous random variable. 

981 

982 The Fisk distribution is also known as the log-logistic distribution. 

983 

984 %(before_notes)s 

985 

986 Notes 

987 ----- 

988 The probability density function for `fisk` is: 

989 

990 .. math:: 

991 

992 f(x, c) = c x^{-c-1} (1 + x^{-c})^{-2} 

993 

994 for :math:`x >= 0` and :math:`c > 0`. 

995 

996 `fisk` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 

997 

998 `fisk` is a special case of `burr` or `burr12` with ``d=1``. 

999 

1000 %(after_notes)s 

1001 

1002 See Also 

1003 -------- 

1004 burr 

1005 

1006 %(example)s 

1007 

1008 """ 

1009 def _pdf(self, x, c): 

1010 # fisk.pdf(x, c) = c * x**(-c-1) * (1 + x**(-c))**(-2) 

1011 return burr._pdf(x, c, 1.0) 

1012 

1013 def _cdf(self, x, c): 

1014 return burr._cdf(x, c, 1.0) 

1015 

1016 def _sf(self, x, c): 

1017 return burr._sf(x, c, 1.0) 

1018 

1019 def _logpdf(self, x, c): 

1020 # fisk.pdf(x, c) = c * x**(-c-1) * (1 + x**(-c))**(-2) 

1021 return burr._logpdf(x, c, 1.0) 

1022 

1023 def _logcdf(self, x, c): 

1024 return burr._logcdf(x, c, 1.0) 

1025 

1026 def _logsf(self, x, c): 

1027 return burr._logsf(x, c, 1.0) 

1028 

1029 def _ppf(self, x, c): 

1030 return burr._ppf(x, c, 1.0) 

1031 

1032 def _munp(self, n, c): 

1033 return burr._munp(n, c, 1.0) 

1034 

1035 def _stats(self, c): 

1036 return burr._stats(c, 1.0) 

1037 

1038 def _entropy(self, c): 

1039 return 2 - np.log(c) 

1040 

1041 

1042fisk = fisk_gen(a=0.0, name='fisk') 

1043 

1044 

1045# median = loc 

1046class cauchy_gen(rv_continuous): 

1047 r"""A Cauchy continuous random variable. 

1048 

1049 %(before_notes)s 

1050 

1051 Notes 

1052 ----- 

1053 The probability density function for `cauchy` is 

1054 

1055 .. math:: 

1056 

1057 f(x) = \frac{1}{\pi (1 + x^2)} 

1058 

1059 for a real number :math:`x`. 

1060 

1061 %(after_notes)s 

1062 

1063 %(example)s 

1064 

1065 """ 

1066 def _pdf(self, x): 

1067 # cauchy.pdf(x) = 1 / (pi * (1 + x**2)) 

1068 return 1.0/np.pi/(1.0+x*x) 

1069 

1070 def _cdf(self, x): 

1071 return 0.5 + 1.0/np.pi*np.arctan(x) 

1072 

1073 def _ppf(self, q): 

1074 return np.tan(np.pi*q-np.pi/2.0) 

1075 

1076 def _sf(self, x): 

1077 return 0.5 - 1.0/np.pi*np.arctan(x) 

1078 

1079 def _isf(self, q): 

1080 return np.tan(np.pi/2.0-np.pi*q) 

1081 

1082 def _stats(self): 

1083 return np.nan, np.nan, np.nan, np.nan 

1084 

1085 def _entropy(self): 

1086 return np.log(4*np.pi) 

1087 

1088 def _fitstart(self, data, args=None): 

1089 # Initialize ML guesses using quartiles instead of moments. 

1090 p25, p50, p75 = np.percentile(data, [25, 50, 75]) 

1091 return p50, (p75 - p25)/2 

1092 

1093 

1094cauchy = cauchy_gen(name='cauchy') 

1095 

1096 

1097class chi_gen(rv_continuous): 

1098 r"""A chi continuous random variable. 

1099 

1100 %(before_notes)s 

1101 

1102 Notes 

1103 ----- 

1104 The probability density function for `chi` is: 

1105 

1106 .. math:: 

1107 

1108 f(x, k) = \frac{1}{2^{k/2-1} \Gamma \left( k/2 \right)} 

1109 x^{k-1} \exp \left( -x^2/2 \right) 

1110 

1111 for :math:`x >= 0` and :math:`k > 0` (degrees of freedom, denoted ``df`` 

1112 in the implementation). :math:`\Gamma` is the gamma function 

1113 (`scipy.special.gamma`). 

1114 

1115 Special cases of `chi` are: 

1116 

1117 - ``chi(1, loc, scale)`` is equivalent to `halfnorm` 

1118 - ``chi(2, 0, scale)`` is equivalent to `rayleigh` 

1119 - ``chi(3, 0, scale)`` is equivalent to `maxwell` 

1120 

1121 `chi` takes ``df`` as a shape parameter. 

1122 

1123 %(after_notes)s 

1124 

1125 %(example)s 

1126 

1127 """ 

1128 

1129 def _rvs(self, df): 

1130 sz, rndm = self._size, self._random_state 

1131 return np.sqrt(chi2.rvs(df, size=sz, random_state=rndm)) 

1132 

1133 def _pdf(self, x, df): 

1134 # x**(df-1) * exp(-x**2/2) 

1135 # chi.pdf(x, df) = ------------------------- 

1136 # 2**(df/2-1) * gamma(df/2) 

1137 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, df)) 

1138 

1139 def _logpdf(self, x, df): 

1140 l = np.log(2) - .5*np.log(2)*df - sc.gammaln(.5*df) 

1141 return l + sc.xlogy(df - 1., x) - .5*x**2 

1142 

1143 def _cdf(self, x, df): 

1144 return sc.gammainc(.5*df, .5*x**2) 

1145 

1146 def _ppf(self, q, df): 

1147 return np.sqrt(2*sc.gammaincinv(.5*df, q)) 

1148 

1149 def _stats(self, df): 

1150 mu = np.sqrt(2)*sc.gamma(df/2.0+0.5)/sc.gamma(df/2.0) 

1151 mu2 = df - mu*mu 

1152 g1 = (2*mu**3.0 + mu*(1-2*df))/np.asarray(np.power(mu2, 1.5)) 

1153 g2 = 2*df*(1.0-df)-6*mu**4 + 4*mu**2 * (2*df-1) 

1154 g2 /= np.asarray(mu2**2.0) 

1155 return mu, mu2, g1, g2 

1156 

1157 

1158chi = chi_gen(a=0.0, name='chi') 

1159 

1160 

1161## Chi-squared (gamma-distributed with loc=0 and scale=2 and shape=df/2) 

1162class chi2_gen(rv_continuous): 

1163 r"""A chi-squared continuous random variable. 

1164 

1165 %(before_notes)s 

1166 

1167 Notes 

1168 ----- 

1169 The probability density function for `chi2` is: 

1170 

1171 .. math:: 

1172 

1173 f(x, k) = \frac{1}{2^{k/2} \Gamma \left( k/2 \right)} 

1174 x^{k/2-1} \exp \left( -x/2 \right) 

1175 

1176 for :math:`x > 0` and :math:`k > 0` (degrees of freedom, denoted ``df`` 

1177 in the implementation). 

1178 

1179 `chi2` takes ``df`` as a shape parameter. 

1180 

1181 %(after_notes)s 

1182 

1183 %(example)s 

1184 

1185 """ 

1186 def _rvs(self, df): 

1187 return self._random_state.chisquare(df, self._size) 

1188 

1189 def _pdf(self, x, df): 

1190 # chi2.pdf(x, df) = 1 / (2*gamma(df/2)) * (x/2)**(df/2-1) * exp(-x/2) 

1191 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, df)) 

1192 

1193 def _logpdf(self, x, df): 

1194 return sc.xlogy(df/2.-1, x) - x/2. - sc.gammaln(df/2.) - (np.log(2)*df)/2. 

1195 

1196 def _cdf(self, x, df): 

1197 return sc.chdtr(df, x) 

1198 

1199 def _sf(self, x, df): 

1200 return sc.chdtrc(df, x) 

1201 

1202 def _isf(self, p, df): 

1203 return sc.chdtri(df, p) 

1204 

1205 def _ppf(self, p, df): 

1206 return 2*sc.gammaincinv(df/2, p) 

1207 

1208 def _stats(self, df): 

1209 mu = df 

1210 mu2 = 2*df 

1211 g1 = 2*np.sqrt(2.0/df) 

1212 g2 = 12.0/df 

1213 return mu, mu2, g1, g2 

1214 

1215 

1216chi2 = chi2_gen(a=0.0, name='chi2') 

1217 

1218 

1219class cosine_gen(rv_continuous): 

1220 r"""A cosine continuous random variable. 

1221 

1222 %(before_notes)s 

1223 

1224 Notes 

1225 ----- 

1226 The cosine distribution is an approximation to the normal distribution. 

1227 The probability density function for `cosine` is: 

1228 

1229 .. math:: 

1230 

1231 f(x) = \frac{1}{2\pi} (1+\cos(x)) 

1232 

1233 for :math:`-\pi \le x \le \pi`. 

1234 

1235 %(after_notes)s 

1236 

1237 %(example)s 

1238 

1239 """ 

1240 def _pdf(self, x): 

1241 # cosine.pdf(x) = 1/(2*pi) * (1+cos(x)) 

1242 return 1.0/2/np.pi*(1+np.cos(x)) 

1243 

1244 def _cdf(self, x): 

1245 return 1.0/2/np.pi*(np.pi + x + np.sin(x)) 

1246 

1247 def _stats(self): 

1248 return 0.0, np.pi*np.pi/3.0-2.0, 0.0, -6.0*(np.pi**4-90)/(5.0*(np.pi*np.pi-6)**2) 

1249 

1250 def _entropy(self): 

1251 return np.log(4*np.pi)-1.0 

1252 

1253 

1254cosine = cosine_gen(a=-np.pi, b=np.pi, name='cosine') 

1255 

1256 

1257class dgamma_gen(rv_continuous): 

1258 r"""A double gamma continuous random variable. 

1259 

1260 %(before_notes)s 

1261 

1262 Notes 

1263 ----- 

1264 The probability density function for `dgamma` is: 

1265 

1266 .. math:: 

1267 

1268 f(x, a) = \frac{1}{2\Gamma(a)} |x|^{a-1} \exp(-|x|) 

1269 

1270 for a real number :math:`x` and :math:`a > 0`. :math:`\Gamma` is the 

1271 gamma function (`scipy.special.gamma`). 

1272 

1273 `dgamma` takes ``a`` as a shape parameter for :math:`a`. 

1274 

1275 %(after_notes)s 

1276 

1277 %(example)s 

1278 

1279 """ 

1280 def _rvs(self, a): 

1281 sz, rndm = self._size, self._random_state 

1282 u = rndm.random_sample(size=sz) 

1283 gm = gamma.rvs(a, size=sz, random_state=rndm) 

1284 return gm * np.where(u >= 0.5, 1, -1) 

1285 

1286 def _pdf(self, x, a): 

1287 # dgamma.pdf(x, a) = 1 / (2*gamma(a)) * abs(x)**(a-1) * exp(-abs(x)) 

1288 ax = abs(x) 

1289 return 1.0/(2*sc.gamma(a))*ax**(a-1.0) * np.exp(-ax) 

1290 

1291 def _logpdf(self, x, a): 

1292 ax = abs(x) 

1293 return sc.xlogy(a - 1.0, ax) - ax - np.log(2) - sc.gammaln(a) 

1294 

1295 def _cdf(self, x, a): 

1296 fac = 0.5*sc.gammainc(a, abs(x)) 

1297 return np.where(x > 0, 0.5 + fac, 0.5 - fac) 

1298 

1299 def _sf(self, x, a): 

1300 fac = 0.5*sc.gammainc(a, abs(x)) 

1301 return np.where(x > 0, 0.5-fac, 0.5+fac) 

1302 

1303 def _ppf(self, q, a): 

1304 fac = sc.gammainccinv(a, 1-abs(2*q-1)) 

1305 return np.where(q > 0.5, fac, -fac) 

1306 

1307 def _stats(self, a): 

1308 mu2 = a*(a+1.0) 

1309 return 0.0, mu2, 0.0, (a+2.0)*(a+3.0)/mu2-3.0 

1310 

1311 

1312dgamma = dgamma_gen(name='dgamma') 

1313 

1314 

1315class dweibull_gen(rv_continuous): 

1316 r"""A double Weibull continuous random variable. 

1317 

1318 %(before_notes)s 

1319 

1320 Notes 

1321 ----- 

1322 The probability density function for `dweibull` is given by 

1323 

1324 .. math:: 

1325 

1326 f(x, c) = c / 2 |x|^{c-1} \exp(-|x|^c) 

1327 

1328 for a real number :math:`x` and :math:`c > 0`. 

1329 

1330 `dweibull` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 

1331 

1332 %(after_notes)s 

1333 

1334 %(example)s 

1335 

1336 """ 

1337 def _rvs(self, c): 

1338 sz, rndm = self._size, self._random_state 

1339 u = rndm.random_sample(size=sz) 

1340 w = weibull_min.rvs(c, size=sz, random_state=rndm) 

1341 return w * (np.where(u >= 0.5, 1, -1)) 

1342 

1343 def _pdf(self, x, c): 

1344 # dweibull.pdf(x, c) = c / 2 * abs(x)**(c-1) * exp(-abs(x)**c) 

1345 ax = abs(x) 

1346 Px = c / 2.0 * ax**(c-1.0) * np.exp(-ax**c) 

1347 return Px 

1348 

1349 def _logpdf(self, x, c): 

1350 ax = abs(x) 

1351 return np.log(c) - np.log(2.0) + sc.xlogy(c - 1.0, ax) - ax**c 

1352 

1353 def _cdf(self, x, c): 

1354 Cx1 = 0.5 * np.exp(-abs(x)**c) 

1355 return np.where(x > 0, 1 - Cx1, Cx1) 

1356 

1357 def _ppf(self, q, c): 

1358 fac = 2. * np.where(q <= 0.5, q, 1. - q) 

1359 fac = np.power(-np.log(fac), 1.0 / c) 

1360 return np.where(q > 0.5, fac, -fac) 

1361 

1362 def _munp(self, n, c): 

1363 return (1 - (n % 2)) * sc.gamma(1.0 + 1.0 * n / c) 

1364 

1365 # since we know that all odd moments are zeros, return them at once. 

1366 # returning Nones from _stats makes the public stats call _munp 

1367 # so overall we're saving one or two gamma function evaluations here. 

1368 def _stats(self, c): 

1369 return 0, None, 0, None 

1370 

1371 

1372dweibull = dweibull_gen(name='dweibull') 

1373 

1374 

1375## Exponential (gamma distributed with a=1.0, loc=loc and scale=scale) 

1376class expon_gen(rv_continuous): 

1377 r"""An exponential continuous random variable. 

1378 

1379 %(before_notes)s 

1380 

1381 Notes 

1382 ----- 

1383 The probability density function for `expon` is: 

1384 

1385 .. math:: 

1386 

1387 f(x) = \exp(-x) 

1388 

1389 for :math:`x \ge 0`. 

1390 

1391 %(after_notes)s 

1392 

1393 A common parameterization for `expon` is in terms of the rate parameter 

1394 ``lambda``, such that ``pdf = lambda * exp(-lambda * x)``. This 

1395 parameterization corresponds to using ``scale = 1 / lambda``. 

1396 

1397 %(example)s 

1398 

1399 """ 

1400 def _rvs(self): 

1401 return self._random_state.standard_exponential(self._size) 

1402 

1403 def _pdf(self, x): 

1404 # expon.pdf(x) = exp(-x) 

1405 return np.exp(-x) 

1406 

1407 def _logpdf(self, x): 

1408 return -x 

1409 

1410 def _cdf(self, x): 

1411 return -sc.expm1(-x) 

1412 

1413 def _ppf(self, q): 

1414 return -sc.log1p(-q) 

1415 

1416 def _sf(self, x): 

1417 return np.exp(-x) 

1418 

1419 def _logsf(self, x): 

1420 return -x 

1421 

1422 def _isf(self, q): 

1423 return -np.log(q) 

1424 

1425 def _stats(self): 

1426 return 1.0, 1.0, 2.0, 6.0 

1427 

1428 def _entropy(self): 

1429 return 1.0 

1430 

1431 @replace_notes_in_docstring(rv_continuous, notes="""\ 

1432 This function uses explicit formulas for the maximum likelihood 

1433 estimation of the exponential distribution parameters, so the 

1434 `optimizer`, `loc` and `scale` keyword arguments are ignored.\n\n""") 

1435 def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds): 

1436 if len(args) > 0: 

1437 raise TypeError("Too many arguments.") 

1438 

1439 floc = kwds.pop('floc', None) 

1440 fscale = kwds.pop('fscale', None) 

1441 

1442 _remove_optimizer_parameters(kwds) 

1443 

1444 if floc is not None and fscale is not None: 

1445 # This check is for consistency with `rv_continuous.fit`. 

1446 raise ValueError("All parameters fixed. There is nothing to " 

1447 "optimize.") 

1448 

1449 data = np.asarray(data) 

1450 

1451 if not np.isfinite(data).all(): 

1452 raise RuntimeError("The data contains non-finite values.") 

1453 

1454 data_min = data.min() 

1455 

1456 if floc is None: 

1457 # ML estimate of the location is the minimum of the data. 

1458 loc = data_min 

1459 else: 

1460 loc = floc 

1461 if data_min < loc: 

1462 # There are values that are less than the specified loc. 

1463 raise FitDataError("expon", lower=floc, upper=np.inf) 

1464 

1465 if fscale is None: 

1466 # ML estimate of the scale is the shifted mean. 

1467 scale = data.mean() - loc 

1468 else: 

1469 scale = fscale 

1470 

1471 # We expect the return values to be floating point, so ensure it 

1472 # by explicitly converting to float. 

1473 return float(loc), float(scale) 

1474 

1475 

1476expon = expon_gen(a=0.0, name='expon') 

1477 

1478 

1479## Exponentially Modified Normal (exponential distribution 

1480## convolved with a Normal). 

1481## This is called an exponentially modified gaussian on wikipedia 

1482class exponnorm_gen(rv_continuous): 

1483 r"""An exponentially modified Normal continuous random variable. 

1484 

1485 %(before_notes)s 

1486 

1487 Notes 

1488 ----- 

1489 The probability density function for `exponnorm` is: 

1490 

1491 .. math:: 

1492 

1493 f(x, K) = \frac{1}{2K} \exp\left(\frac{1}{2 K^2} - x / K \right) 

1494 \text{erfc}\left(-\frac{x - 1/K}{\sqrt{2}}\right) 

1495 

1496 where :math:`x` is a real number and :math:`K > 0`. 

1497 

1498 It can be thought of as the sum of a standard normal random variable 

1499 and an independent exponentially distributed random variable with rate 

1500 ``1/K``. 

1501 

1502 %(after_notes)s 

1503 

1504 An alternative parameterization of this distribution (for example, in 

1505 `Wikipedia <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponentially_modified_Gaussian_distribution>`_) 

1506 involves three parameters, :math:`\mu`, :math:`\lambda` and 

1507 :math:`\sigma`. 

1508 In the present parameterization this corresponds to having ``loc`` and 

1509 ``scale`` equal to :math:`\mu` and :math:`\sigma`, respectively, and 

1510 shape parameter :math:`K = 1/(\sigma\lambda)`. 

1511 

1512 .. versionadded:: 0.16.0 

1513 

1514 %(example)s 

1515 

1516 """ 

1517 def _rvs(self, K): 

1518 expval = self._random_state.standard_exponential(self._size) * K 

1519 gval = self._random_state.standard_normal(self._size) 

1520 return expval + gval 

1521 

1522 def _pdf(self, x, K): 

1523 # exponnorm.pdf(x, K) = 

1524 # 1/(2*K) exp(1/(2 * K**2)) exp(-x / K) * erfc-(x - 1/K) / sqrt(2)) 

1525 invK = 1.0 / K 

1526 exparg = 0.5 * invK**2 - invK * x 

1527 # Avoid overflows; setting np.exp(exparg) to the max float works 

1528 # all right here 

1529 expval = _lazywhere(exparg < _LOGXMAX, (exparg,), np.exp, _XMAX) 

1530 return 0.5 * invK * (expval * sc.erfc(-(x - invK) / np.sqrt(2))) 

1531 

1532 def _logpdf(self, x, K): 

1533 invK = 1.0 / K 

1534 exparg = 0.5 * invK**2 - invK * x 

1535 return exparg + np.log(0.5 * invK * sc.erfc(-(x - invK) / np.sqrt(2))) 

1536 

1537 def _cdf(self, x, K): 

1538 invK = 1.0 / K 

1539 expval = invK * (0.5 * invK - x) 

1540 return _norm_cdf(x) - np.exp(expval) * _norm_cdf(x - invK) 

1541 

1542 def _sf(self, x, K): 

1543 invK = 1.0 / K 

1544 expval = invK * (0.5 * invK - x) 

1545 return _norm_cdf(-x) + np.exp(expval) * _norm_cdf(x - invK) 

1546 

1547 def _stats(self, K): 

1548 K2 = K * K 

1549 opK2 = 1.0 + K2 

1550 skw = 2 * K**3 * opK2**(-1.5) 

1551 krt = 6.0 * K2 * K2 * opK2**(-2) 

1552 return K, opK2, skw, krt 

1553 

1554 

1555exponnorm = exponnorm_gen(name='exponnorm') 

1556 

1557 

1558class exponweib_gen(rv_continuous): 

1559 r"""An exponentiated Weibull continuous random variable. 

1560 

1561 %(before_notes)s 

1562 

1563 See Also 

1564 -------- 

1565 weibull_min, numpy.random.mtrand.RandomState.weibull 

1566 

1567 Notes 

1568 ----- 

1569 The probability density function for `exponweib` is: 

1570 

1571 .. math:: 

1572 

1573 f(x, a, c) = a c [1-\exp(-x^c)]^{a-1} \exp(-x^c) x^{c-1} 

1574 

1575 and its cumulative distribution function is: 

1576 

1577 .. math:: 

1578 

1579 F(x, a, c) = [1-\exp(-x^c)]^a 

1580 

1581 for :math:`x > 0`, :math:`a > 0`, :math:`c > 0`. 

1582 

1583 `exponweib` takes :math:`a` and :math:`c` as shape parameters: 

1584 

1585 * :math:`a` is the exponentiation parameter, 

1586 with the special case :math:`a=1` corresponding to the 

1587 (non-exponentiated) Weibull distribution `weibull_min`. 

1588 * :math:`c` is the shape parameter of the non-exponentiated Weibull law. 

1589 

1590 %(after_notes)s 

1591 

1592 References 

1593 ---------- 

1594 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponentiated_Weibull_distribution 

1595 

1596 %(example)s 

1597 

1598 """ 

1599 def _pdf(self, x, a, c): 

1600 # exponweib.pdf(x, a, c) = 

1601 # a * c * (1-exp(-x**c))**(a-1) * exp(-x**c)*x**(c-1) 

1602 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, a, c)) 

1603 

1604 def _logpdf(self, x, a, c): 

1605 negxc = -x**c 

1606 exm1c = -sc.expm1(negxc) 

1607 logp = (np.log(a) + np.log(c) + sc.xlogy(a - 1.0, exm1c) + 

1608 negxc + sc.xlogy(c - 1.0, x)) 

1609 return logp 

1610 

1611 def _cdf(self, x, a, c): 

1612 exm1c = -sc.expm1(-x**c) 

1613 return exm1c**a 

1614 

1615 def _ppf(self, q, a, c): 

1616 return (-sc.log1p(-q**(1.0/a)))**np.asarray(1.0/c) 

1617 

1618 

1619exponweib = exponweib_gen(a=0.0, name='exponweib') 

1620 

1621 

1622class exponpow_gen(rv_continuous): 

1623 r"""An exponential power continuous random variable. 

1624 

1625 %(before_notes)s 

1626 

1627 Notes 

1628 ----- 

1629 The probability density function for `exponpow` is: 

1630 

1631 .. math:: 

1632 

1633 f(x, b) = b x^{b-1} \exp(1 + x^b - \exp(x^b)) 

1634 

1635 for :math:`x \ge 0`, :math:`b > 0`. Note that this is a different 

1636 distribution from the exponential power distribution that is also known 

1637 under the names "generalized normal" or "generalized Gaussian". 

1638 

1639 `exponpow` takes ``b`` as a shape parameter for :math:`b`. 

1640 

1641 %(after_notes)s 

1642 

1643 References 

1644 ---------- 

1645 http://www.math.wm.edu/~leemis/chart/UDR/PDFs/Exponentialpower.pdf 

1646 

1647 %(example)s 

1648 

1649 """ 

1650 def _pdf(self, x, b): 

1651 # exponpow.pdf(x, b) = b * x**(b-1) * exp(1 + x**b - exp(x**b)) 

1652 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, b)) 

1653 

1654 def _logpdf(self, x, b): 

1655 xb = x**b 

1656 f = 1 + np.log(b) + sc.xlogy(b - 1.0, x) + xb - np.exp(xb) 

1657 return f 

1658 

1659 def _cdf(self, x, b): 

1660 return -sc.expm1(-sc.expm1(x**b)) 

1661 

1662 def _sf(self, x, b): 

1663 return np.exp(-sc.expm1(x**b)) 

1664 

1665 def _isf(self, x, b): 

1666 return (sc.log1p(-np.log(x)))**(1./b) 

1667 

1668 def _ppf(self, q, b): 

1669 return pow(sc.log1p(-sc.log1p(-q)), 1.0/b) 

1670 

1671 

1672exponpow = exponpow_gen(a=0.0, name='exponpow') 

1673 

1674 

1675class fatiguelife_gen(rv_continuous): 

1676 r"""A fatigue-life (Birnbaum-Saunders) continuous random variable. 

1677 

1678 %(before_notes)s 

1679 

1680 Notes 

1681 ----- 

1682 The probability density function for `fatiguelife` is: 

1683 

1684 .. math:: 

1685 

1686 f(x, c) = \frac{x+1}{2c\sqrt{2\pi x^3}} \exp(-\frac{(x-1)^2}{2x c^2}) 

1687 

1688 for :math:`x >= 0` and :math:`c > 0`. 

1689 

1690 `fatiguelife` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 

1691 

1692 %(after_notes)s 

1693 

1694 References 

1695 ---------- 

1696 .. [1] "Birnbaum-Saunders distribution", 

1697 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birnbaum-Saunders_distribution 

1698 

1699 %(example)s 

1700 

1701 """ 

1702 _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask 

1703 

1704 def _rvs(self, c): 

1705 z = self._random_state.standard_normal(self._size) 

1706 x = 0.5*c*z 

1707 x2 = x*x 

1708 t = 1.0 + 2*x2 + 2*x*np.sqrt(1 + x2) 

1709 return t 

1710 

1711 def _pdf(self, x, c): 

1712 # fatiguelife.pdf(x, c) = 

1713 # (x+1) / (2*c*sqrt(2*pi*x**3)) * exp(-(x-1)**2/(2*x*c**2)) 

1714 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, c)) 

1715 

1716 def _logpdf(self, x, c): 

1717 return (np.log(x+1) - (x-1)**2 / (2.0*x*c**2) - np.log(2*c) - 

1718 0.5*(np.log(2*np.pi) + 3*np.log(x))) 

1719 

1720 def _cdf(self, x, c): 

1721 return _norm_cdf(1.0 / c * (np.sqrt(x) - 1.0/np.sqrt(x))) 

1722 

1723 def _ppf(self, q, c): 

1724 tmp = c*sc.ndtri(q) 

1725 return 0.25 * (tmp + np.sqrt(tmp**2 + 4))**2 

1726 

1727 def _stats(self, c): 

1728 # NB: the formula for kurtosis in wikipedia seems to have an error: 

1729 # it's 40, not 41. At least it disagrees with the one from Wolfram 

1730 # Alpha. And the latter one, below, passes the tests, while the wiki 

1731 # one doesn't So far I didn't have the guts to actually check the 

1732 # coefficients from the expressions for the raw moments. 

1733 c2 = c*c 

1734 mu = c2 / 2.0 + 1.0 

1735 den = 5.0 * c2 + 4.0 

1736 mu2 = c2*den / 4.0 

1737 g1 = 4 * c * (11*c2 + 6.0) / np.power(den, 1.5) 

1738 g2 = 6 * c2 * (93*c2 + 40.0) / den**2.0 

1739 return mu, mu2, g1, g2 

1740 

1741 

1742fatiguelife = fatiguelife_gen(a=0.0, name='fatiguelife') 

1743 

1744 

1745class foldcauchy_gen(rv_continuous): 

1746 r"""A folded Cauchy continuous random variable. 

1747 

1748 %(before_notes)s 

1749 

1750 Notes 

1751 ----- 

1752 The probability density function for `foldcauchy` is: 

1753 

1754 .. math:: 

1755 

1756 f(x, c) = \frac{1}{\pi (1+(x-c)^2)} + \frac{1}{\pi (1+(x+c)^2)} 

1757 

1758 for :math:`x \ge 0`. 

1759 

1760 `foldcauchy` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 

1761 

1762 %(example)s 

1763 

1764 """ 

1765 def _rvs(self, c): 

1766 return abs(cauchy.rvs(loc=c, size=self._size, 

1767 random_state=self._random_state)) 

1768 

1769 def _pdf(self, x, c): 

1770 # foldcauchy.pdf(x, c) = 1/(pi*(1+(x-c)**2)) + 1/(pi*(1+(x+c)**2)) 

1771 return 1.0/np.pi*(1.0/(1+(x-c)**2) + 1.0/(1+(x+c)**2)) 

1772 

1773 def _cdf(self, x, c): 

1774 return 1.0/np.pi*(np.arctan(x-c) + np.arctan(x+c)) 

1775 

1776 def _stats(self, c): 

1777 return np.inf, np.inf, np.nan, np.nan 

1778 

1779 

1780foldcauchy = foldcauchy_gen(a=0.0, name='foldcauchy') 

1781 

1782 

1783class f_gen(rv_continuous): 

1784 r"""An F continuous random variable. 

1785 

1786 %(before_notes)s 

1787 

1788 Notes 

1789 ----- 

1790 The probability density function for `f` is: 

1791 

1792 .. math:: 

1793 

1794 f(x, df_1, df_2) = \frac{df_2^{df_2/2} df_1^{df_1/2} x^{df_1 / 2-1}} 

1795 {(df_2+df_1 x)^{(df_1+df_2)/2} 

1796 B(df_1/2, df_2/2)} 

1797 

1798 for :math:`x > 0`. 

1799 

1800 `f` takes ``dfn`` and ``dfd`` as shape parameters. 

1801 

1802 %(after_notes)s 

1803 

1804 %(example)s 

1805 

1806 """ 

1807 def _rvs(self, dfn, dfd): 

1808 return self._random_state.f(dfn, dfd, self._size) 

1809 

1810 def _pdf(self, x, dfn, dfd): 

1811 # df2**(df2/2) * df1**(df1/2) * x**(df1/2-1) 

1812 # F.pdf(x, df1, df2) = -------------------------------------------- 

1813 # (df2+df1*x)**((df1+df2)/2) * B(df1/2, df2/2) 

1814 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, dfn, dfd)) 

1815 

1816 def _logpdf(self, x, dfn, dfd): 

1817 n = 1.0 * dfn 

1818 m = 1.0 * dfd 

1819 lPx = m/2 * np.log(m) + n/2 * np.log(n) + sc.xlogy(n/2 - 1, x) 

1820 lPx -= ((n+m)/2) * np.log(m + n*x) + sc.betaln(n/2, m/2) 

1821 return lPx 

1822 

1823 def _cdf(self, x, dfn, dfd): 

1824 return sc.fdtr(dfn, dfd, x) 

1825 

1826 def _sf(self, x, dfn, dfd): 

1827 return sc.fdtrc(dfn, dfd, x) 

1828 

1829 def _ppf(self, q, dfn, dfd): 

1830 return sc.fdtri(dfn, dfd, q) 

1831 

1832 def _stats(self, dfn, dfd): 

1833 v1, v2 = 1. * dfn, 1. * dfd 

1834 v2_2, v2_4, v2_6, v2_8 = v2 - 2., v2 - 4., v2 - 6., v2 - 8. 

1835 

1836 mu = _lazywhere( 

1837 v2 > 2, (v2, v2_2), 

1838 lambda v2, v2_2: v2 / v2_2, 

1839 np.inf) 

1840 

1841 mu2 = _lazywhere( 

1842 v2 > 4, (v1, v2, v2_2, v2_4), 

1843 lambda v1, v2, v2_2, v2_4: 

1844 2 * v2 * v2 * (v1 + v2_2) / (v1 * v2_2**2 * v2_4), 

1845 np.inf) 

1846 

1847 g1 = _lazywhere( 

1848 v2 > 6, (v1, v2_2, v2_4, v2_6), 

1849 lambda v1, v2_2, v2_4, v2_6: 

1850 (2 * v1 + v2_2) / v2_6 * np.sqrt(v2_4 / (v1 * (v1 + v2_2))), 

1851 np.nan) 

1852 g1 *= np.sqrt(8.) 

1853 

1854 g2 = _lazywhere( 

1855 v2 > 8, (g1, v2_6, v2_8), 

1856 lambda g1, v2_6, v2_8: (8 + g1 * g1 * v2_6) / v2_8, 

1857 np.nan) 

1858 g2 *= 3. / 2. 

1859 

1860 return mu, mu2, g1, g2 

1861 

1862 

1863f = f_gen(a=0.0, name='f') 

1864 

1865 

1866## Folded Normal 

1867## abs(Z) where (Z is normal with mu=L and std=S so that c=abs(L)/S) 

1868## 

1869## note: regress docs have scale parameter correct, but first parameter 

1870## he gives is a shape parameter A = c * scale 

1871 

1872## Half-normal is folded normal with shape-parameter c=0. 

1873 

1874class foldnorm_gen(rv_continuous): 

1875 r"""A folded normal continuous random variable. 

1876 

1877 %(before_notes)s 

1878 

1879 Notes 

1880 ----- 

1881 The probability density function for `foldnorm` is: 

1882 

1883 .. math:: 

1884 

1885 f(x, c) = \sqrt{2/\pi} cosh(c x) \exp(-\frac{x^2+c^2}{2}) 

1886 

1887 for :math:`c \ge 0`. 

1888 

1889 `foldnorm` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 

1890 

1891 %(after_notes)s 

1892 

1893 %(example)s 

1894 

1895 """ 

1896 def _argcheck(self, c): 

1897 return c >= 0 

1898 

1899 def _rvs(self, c): 

1900 return abs(self._random_state.standard_normal(self._size) + c) 

1901 

1902 def _pdf(self, x, c): 

1903 # foldnormal.pdf(x, c) = sqrt(2/pi) * cosh(c*x) * exp(-(x**2+c**2)/2) 

1904 return _norm_pdf(x + c) + _norm_pdf(x-c) 

1905 

1906 def _cdf(self, x, c): 

1907 return _norm_cdf(x-c) + _norm_cdf(x+c) - 1.0 

1908 

1909 def _stats(self, c): 

1910 # Regina C. Elandt, Technometrics 3, 551 (1961) 

1911 # https://www.jstor.org/stable/1266561 

1912 # 

1913 c2 = c*c 

1914 expfac = np.exp(-0.5*c2) / np.sqrt(2.*np.pi) 

1915 

1916 mu = 2.*expfac + c * sc.erf(c/np.sqrt(2)) 

1917 mu2 = c2 + 1 - mu*mu 

1918 

1919 g1 = 2. * (mu*mu*mu - c2*mu - expfac) 

1920 g1 /= np.power(mu2, 1.5) 

1921 

1922 g2 = c2 * (c2 + 6.) + 3 + 8.*expfac*mu 

1923 g2 += (2. * (c2 - 3.) - 3. * mu**2) * mu**2 

1924 g2 = g2 / mu2**2.0 - 3. 

1925 

1926 return mu, mu2, g1, g2 

1927 

1928 

1929foldnorm = foldnorm_gen(a=0.0, name='foldnorm') 

1930 

1931 

1932class weibull_min_gen(rv_continuous): 

1933 r"""Weibull minimum continuous random variable. 

1934 

1935 The Weibull Minimum Extreme Value distribution, from extreme value theory, 

1936 is also often simply called the Weibull distribution. 

1937 

1938 %(before_notes)s 

1939 

1940 See Also 

1941 -------- 

1942 weibull_max, numpy.random.mtrand.RandomState.weibull, exponweib 

1943 

1944 Notes 

1945 ----- 

1946 The probability density function for `weibull_min` is: 

1947 

1948 .. math:: 

1949 

1950 f(x, c) = c x^{c-1} \exp(-x^c) 

1951 

1952 for :math:`x >= 0`, :math:`c > 0`. 

1953 

1954 `weibull_min` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 

1955 (named :math:`k` in Wikipedia article and :math:`a` in 

1956 ``numpy.random.weibull``). Special shape values are :math:`c=1` and 

1957 :math:`c=2` where Weibull distribution reduces to the `expon` and 

1958 `rayleigh` distributions respectively. 

1959 

1960 %(after_notes)s 

1961 

1962 References 

1963 ---------- 

1964 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weibull_distribution 

1965 

1966 %(example)s 

1967 

1968 """ 

1969 

1970 def _pdf(self, x, c): 

1971 # frechet_r.pdf(x, c) = c * x**(c-1) * exp(-x**c) 

1972 return c*pow(x, c-1)*np.exp(-pow(x, c)) 

1973 

1974 def _logpdf(self, x, c): 

1975 return np.log(c) + sc.xlogy(c - 1, x) - pow(x, c) 

1976 

1977 def _cdf(self, x, c): 

1978 return -sc.expm1(-pow(x, c)) 

1979 

1980 def _sf(self, x, c): 

1981 return np.exp(-pow(x, c)) 

1982 

1983 def _logsf(self, x, c): 

1984 return -pow(x, c) 

1985 

1986 def _ppf(self, q, c): 

1987 return pow(-sc.log1p(-q), 1.0/c) 

1988 

1989 def _munp(self, n, c): 

1990 return sc.gamma(1.0+n*1.0/c) 

1991 

1992 def _entropy(self, c): 

1993 return -_EULER / c - np.log(c) + _EULER + 1 

1994 

1995 

1996weibull_min = weibull_min_gen(a=0.0, name='weibull_min') 

1997 

1998 

1999class weibull_max_gen(rv_continuous): 

2000 r"""Weibull maximum continuous random variable. 

2001 

2002 %(before_notes)s 

2003 

2004 See Also 

2005 -------- 

2006 weibull_min 

2007 

2008 Notes 

2009 ----- 

2010 The probability density function for `weibull_max` is: 

2011 

2012 .. math:: 

2013 

2014 f(x, c) = c (-x)^{c-1} \exp(-(-x)^c) 

2015 

2016 for :math:`x < 0`, :math:`c > 0`. 

2017 

2018 `weibull_max` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 

2019 

2020 %(after_notes)s 

2021 

2022 %(example)s 

2023 

2024 """ 

2025 def _pdf(self, x, c): 

2026 # frechet_l.pdf(x, c) = c * (-x)**(c-1) * exp(-(-x)**c) 

2027 return c*pow(-x, c-1)*np.exp(-pow(-x, c)) 

2028 

2029 def _logpdf(self, x, c): 

2030 return np.log(c) + sc.xlogy(c-1, -x) - pow(-x, c) 

2031 

2032 def _cdf(self, x, c): 

2033 return np.exp(-pow(-x, c)) 

2034 

2035 def _logcdf(self, x, c): 

2036 return -pow(-x, c) 

2037 

2038 def _sf(self, x, c): 

2039 return -sc.expm1(-pow(-x, c)) 

2040 

2041 def _ppf(self, q, c): 

2042 return -pow(-np.log(q), 1.0/c) 

2043 

2044 def _munp(self, n, c): 

2045 val = sc.gamma(1.0+n*1.0/c) 

2046 if int(n) % 2: 

2047 sgn = -1 

2048 else: 

2049 sgn = 1 

2050 return sgn * val 

2051 

2052 def _entropy(self, c): 

2053 return -_EULER / c - np.log(c) + _EULER + 1 

2054 

2055 

2056weibull_max = weibull_max_gen(b=0.0, name='weibull_max') 

2057 

2058# Public methods to be deprecated in frechet_r and frechet_l: 

2059# ['__call__', 'cdf', 'entropy', 'expect', 'fit', 'fit_loc_scale', 'freeze', 

2060# 'interval', 'isf', 'logcdf', 'logpdf', 'logsf', 'mean', 'median', 'moment', 

2061# 'nnlf', 'pdf', 'ppf', 'rvs', 'sf', 'stats', 'std', 'var'] 

2062 

2063_frechet_r_deprec_msg = """\ 

2064The distribution `frechet_r` is a synonym for `weibull_min`; this historical 

2065usage is deprecated because of possible confusion with the (quite different) 

2066Frechet distribution. To preserve the existing behavior of the program, use 

2067`scipy.stats.weibull_min`. For the Frechet distribution (i.e. the Type II 

2068extreme value distribution), use `scipy.stats.invweibull`.""" 

2069 

2070 

2071class frechet_r_gen(weibull_min_gen): 

2072 """A Frechet right (or Weibull minimum) continuous random variable. 

2073 

2074 %(before_notes)s 

2075 

2076 See Also 

2077 -------- 

2078 weibull_min : The same distribution as `frechet_r`. 

2079 

2080 Notes 

2081 ----- 

2082 %(after_notes)s 

2083 

2084 %(example)s 

2085 """ 

2086 

2087 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_r', message=_frechet_r_deprec_msg) 

2088 def __call__(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2089 return weibull_min_gen.__call__(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2090 

2091 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_r', message=_frechet_r_deprec_msg) 

2092 def cdf(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2093 return weibull_min_gen.cdf(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2094 

2095 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_r', message=_frechet_r_deprec_msg) 

2096 def entropy(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2097 return weibull_min_gen.entropy(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2098 

2099 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_r', message=_frechet_r_deprec_msg) 

2100 def expect(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2101 return weibull_min_gen.expect(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2102 

2103 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_r', message=_frechet_r_deprec_msg) 

2104 def fit(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2105 return weibull_min_gen.fit(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2106 

2107 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_r', message=_frechet_r_deprec_msg) 

2108 def fit_loc_scale(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2109 return weibull_min_gen.fit_loc_scale(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2110 

2111 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_r', message=_frechet_r_deprec_msg) 

2112 def freeze(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2113 return weibull_min_gen.freeze(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2114 

2115 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_r', message=_frechet_r_deprec_msg) 

2116 def interval(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2117 return weibull_min_gen.interval(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2118 

2119 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_r', message=_frechet_r_deprec_msg) 

2120 def isf(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2121 return weibull_min_gen.isf(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2122 

2123 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_r', message=_frechet_r_deprec_msg) 

2124 def logcdf(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2125 return weibull_min_gen.logcdf(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2126 

2127 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_r', message=_frechet_r_deprec_msg) 

2128 def logpdf(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2129 return weibull_min_gen.logpdf(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2130 

2131 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_r', message=_frechet_r_deprec_msg) 

2132 def logsf(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2133 return weibull_min_gen.logsf(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2134 

2135 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_r', message=_frechet_r_deprec_msg) 

2136 def mean(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2137 return weibull_min_gen.mean(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2138 

2139 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_r', message=_frechet_r_deprec_msg) 

2140 def median(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2141 return weibull_min_gen.median(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2142 

2143 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_r', message=_frechet_r_deprec_msg) 

2144 def moment(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2145 return weibull_min_gen.moment(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2146 

2147 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_r', message=_frechet_r_deprec_msg) 

2148 def nnlf(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2149 return weibull_min_gen.nnlf(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2150 

2151 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_r', message=_frechet_r_deprec_msg) 

2152 def pdf(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2153 return weibull_min_gen.pdf(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2154 

2155 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_r', message=_frechet_r_deprec_msg) 

2156 def ppf(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2157 return weibull_min_gen.ppf(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2158 

2159 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_r', message=_frechet_r_deprec_msg) 

2160 def rvs(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2161 return weibull_min_gen.rvs(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2162 

2163 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_r', message=_frechet_r_deprec_msg) 

2164 def sf(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2165 return weibull_min_gen.sf(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2166 

2167 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_r', message=_frechet_r_deprec_msg) 

2168 def stats(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2169 return weibull_min_gen.stats(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2170 

2171 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_r', message=_frechet_r_deprec_msg) 

2172 def std(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2173 return weibull_min_gen.std(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2174 

2175 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_r', message=_frechet_r_deprec_msg) 

2176 def var(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2177 return weibull_min_gen.var(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2178

2183_frechet_l_deprec_msg = """\ 

2184The distribution `frechet_l` is a synonym for `weibull_max`; this historical 

2185usage is deprecated because of possible confusion with the (quite different) 

2186Frechet distribution. To preserve the existing behavior of the program, use 

2187`scipy.stats.weibull_max`. For the Frechet distribution (i.e. the Type II 

2188extreme value distribution), use `scipy.stats.invweibull`.""" 

2189 

2190 

2191class frechet_l_gen(weibull_max_gen): 

2192 """A Frechet left (or Weibull maximum) continuous random variable. 

2193 

2194 %(before_notes)s 

2195 

2196 See Also 

2197 -------- 

2198 weibull_max : The same distribution as `frechet_l`. 

2199 

2200 Notes 

2201 ----- 

2202 %(after_notes)s 

2203 

2204 %(example)s 

2205 """ 

2206 

2207 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_l', message=_frechet_l_deprec_msg) 

2208 def __call__(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2209 return weibull_max_gen.__call__(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2210 

2211 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_l', message=_frechet_l_deprec_msg) 

2212 def cdf(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2213 return weibull_max_gen.cdf(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2214

2217 return weibull_max_gen.entropy(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2218 

2219 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_l', message=_frechet_l_deprec_msg) 

2220 def expect(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2221 return weibull_max_gen.expect(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2222 

2223 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_l', message=_frechet_l_deprec_msg) 

2224 def fit(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2225 return weibull_max_gen.fit(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2226 

2227 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_l', message=_frechet_l_deprec_msg) 

2228 def fit_loc_scale(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2229 return weibull_max_gen.fit_loc_scale(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2230 

2231 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_l', message=_frechet_l_deprec_msg) 

2232 def freeze(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2233 return weibull_max_gen.freeze(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2234 

2235 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_l', message=_frechet_l_deprec_msg) 

2236 def interval(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2237 return weibull_max_gen.interval(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2238 

2239 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_l', message=_frechet_l_deprec_msg) 

2240 def isf(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2241 return weibull_max_gen.isf(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2242 

2243 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_l', message=_frechet_l_deprec_msg) 

2244 def logcdf(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2245 return weibull_max_gen.logcdf(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2246

2248 def logpdf(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2249 return weibull_max_gen.logpdf(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2250 

2251 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_l', message=_frechet_l_deprec_msg) 

2252 def logsf(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2253 return weibull_max_gen.logsf(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2254 

2255 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_l', message=_frechet_l_deprec_msg) 

2256 def mean(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2257 return weibull_max_gen.mean(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2258

2260 def median(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2261 return weibull_max_gen.median(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2262 

2263 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_l', message=_frechet_l_deprec_msg) 

2264 def moment(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2265 return weibull_max_gen.moment(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2266 

2267 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_l', message=_frechet_l_deprec_msg) 

2268 def nnlf(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2269 return weibull_max_gen.nnlf(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2270 

2271 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_l', message=_frechet_l_deprec_msg) 

2272 def pdf(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2273 return weibull_max_gen.pdf(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2274 

2275 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_l', message=_frechet_l_deprec_msg) 

2276 def ppf(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2277 return weibull_max_gen.ppf(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2278 

2279 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_l', message=_frechet_l_deprec_msg) 

2280 def rvs(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2281 return weibull_max_gen.rvs(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2282 

2283 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_l', message=_frechet_l_deprec_msg) 

2284 def sf(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2285 return weibull_max_gen.sf(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2286 

2287 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_l', message=_frechet_l_deprec_msg) 

2288 def stats(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2289 return weibull_max_gen.stats(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2290 

2291 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_l', message=_frechet_l_deprec_msg) 

2292 def std(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2293 return weibull_max_gen.std(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2294 

2295 @np.deprecate(old_name='frechet_l', message=_frechet_l_deprec_msg) 

2296 def var(self, *args, **kwargs): 

2297 return weibull_max_gen.var(self, *args, **kwargs) 

2298 

2299 

2300frechet_l = frechet_l_gen(b=0.0, name='frechet_l') 

2301 

2302 

2303class genlogistic_gen(rv_continuous): 

2304 r"""A generalized logistic continuous random variable. 

2305 

2306 %(before_notes)s 

2307 

2308 Notes 

2309 ----- 

2310 The probability density function for `genlogistic` is: 

2311 

2312 .. math:: 

2313 

2314 f(x, c) = c \frac{\exp(-x)} 

2315 {(1 + \exp(-x))^{c+1}} 

2316 

2317 for :math:`x >= 0`, :math:`c > 0`. 

2318 

2319 `genlogistic` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 

2320 

2321 %(after_notes)s 

2322 

2323 %(example)s 

2324 

2325 """ 

2326 def _pdf(self, x, c): 

2327 # genlogistic.pdf(x, c) = c * exp(-x) / (1 + exp(-x))**(c+1) 

2328 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, c)) 

2329 

2330 def _logpdf(self, x, c): 

2331 return np.log(c) - x - (c+1.0)*sc.log1p(np.exp(-x)) 

2332 

2333 def _cdf(self, x, c): 

2334 Cx = (1+np.exp(-x))**(-c) 

2335 return Cx 

2336 

2337 def _ppf(self, q, c): 

2338 vals = -np.log(pow(q, -1.0/c)-1) 

2339 return vals 

2340 

2341 def _stats(self, c): 

2342 mu = _EULER + sc.psi(c) 

2343 mu2 = np.pi*np.pi/6.0 + sc.zeta(2, c) 

2344 g1 = -2*sc.zeta(3, c) + 2*_ZETA3 

2345 g1 /= np.power(mu2, 1.5) 

2346 g2 = np.pi**4/15.0 + 6*sc.zeta(4, c) 

2347 g2 /= mu2**2.0 

2348 return mu, mu2, g1, g2 

2349 

2350 

2351genlogistic = genlogistic_gen(name='genlogistic') 

2352 

2353 

2354class genpareto_gen(rv_continuous): 

2355 r"""A generalized Pareto continuous random variable. 

2356 

2357 %(before_notes)s 

2358 

2359 Notes 

2360 ----- 

2361 The probability density function for `genpareto` is: 

2362 

2363 .. math:: 

2364 

2365 f(x, c) = (1 + c x)^{-1 - 1/c} 

2366 

2367 defined for :math:`x \ge 0` if :math:`c \ge 0`, and for 

2368 :math:`0 \le x \le -1/c` if :math:`c < 0`. 

2369 

2370 `genpareto` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 

2371 

2372 For :math:`c=0`, `genpareto` reduces to the exponential 

2373 distribution, `expon`: 

2374 

2375 .. math:: 

2376 

2377 f(x, 0) = \exp(-x) 

2378 

2379 For :math:`c=-1`, `genpareto` is uniform on ``[0, 1]``: 

2380 

2381 .. math:: 

2382 

2383 f(x, -1) = 1 

2384 

2385 %(after_notes)s 

2386 

2387 %(example)s 

2388 

2389 """ 

2390 def _argcheck(self, c): 

2391 return np.isfinite(c) 

2392 

2393 def _get_support(self, c): 

2394 c = np.asarray(c) 

2395 b = _lazywhere(c < 0, (c,), 

2396 lambda c: -1. / c, 

2397 np.inf) 

2398 a = np.where(c >= 0, self.a, self.a) 

2399 return a, b 

2400 

2401 def _pdf(self, x, c): 

2402 # genpareto.pdf(x, c) = (1 + c * x)**(-1 - 1/c) 

2403 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, c)) 

2404 

2405 def _logpdf(self, x, c): 

2406 return _lazywhere((x == x) & (c != 0), (x, c), 

2407 lambda x, c: -sc.xlog1py(c + 1., c*x) / c, 

2408 -x) 

2409 

2410 def _cdf(self, x, c): 

2411 return -sc.inv_boxcox1p(-x, -c) 

2412 

2413 def _sf(self, x, c): 

2414 return sc.inv_boxcox(-x, -c) 

2415 

2416 def _logsf(self, x, c): 

2417 return _lazywhere((x == x) & (c != 0), (x, c), 

2418 lambda x, c: -sc.log1p(c*x) / c, 

2419 -x) 

2420 

2421 def _ppf(self, q, c): 

2422 return -sc.boxcox1p(-q, -c) 

2423 

2424 def _isf(self, q, c): 

2425 return -sc.boxcox(q, -c) 

2426 

2427 def _munp(self, n, c): 

2428 def __munp(n, c): 

2429 val = 0.0 

2430 k = np.arange(0, n + 1) 

2431 for ki, cnk in zip(k, sc.comb(n, k)): 

2432 val = val + cnk * (-1) ** ki / (1.0 - c * ki) 

2433 return np.where(c * n < 1, val * (-1.0 / c) ** n, np.inf) 

2434 return _lazywhere(c != 0, (c,), 

2435 lambda c: __munp(n, c), 

2436 sc.gamma(n + 1)) 

2437 

2438 def _entropy(self, c): 

2439 return 1. + c 

2440 

2441 

2442genpareto = genpareto_gen(a=0.0, name='genpareto') 

2443 

2444 

2445class genexpon_gen(rv_continuous): 

2446 r"""A generalized exponential continuous random variable. 

2447 

2448 %(before_notes)s 

2449 

2450 Notes 

2451 ----- 

2452 The probability density function for `genexpon` is: 

2453 

2454 .. math:: 

2455 

2456 f(x, a, b, c) = (a + b (1 - \exp(-c x))) 

2457 \exp(-a x - b x + \frac{b}{c} (1-\exp(-c x))) 

2458 

2459 for :math:`x \ge 0`, :math:`a, b, c > 0`. 

2460 

2461 `genexpon` takes :math:`a`, :math:`b` and :math:`c` as shape parameters. 

2462 

2463 %(after_notes)s 

2464 

2465 References 

2466 ---------- 

2467 H.K. Ryu, "An Extension of Marshall and Olkin's Bivariate Exponential 

2468 Distribution", Journal of the American Statistical Association, 1993. 

2469 

2470 N. Balakrishnan, "The Exponential Distribution: Theory, Methods and 

2471 Applications", Asit P. Basu. 

2472 

2473 %(example)s 

2474 

2475 """ 

2476 def _pdf(self, x, a, b, c): 

2477 # genexpon.pdf(x, a, b, c) = (a + b * (1 - exp(-c*x))) * \ 

2478 # exp(-a*x - b*x + b/c * (1-exp(-c*x))) 

2479 return (a + b*(-sc.expm1(-c*x)))*np.exp((-a-b)*x + 

2480 b*(-sc.expm1(-c*x))/c) 

2481 

2482 def _cdf(self, x, a, b, c): 

2483 return -sc.expm1((-a-b)*x + b*(-sc.expm1(-c*x))/c) 

2484 

2485 def _logpdf(self, x, a, b, c): 

2486 return np.log(a+b*(-sc.expm1(-c*x))) + (-a-b)*x+b*(-sc.expm1(-c*x))/c 

2487 

2488 

2489genexpon = genexpon_gen(a=0.0, name='genexpon') 

2490 

2491 

2492class genextreme_gen(rv_continuous): 

2493 r"""A generalized extreme value continuous random variable. 

2494 

2495 %(before_notes)s 

2496 

2497 See Also 

2498 -------- 

2499 gumbel_r 

2500 

2501 Notes 

2502 ----- 

2503 For :math:`c=0`, `genextreme` is equal to `gumbel_r`. 

2504 The probability density function for `genextreme` is: 

2505 

2506 .. math:: 

2507 

2508 f(x, c) = \begin{cases} 

2509 \exp(-\exp(-x)) \exp(-x) &\text{for } c = 0\\ 

2510 \exp(-(1-c x)^{1/c}) (1-c x)^{1/c-1} &\text{for } 

2511 x \le 1/c, c > 0 

2512 \end{cases} 

2513 

2514 

2515 Note that several sources and software packages use the opposite 

2516 convention for the sign of the shape parameter :math:`c`. 

2517 

2518 `genextreme` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 

2519 

2520 %(after_notes)s 

2521 

2522 %(example)s 

2523 

2524 """ 

2525 def _argcheck(self, c): 

2526 return np.where(abs(c) == np.inf, 0, 1) 

2527 

2528 def _get_support(self, c): 

2529 _b = np.where(c > 0, 1.0 / np.maximum(c, _XMIN), np.inf) 

2530 _a = np.where(c < 0, 1.0 / np.minimum(c, -_XMIN), -np.inf) 

2531 return _a, _b 

2532 

2533 def _loglogcdf(self, x, c): 

2534 return _lazywhere((x == x) & (c != 0), (x, c), 

2535 lambda x, c: sc.log1p(-c*x)/c, -x) 

2536 

2537 def _pdf(self, x, c): 

2538 # genextreme.pdf(x, c) = 

2539 # exp(-exp(-x))*exp(-x), for c==0 

2540 # exp(-(1-c*x)**(1/c))*(1-c*x)**(1/c-1), for x \le 1/c, c > 0 

2541 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, c)) 

2542 

2543 def _logpdf(self, x, c): 

2544 cx = _lazywhere((x == x) & (c != 0), (x, c), lambda x, c: c*x, 0.0) 

2545 logex2 = sc.log1p(-cx) 

2546 logpex2 = self._loglogcdf(x, c) 

2547 pex2 = np.exp(logpex2) 

2548 # Handle special cases 

2549 np.putmask(logpex2, (c == 0) & (x == -np.inf), 0.0) 

2550 logpdf = np.where((cx == 1) | (cx == -np.inf), 

2551 -np.inf, 

2552 -pex2+logpex2-logex2) 

2553 np.putmask(logpdf, (c == 1) & (x == 1), 0.0) 

2554 return logpdf 

2555 

2556 def _logcdf(self, x, c): 

2557 return -np.exp(self._loglogcdf(x, c)) 

2558 

2559 def _cdf(self, x, c): 

2560 return np.exp(self._logcdf(x, c)) 

2561 

2562 def _sf(self, x, c): 

2563 return -sc.expm1(self._logcdf(x, c)) 

2564 

2565 def _ppf(self, q, c): 

2566 x = -np.log(-np.log(q)) 

2567 return _lazywhere((x == x) & (c != 0), (x, c), 

2568 lambda x, c: -sc.expm1(-c * x) / c, x) 

2569 

2570 def _isf(self, q, c): 

2571 x = -np.log(-sc.log1p(-q)) 

2572 return _lazywhere((x == x) & (c != 0), (x, c), 

2573 lambda x, c: -sc.expm1(-c * x) / c, x) 

2574 

2575 def _stats(self, c): 

2576 g = lambda n: sc.gamma(n*c + 1) 

2577 g1 = g(1) 

2578 g2 = g(2) 

2579 g3 = g(3) 

2580 g4 = g(4) 

2581 g2mg12 = np.where(abs(c) < 1e-7, (c*np.pi)**2.0/6.0, g2-g1**2.0) 

2582 gam2k = np.where(abs(c) < 1e-7, np.pi**2.0/6.0, 

2583 sc.expm1(sc.gammaln(2.0*c+1.0)-2*sc.gammaln(c + 1.0))/c**2.0) 

2584 eps = 1e-14 

2585 gamk = np.where(abs(c) < eps, -_EULER, sc.expm1(sc.gammaln(c + 1))/c) 

2586 

2587 m = np.where(c < -1.0, np.nan, -gamk) 

2588 v = np.where(c < -0.5, np.nan, g1**2.0*gam2k) 

2589 

2590 # skewness 

2591 sk1 = _lazywhere(c >= -1./3, 

2592 (c, g1, g2, g3, g2mg12), 

2593 lambda c, g1, g2, g3, g2gm12: 

2594 np.sign(c)*(-g3 + (g2 + 2*g2mg12)*g1)/g2mg12**1.5, 

2595 fillvalue=np.nan) 

2596 sk = np.where(abs(c) <= eps**0.29, 12*np.sqrt(6)*_ZETA3/np.pi**3, sk1) 

2597 

2598 # kurtosis 

2599 ku1 = _lazywhere(c >= -1./4, 

2600 (g1, g2, g3, g4, g2mg12), 

2601 lambda g1, g2, g3, g4, g2mg12: 

2602 (g4 + (-4*g3 + 3*(g2 + g2mg12)*g1)*g1)/g2mg12**2, 

2603 fillvalue=np.nan) 

2604 ku = np.where(abs(c) <= (eps)**0.23, 12.0/5.0, ku1-3.0) 

2605 return m, v, sk, ku 

2606 

2607 def _fitstart(self, data): 

2608 # This is better than the default shape of (1,). 

2609 g = _skew(data) 

2610 if g < 0: 

2611 a = 0.5 

2612 else: 

2613 a = -0.5 

2614 return super(genextreme_gen, self)._fitstart(data, args=(a,)) 

2615 

2616 def _munp(self, n, c): 

2617 k = np.arange(0, n+1) 

2618 vals = 1.0/c**n * np.sum( 

2619 sc.comb(n, k) * (-1)**k * sc.gamma(c*k + 1), 

2620 axis=0) 

2621 return np.where(c*n > -1, vals, np.inf) 

2622 

2623 def _entropy(self, c): 

2624 return _EULER*(1 - c) + 1 

2625 

2626 

2627genextreme = genextreme_gen(name='genextreme') 

2628 

2629 

2630def _digammainv(y): 

2631 # Inverse of the digamma function (real positive arguments only). 

2632 # This function is used in the `fit` method of `gamma_gen`. 

2633 # The function uses either optimize.fsolve or optimize.newton 

2634 # to solve `sc.digamma(x) - y = 0`. There is probably room for 

2635 # improvement, but currently it works over a wide range of y: 

2636 # >>> y = 64*np.random.randn(1000000) 

2637 # >>> y.min(), y.max() 

2638 # (-311.43592651416662, 351.77388222276869) 

2639 # x = [_digammainv(t) for t in y] 

2640 # np.abs(sc.digamma(x) - y).max() 

2641 # 1.1368683772161603e-13 

2642 # 

2643 _em = 0.5772156649015328606065120 

2644 func = lambda x: sc.digamma(x) - y 

2645 if y > -0.125: 

2646 x0 = np.exp(y) + 0.5 

2647 if y < 10: 

2648 # Some experimentation shows that newton reliably converges 

2649 # must faster than fsolve in this y range. For larger y, 

2650 # newton sometimes fails to converge. 

2651 value = optimize.newton(func, x0, tol=1e-10) 

2652 return value 

2653 elif y > -3: 

2654 x0 = np.exp(y/2.332) + 0.08661 

2655 else: 

2656 x0 = 1.0 / (-y - _em) 

2657 

2658 value, info, ier, mesg = optimize.fsolve(func, x0, xtol=1e-11, 

2659 full_output=True) 

2660 if ier != 1: 

2661 raise RuntimeError("_digammainv: fsolve failed, y = %r" % y) 

2662 

2663 return value[0] 

2664 

2665 

2666## Gamma (Use MATLAB and MATHEMATICA (b=theta=scale, a=alpha=shape) definition) 

2667 

2668## gamma(a, loc, scale) with a an integer is the Erlang distribution 

2669## gamma(1, loc, scale) is the Exponential distribution 

2670## gamma(df/2, 0, 2) is the chi2 distribution with df degrees of freedom. 

2671 

2672class gamma_gen(rv_continuous): 

2673 r"""A gamma continuous random variable. 

2674 

2675 %(before_notes)s 

2676 

2677 See Also 

2678 -------- 

2679 erlang, expon 

2680 

2681 Notes 

2682 ----- 

2683 The probability density function for `gamma` is: 

2684 

2685 .. math:: 

2686 

2687 f(x, a) = \frac{x^{a-1} \exp(-x)}{\Gamma(a)} 

2688 

2689 for :math:`x \ge 0`, :math:`a > 0`. Here :math:`\Gamma(a)` refers to the 

2690 gamma function. 

2691 

2692 `gamma` takes ``a`` as a shape parameter for :math:`a`. 

2693 

2694 When :math:`a` is an integer, `gamma` reduces to the Erlang 

2695 distribution, and when :math:`a=1` to the exponential distribution. 

2696 

2697 %(after_notes)s 

2698 

2699 %(example)s 

2700 

2701 """ 

2702 def _rvs(self, a): 

2703 return self._random_state.standard_gamma(a, self._size) 

2704 

2705 def _pdf(self, x, a): 

2706 # gamma.pdf(x, a) = x**(a-1) * exp(-x) / gamma(a) 

2707 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, a)) 

2708 

2709 def _logpdf(self, x, a): 

2710 return sc.xlogy(a-1.0, x) - x - sc.gammaln(a) 

2711 

2712 def _cdf(self, x, a):
