2713 return sc.gammainc(a, x) 

2714 

2715 def _sf(self, x, a): 

2716 return sc.gammaincc(a, x) 

2717 

2718 def _ppf(self, q, a): 

2719 return sc.gammaincinv(a, q) 

2720 

2721 def _stats(self, a): 

2722 return a, a, 2.0/np.sqrt(a), 6.0/a 

2723 

2724 def _entropy(self, a): 

2725 return sc.psi(a)*(1-a) + a + sc.gammaln(a) 

2726 

2727 def _fitstart(self, data): 

2728 # The skewness of the gamma distribution is `4 / np.sqrt(a)`. 

2729 # We invert that to estimate the shape `a` using the skewness 

2730 # of the data. The formula is regularized with 1e-8 in the 

2731 # denominator to allow for degenerate data where the skewness 

2732 # is close to 0. 

2733 a = 4 / (1e-8 + _skew(data)**2) 

2734 return super(gamma_gen, self)._fitstart(data, args=(a,)) 

2735 

2736 @extend_notes_in_docstring(rv_continuous, notes="""\ 

2737 When the location is fixed by using the argument `floc`, this 

2738 function uses explicit formulas or solves a simpler numerical 

2739 problem than the full ML optimization problem. So in that case, 

2740 the `optimizer`, `loc` and `scale` arguments are ignored.\n\n""") 

2741 def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds): 

2742 floc = kwds.get('floc', None) 

2743 

2744 if floc is None: 

2745 # loc is not fixed. Use the default fit method. 

2746 return super(gamma_gen, self).fit(data, *args, **kwds) 

2747 

2748 # We already have this value, so just pop it from kwds. 

2749 kwds.pop('floc', None) 

2750 

2751 f0 = _get_fixed_fit_value(kwds, ['f0', 'fa', 'fix_a']) 

2752 fscale = kwds.pop('fscale', None) 

2753 

2754 _remove_optimizer_parameters(kwds) 

2755 

2756 # Special case: loc is fixed. 

2757 

2758 if f0 is not None and fscale is not None: 

2759 # This check is for consistency with `rv_continuous.fit`. 

2760 # Without this check, this function would just return the 

2761 # parameters that were given. 

2762 raise ValueError("All parameters fixed. There is nothing to " 

2763 "optimize.") 

2764 

2765 # Fixed location is handled by shifting the data. 

2766 data = np.asarray(data) 

2767 

2768 if not np.isfinite(data).all(): 

2769 raise RuntimeError("The data contains non-finite values.") 

2770 

2771 if np.any(data <= floc): 

2772 raise FitDataError("gamma", lower=floc, upper=np.inf) 

2773 

2774 if floc != 0: 

2775 # Don't do the subtraction in-place, because `data` might be a 

2776 # view of the input array. 

2777 data = data - floc 

2778 xbar = data.mean() 

2779 

2780 # Three cases to handle: 

2781 # * shape and scale both free 

2782 # * shape fixed, scale free 

2783 # * shape free, scale fixed 

2784 

2785 if fscale is None: 

2786 # scale is free 

2787 if f0 is not None: 

2788 # shape is fixed 

2789 a = f0 

2790 else: 

2791 # shape and scale are both free. 

2792 # The MLE for the shape parameter `a` is the solution to: 

2793 # np.log(a) - sc.digamma(a) - np.log(xbar) + 

2794 # np.log(data.mean) = 0 

2795 s = np.log(xbar) - np.log(data).mean() 

2796 func = lambda a: np.log(a) - sc.digamma(a) - s 

2797 aest = (3-s + np.sqrt((s-3)**2 + 24*s)) / (12*s) 

2798 xa = aest*(1-0.4) 

2799 xb = aest*(1+0.4) 

2800 a = optimize.brentq(func, xa, xb, disp=0) 

2801 

2802 # The MLE for the scale parameter is just the data mean 

2803 # divided by the shape parameter. 

2804 scale = xbar / a 

2805 else: 

2806 # scale is fixed, shape is free 

2807 # The MLE for the shape parameter `a` is the solution to: 

2808 # sc.digamma(a) - np.log(data).mean() + np.log(fscale) = 0 

2809 c = np.log(data).mean() - np.log(fscale) 

2810 a = _digammainv(c) 

2811 scale = fscale 

2812 

2813 return a, floc, scale 

2814 

2815 

2816gamma = gamma_gen(a=0.0, name='gamma') 

2817 

2818 

2819class erlang_gen(gamma_gen): 

2820 """An Erlang continuous random variable. 

2821 

2822 %(before_notes)s 

2823 

2824 See Also 

2825 -------- 

2826 gamma 

2827 

2828 Notes 

2829 ----- 

2830 The Erlang distribution is a special case of the Gamma distribution, with 

2831 the shape parameter `a` an integer. Note that this restriction is not 

2832 enforced by `erlang`. It will, however, generate a warning the first time 

2833 a non-integer value is used for the shape parameter. 

2834 

2835 Refer to `gamma` for examples. 

2836 

2837 """ 

2838 

2839 def _argcheck(self, a): 

2840 allint = np.all(np.floor(a) == a) 

2841 if not allint: 

2842 # An Erlang distribution shouldn't really have a non-integer 

2843 # shape parameter, so warn the user. 

2844 warnings.warn( 

2845 'The shape parameter of the erlang distribution ' 

2846 'has been given a non-integer value %r.' % (a,), 

2847 RuntimeWarning) 

2848 return a > 0 

2849 

2850 def _fitstart(self, data): 

2851 # Override gamma_gen_fitstart so that an integer initial value is 

2852 # used. (Also regularize the division, to avoid issues when 

2853 # _skew(data) is 0 or close to 0.) 

2854 a = int(4.0 / (1e-8 + _skew(data)**2)) 

2855 return super(gamma_gen, self)._fitstart(data, args=(a,)) 

2856 

2857 # Trivial override of the fit method, so we can monkey-patch its 

2858 # docstring. 

2859 def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds): 

2860 return super(erlang_gen, self).fit(data, *args, **kwds) 

2861 

2862 if fit.__doc__: 

2863 fit.__doc__ = (rv_continuous.fit.__doc__ + 

2864 """ 

2865 Notes 

2866 ----- 

2867 The Erlang distribution is generally defined to have integer values 

2868 for the shape parameter. This is not enforced by the `erlang` class. 

2869 When fitting the distribution, it will generally return a non-integer 

2870 value for the shape parameter. By using the keyword argument 

2871 `f0=<integer>`, the fit method can be constrained to fit the data to 

2872 a specific integer shape parameter. 

2873 """) 

2874 

2875 

2876erlang = erlang_gen(a=0.0, name='erlang') 

2877 

2878 

2879class gengamma_gen(rv_continuous): 

2880 r"""A generalized gamma continuous random variable. 

2881 

2882 %(before_notes)s 

2883 

2884 Notes 

2885 ----- 

2886 The probability density function for `gengamma` is: 

2887 

2888 .. math:: 

2889 

2890 f(x, a, c) = \frac{|c| x^{c a-1} \exp(-x^c)}{\Gamma(a)} 

2891 

2892 for :math:`x \ge 0`, :math:`a > 0`, and :math:`c \ne 0`. 

2893 :math:`\Gamma` is the gamma function (`scipy.special.gamma`). 

2894 

2895 `gengamma` takes :math:`a` and :math:`c` as shape parameters. 

2896 

2897 %(after_notes)s 

2898 

2899 %(example)s 

2900 

2901 """ 

2902 def _argcheck(self, a, c): 

2903 return (a > 0) & (c != 0) 

2904 

2905 def _pdf(self, x, a, c): 

2906 # gengamma.pdf(x, a, c) = abs(c) * x**(c*a-1) * exp(-x**c) / gamma(a) 

2907 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, a, c)) 

2908 

2909 def _logpdf(self, x, a, c): 

2910 return np.log(abs(c)) + sc.xlogy(c*a - 1, x) - x**c - sc.gammaln(a) 

2911 

2912 def _cdf(self, x, a, c): 

2913 xc = x**c 

2914 val1 = sc.gammainc(a, xc) 

2915 val2 = sc.gammaincc(a, xc) 

2916 return np.where(c > 0, val1, val2) 

2917 

2918 def _sf(self, x, a, c): 

2919 xc = x**c 

2920 val1 = sc.gammainc(a, xc) 

2921 val2 = sc.gammaincc(a, xc) 

2922 return np.where(c > 0, val2, val1) 

2923 

2924 def _ppf(self, q, a, c): 

2925 val1 = sc.gammaincinv(a, q) 

2926 val2 = sc.gammainccinv(a, q) 

2927 return np.where(c > 0, val1, val2)**(1.0/c) 

2928 

2929 def _isf(self, q, a, c): 

2930 val1 = sc.gammaincinv(a, q) 

2931 val2 = sc.gammainccinv(a, q) 

2932 return np.where(c > 0, val2, val1)**(1.0/c) 

2933 

2934 def _munp(self, n, a, c): 

2935 # Pochhammer symbol: sc.pocha,n) = gamma(a+n)/gamma(a) 

2936 return sc.poch(a, n*1.0/c) 

2937 

2938 def _entropy(self, a, c): 

2939 val = sc.psi(a) 

2940 return a*(1-val) + 1.0/c*val + sc.gammaln(a) - np.log(abs(c)) 

2941 

2942 

2943gengamma = gengamma_gen(a=0.0, name='gengamma') 

2944 

2945 

2946class genhalflogistic_gen(rv_continuous): 

2947 r"""A generalized half-logistic continuous random variable. 

2948 

2949 %(before_notes)s 

2950 

2951 Notes 

2952 ----- 

2953 The probability density function for `genhalflogistic` is: 

2954 

2955 .. math:: 

2956 

2957 f(x, c) = \frac{2 (1 - c x)^{1/(c-1)}}{[1 + (1 - c x)^{1/c}]^2} 

2958 

2959 for :math:`0 \le x \le 1/c`, and :math:`c > 0`. 

2960 

2961 `genhalflogistic` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 

2962 

2963 %(after_notes)s 

2964 

2965 %(example)s 

2966 

2967 """ 

2968 def _argcheck(self, c): 

2969 return c > 0 

2970 

2971 def _get_support(self, c): 

2972 return self.a, 1.0/c 

2973 

2974 def _pdf(self, x, c): 

2975 # genhalflogistic.pdf(x, c) = 

2976 # 2 * (1-c*x)**(1/c-1) / (1+(1-c*x)**(1/c))**2 

2977 limit = 1.0/c 

2978 tmp = np.asarray(1-c*x) 

2979 tmp0 = tmp**(limit-1) 

2980 tmp2 = tmp0*tmp 

2981 return 2*tmp0 / (1+tmp2)**2 

2982 

2983 def _cdf(self, x, c): 

2984 limit = 1.0/c 

2985 tmp = np.asarray(1-c*x) 

2986 tmp2 = tmp**(limit) 

2987 return (1.0-tmp2) / (1+tmp2) 

2988 

2989 def _ppf(self, q, c): 

2990 return 1.0/c*(1-((1.0-q)/(1.0+q))**c) 

2991 

2992 def _entropy(self, c): 

2993 return 2 - (2*c+1)*np.log(2) 

2994 

2995 

2996genhalflogistic = genhalflogistic_gen(a=0.0, name='genhalflogistic') 

2997 

2998 

2999class gompertz_gen(rv_continuous): 

3000 r"""A Gompertz (or truncated Gumbel) continuous random variable. 

3001 

3002 %(before_notes)s 

3003 

3004 Notes 

3005 ----- 

3006 The probability density function for `gompertz` is: 

3007 

3008 .. math:: 

3009 

3010 f(x, c) = c \exp(x) \exp(-c (e^x-1)) 

3011 

3012 for :math:`x \ge 0`, :math:`c > 0`. 

3013 

3014 `gompertz` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 

3015 

3016 %(after_notes)s 

3017 

3018 %(example)s 

3019 

3020 """ 

3021 def _pdf(self, x, c): 

3022 # gompertz.pdf(x, c) = c * exp(x) * exp(-c*(exp(x)-1)) 

3023 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, c)) 

3024 

3025 def _logpdf(self, x, c): 

3026 return np.log(c) + x - c * sc.expm1(x) 

3027 

3028 def _cdf(self, x, c): 

3029 return -sc.expm1(-c * sc.expm1(x)) 

3030 

3031 def _ppf(self, q, c): 

3032 return sc.log1p(-1.0 / c * sc.log1p(-q)) 

3033 

3034 def _entropy(self, c): 

3035 return 1.0 - np.log(c) - np.exp(c)*sc.expn(1, c) 

3036 

3037 

3038gompertz = gompertz_gen(a=0.0, name='gompertz') 

3039 

3040 

3041class gumbel_r_gen(rv_continuous): 

3042 r"""A right-skewed Gumbel continuous random variable. 

3043 

3044 %(before_notes)s 

3045 

3046 See Also 

3047 -------- 

3048 gumbel_l, gompertz, genextreme 

3049 

3050 Notes 

3051 ----- 

3052 The probability density function for `gumbel_r` is: 

3053 

3054 .. math:: 

3055 

3056 f(x) = \exp(-(x + e^{-x})) 

3057 

3058 The Gumbel distribution is sometimes referred to as a type I Fisher-Tippett 

3059 distribution. It is also related to the extreme value distribution, 

3060 log-Weibull and Gompertz distributions. 

3061 

3062 %(after_notes)s 

3063 

3064 %(example)s 

3065 

3066 """ 

3067 def _pdf(self, x): 

3068 # gumbel_r.pdf(x) = exp(-(x + exp(-x))) 

3069 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x)) 

3070 

3071 def _logpdf(self, x): 

3072 return -x - np.exp(-x) 

3073 

3074 def _cdf(self, x): 

3075 return np.exp(-np.exp(-x)) 

3076 

3077 def _logcdf(self, x): 

3078 return -np.exp(-x) 

3079 

3080 def _ppf(self, q): 

3081 return -np.log(-np.log(q)) 

3082 

3083 def _stats(self): 

3084 return _EULER, np.pi*np.pi/6.0, 12*np.sqrt(6)/np.pi**3 * _ZETA3, 12.0/5 

3085 

3086 def _entropy(self): 

3087 # https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gumbel_distribution 

3088 return _EULER + 1. 

3089 

3090 

3091gumbel_r = gumbel_r_gen(name='gumbel_r') 

3092 

3093 

3094class gumbel_l_gen(rv_continuous): 

3095 r"""A left-skewed Gumbel continuous random variable. 

3096 

3097 %(before_notes)s 

3098 

3099 See Also 

3100 -------- 

3101 gumbel_r, gompertz, genextreme 

3102 

3103 Notes 

3104 ----- 

3105 The probability density function for `gumbel_l` is: 

3106 

3107 .. math:: 

3108 

3109 f(x) = \exp(x - e^x) 

3110 

3111 The Gumbel distribution is sometimes referred to as a type I Fisher-Tippett 

3112 distribution. It is also related to the extreme value distribution, 

3113 log-Weibull and Gompertz distributions. 

3114 

3115 %(after_notes)s 

3116 

3117 %(example)s 

3118 

3119 """ 

3120 def _pdf(self, x): 

3121 # gumbel_l.pdf(x) = exp(x - exp(x)) 

3122 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x)) 

3123 

3124 def _logpdf(self, x): 

3125 return x - np.exp(x) 

3126 

3127 def _cdf(self, x): 

3128 return -sc.expm1(-np.exp(x)) 

3129 

3130 def _ppf(self, q): 

3131 return np.log(-sc.log1p(-q)) 

3132 

3133 def _logsf(self, x): 

3134 return -np.exp(x) 

3135 

3136 def _sf(self, x): 

3137 return np.exp(-np.exp(x)) 

3138 

3139 def _isf(self, x): 

3140 return np.log(-np.log(x)) 

3141 

3142 def _stats(self): 

3143 return -_EULER, np.pi*np.pi/6.0, \ 

3144 -12*np.sqrt(6)/np.pi**3 * _ZETA3, 12.0/5 

3145 

3146 def _entropy(self): 

3147 return _EULER + 1. 

3148 

3149 

3150gumbel_l = gumbel_l_gen(name='gumbel_l') 

3151 

3152 

3153class halfcauchy_gen(rv_continuous): 

3154 r"""A Half-Cauchy continuous random variable. 

3155 

3156 %(before_notes)s 

3157 

3158 Notes 

3159 ----- 

3160 The probability density function for `halfcauchy` is: 

3161 

3162 .. math:: 

3163 

3164 f(x) = \frac{2}{\pi (1 + x^2)} 

3165 

3166 for :math:`x \ge 0`. 

3167 

3168 %(after_notes)s 

3169 

3170 %(example)s 

3171 

3172 """ 

3173 def _pdf(self, x): 

3174 # halfcauchy.pdf(x) = 2 / (pi * (1 + x**2)) 

3175 return 2.0/np.pi/(1.0+x*x) 

3176 

3177 def _logpdf(self, x): 

3178 return np.log(2.0/np.pi) - sc.log1p(x*x) 

3179 

3180 def _cdf(self, x): 

3181 return 2.0/np.pi*np.arctan(x) 

3182 

3183 def _ppf(self, q): 

3184 return np.tan(np.pi/2*q) 

3185 

3186 def _stats(self): 

3187 return np.inf, np.inf, np.nan, np.nan 

3188 

3189 def _entropy(self): 

3190 return np.log(2*np.pi) 

3191 

3192 

3193halfcauchy = halfcauchy_gen(a=0.0, name='halfcauchy') 

3194 

3195 

3196class halflogistic_gen(rv_continuous): 

3197 r"""A half-logistic continuous random variable. 

3198 

3199 %(before_notes)s 

3200 

3201 Notes 

3202 ----- 

3203 The probability density function for `halflogistic` is: 

3204 

3205 .. math:: 

3206 

3207 f(x) = \frac{ 2 e^{-x} }{ (1+e^{-x})^2 } 

3208 = \frac{1}{2} \text{sech}(x/2)^2 

3209 

3210 for :math:`x \ge 0`. 

3211 

3212 %(after_notes)s 

3213 

3214 %(example)s 

3215 

3216 """ 

3217 def _pdf(self, x): 

3218 # halflogistic.pdf(x) = 2 * exp(-x) / (1+exp(-x))**2 

3219 # = 1/2 * sech(x/2)**2 

3220 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x)) 

3221 

3222 def _logpdf(self, x): 

3223 return np.log(2) - x - 2. * sc.log1p(np.exp(-x)) 

3224 

3225 def _cdf(self, x): 

3226 return np.tanh(x/2.0) 

3227 

3228 def _ppf(self, q): 

3229 return 2*np.arctanh(q) 

3230 

3231 def _munp(self, n): 

3232 if n == 1: 

3233 return 2*np.log(2) 

3234 if n == 2: 

3235 return np.pi*np.pi/3.0 

3236 if n == 3: 

3237 return 9*_ZETA3 

3238 if n == 4: 

3239 return 7*np.pi**4 / 15.0 

3240 return 2*(1-pow(2.0, 1-n))*sc.gamma(n+1)*sc.zeta(n, 1) 

3241 

3242 def _entropy(self): 

3243 return 2-np.log(2) 

3244 

3245 

3246halflogistic = halflogistic_gen(a=0.0, name='halflogistic') 

3247 

3248 

3249class halfnorm_gen(rv_continuous): 

3250 r"""A half-normal continuous random variable. 

3251 

3252 %(before_notes)s 

3253 

3254 Notes 

3255 ----- 

3256 The probability density function for `halfnorm` is: 

3257 

3258 .. math:: 

3259 

3260 f(x) = \sqrt{2/\pi} \exp(-x^2 / 2) 

3261 

3262 for :math:`x >= 0`. 

3263 

3264 `halfnorm` is a special case of `chi` with ``df=1``. 

3265 

3266 %(after_notes)s 

3267 

3268 %(example)s 

3269 

3270 """ 

3271 def _rvs(self): 

3272 return abs(self._random_state.standard_normal(size=self._size)) 

3273 

3274 def _pdf(self, x): 

3275 # halfnorm.pdf(x) = sqrt(2/pi) * exp(-x**2/2) 

3276 return np.sqrt(2.0/np.pi)*np.exp(-x*x/2.0) 

3277 

3278 def _logpdf(self, x): 

3279 return 0.5 * np.log(2.0/np.pi) - x*x/2.0 

3280 

3281 def _cdf(self, x): 

3282 return _norm_cdf(x)*2-1.0 

3283 

3284 def _ppf(self, q): 

3285 return sc.ndtri((1+q)/2.0) 

3286 

3287 def _stats(self): 

3288 return (np.sqrt(2.0/np.pi), 

3289 1-2.0/np.pi, 

3290 np.sqrt(2)*(4-np.pi)/(np.pi-2)**1.5, 

3291 8*(np.pi-3)/(np.pi-2)**2) 

3292 

3293 def _entropy(self): 

3294 return 0.5*np.log(np.pi/2.0)+0.5 

3295 

3296 

3297halfnorm = halfnorm_gen(a=0.0, name='halfnorm') 

3298 

3299 

3300class hypsecant_gen(rv_continuous): 

3301 r"""A hyperbolic secant continuous random variable. 

3302 

3303 %(before_notes)s 

3304 

3305 Notes 

3306 ----- 

3307 The probability density function for `hypsecant` is: 

3308 

3309 .. math:: 

3310 

3311 f(x) = \frac{1}{\pi} \text{sech}(x) 

3312 

3313 for a real number :math:`x`. 

3314 

3315 %(after_notes)s 

3316 

3317 %(example)s 

3318 

3319 """ 

3320 def _pdf(self, x): 

3321 # hypsecant.pdf(x) = 1/pi * sech(x) 

3322 return 1.0/(np.pi*np.cosh(x)) 

3323 

3324 def _cdf(self, x): 

3325 return 2.0/np.pi*np.arctan(np.exp(x)) 

3326 

3327 def _ppf(self, q): 

3328 return np.log(np.tan(np.pi*q/2.0)) 

3329 

3330 def _stats(self): 

3331 return 0, np.pi*np.pi/4, 0, 2 

3332 

3333 def _entropy(self): 

3334 return np.log(2*np.pi) 

3335 

3336 

3337hypsecant = hypsecant_gen(name='hypsecant') 

3338 

3339 

3340class gausshyper_gen(rv_continuous): 

3341 r"""A Gauss hypergeometric continuous random variable. 

3342 

3343 %(before_notes)s 

3344 

3345 Notes 

3346 ----- 

3347 The probability density function for `gausshyper` is: 

3348 

3349 .. math:: 

3350 

3351 f(x, a, b, c, z) = C x^{a-1} (1-x)^{b-1} (1+zx)^{-c} 

3352 

3353 for :math:`0 \le x \le 1`, :math:`a > 0`, :math:`b > 0`, and 

3354 :math:`C = \frac{1}{B(a, b) F[2, 1](c, a; a+b; -z)}`. 

3355 :math:`F[2, 1]` is the Gauss hypergeometric function 

3356 `scipy.special.hyp2f1`. 

3357 

3358 `gausshyper` takes :math:`a`, :math:`b`, :math:`c` and :math:`z` as shape 

3359 parameters. 

3360 

3361 %(after_notes)s 

3362 

3363 %(example)s 

3364 

3365 """ 

3366 def _argcheck(self, a, b, c, z): 

3367 return (a > 0) & (b > 0) & (c == c) & (z == z) 

3368 

3369 def _pdf(self, x, a, b, c, z): 

3370 # gausshyper.pdf(x, a, b, c, z) = 

3371 # C * x**(a-1) * (1-x)**(b-1) * (1+z*x)**(-c) 

3372 Cinv = sc.gamma(a)*sc.gamma(b)/sc.gamma(a+b)*sc.hyp2f1(c, a, a+b, -z) 

3373 return 1.0/Cinv * x**(a-1.0) * (1.0-x)**(b-1.0) / (1.0+z*x)**c 

3374 

3375 def _munp(self, n, a, b, c, z): 

3376 fac = sc.beta(n+a, b) / sc.beta(a, b) 

3377 num = sc.hyp2f1(c, a+n, a+b+n, -z) 

3378 den = sc.hyp2f1(c, a, a+b, -z) 

3379 return fac*num / den 

3380 

3381 

3382gausshyper = gausshyper_gen(a=0.0, b=1.0, name='gausshyper') 

3383 

3384 

3385class invgamma_gen(rv_continuous): 

3386 r"""An inverted gamma continuous random variable. 

3387 

3388 %(before_notes)s 

3389 

3390 Notes 

3391 ----- 

3392 The probability density function for `invgamma` is: 

3393 

3394 .. math:: 

3395 

3396 f(x, a) = \frac{x^{-a-1}}{\Gamma(a)} \exp(-\frac{1}{x}) 

3397 

3398 for :math:`x >= 0`, :math:`a > 0`. :math:`\Gamma` is the gamma function 

3399 (`scipy.special.gamma`). 

3400 

3401 `invgamma` takes ``a`` as a shape parameter for :math:`a`. 

3402 

3403 `invgamma` is a special case of `gengamma` with ``c=-1``. 

3404 

3405 %(after_notes)s 

3406 

3407 %(example)s 

3408 

3409 """ 

3410 _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask 

3411 

3412 def _pdf(self, x, a): 

3413 # invgamma.pdf(x, a) = x**(-a-1) / gamma(a) * exp(-1/x) 

3414 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, a)) 

3415 

3416 def _logpdf(self, x, a): 

3417 return -(a+1) * np.log(x) - sc.gammaln(a) - 1.0/x 

3418 

3419 def _cdf(self, x, a): 

3420 return sc.gammaincc(a, 1.0 / x) 

3421 

3422 def _ppf(self, q, a): 

3423 return 1.0 / sc.gammainccinv(a, q) 

3424 

3425 def _sf(self, x, a): 

3426 return sc.gammainc(a, 1.0 / x) 

3427 

3428 def _isf(self, q, a): 

3429 return 1.0 / sc.gammaincinv(a, q) 

3430 

3431 def _stats(self, a, moments='mvsk'): 

3432 m1 = _lazywhere(a > 1, (a,), lambda x: 1. / (x - 1.), np.inf) 

3433 m2 = _lazywhere(a > 2, (a,), lambda x: 1. / (x - 1.)**2 / (x - 2.), 

3434 np.inf) 

3435 

3436 g1, g2 = None, None 

3437 if 's' in moments: 

3438 g1 = _lazywhere( 

3439 a > 3, (a,), 

3440 lambda x: 4. * np.sqrt(x - 2.) / (x - 3.), np.nan) 

3441 if 'k' in moments: 

3442 g2 = _lazywhere( 

3443 a > 4, (a,), 

3444 lambda x: 6. * (5. * x - 11.) / (x - 3.) / (x - 4.), np.nan) 

3445 return m1, m2, g1, g2 

3446 

3447 def _entropy(self, a): 

3448 return a - (a+1.0) * sc.psi(a) + sc.gammaln(a) 

3449 

3450 

3451invgamma = invgamma_gen(a=0.0, name='invgamma') 

3452 

3453 

3454# scale is gamma from DATAPLOT and B from Regress 

3455class invgauss_gen(rv_continuous): 

3456 r"""An inverse Gaussian continuous random variable. 

3457 

3458 %(before_notes)s 

3459 

3460 Notes 

3461 ----- 

3462 The probability density function for `invgauss` is: 

3463 

3464 .. math:: 

3465 

3466 f(x, \mu) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi x^3}} 

3467 \exp(-\frac{(x-\mu)^2}{2 x \mu^2}) 

3468 

3469 for :math:`x >= 0` and :math:`\mu > 0`. 

3470 

3471 `invgauss` takes ``mu`` as a shape parameter for :math:`\mu`. 

3472 

3473 %(after_notes)s 

3474 

3475 When :math:`\mu` is too small, evaluating the cumulative distribution 

3476 function will be inaccurate due to ``cdf(mu -> 0) = inf * 0``. 

3477 NaNs are returned for :math:`\mu \le 0.0028`. 

3478 

3479 %(example)s 

3480 

3481 """ 

3482 _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask 

3483 

3484 def _rvs(self, mu): 

3485 return self._random_state.wald(mu, 1.0, size=self._size) 

3486 

3487 def _pdf(self, x, mu): 

3488 # invgauss.pdf(x, mu) = 

3489 # 1 / sqrt(2*pi*x**3) * exp(-(x-mu)**2/(2*x*mu**2)) 

3490 return 1.0/np.sqrt(2*np.pi*x**3.0)*np.exp(-1.0/(2*x)*((x-mu)/mu)**2) 

3491 

3492 def _logpdf(self, x, mu): 

3493 return -0.5*np.log(2*np.pi) - 1.5*np.log(x) - ((x-mu)/mu)**2/(2*x) 

3494 

3495 def _cdf(self, x, mu): 

3496 fac = np.sqrt(1.0/x) 

3497 # Numerical accuracy for small `mu` is bad. See #869. 

3498 C1 = _norm_cdf(fac*(x-mu)/mu) 

3499 C1 += np.exp(1.0/mu) * _norm_cdf(-fac*(x+mu)/mu) * np.exp(1.0/mu) 

3500 return C1 

3501 

3502 def _stats(self, mu): 

3503 return mu, mu**3.0, 3*np.sqrt(mu), 15*mu 

3504 

3505 

3506invgauss = invgauss_gen(a=0.0, name='invgauss') 

3507 

3508 

3509class geninvgauss_gen(rv_continuous): 

3510 r"""A Generalized Inverse Gaussian continuous random variable. 

3511 

3512 %(before_notes)s 

3513 

3514 Notes 

3515 ----- 

3516 The probability density function for `geninvgauss` is: 

3517 

3518 .. math:: 

3519 

3520 f(x, p, b) = x^{p-1} \exp(-b (x + 1/x) / 2) / (2 K_p(b)) 

3521 

3522 where `x > 0`, and the parameters `p, b` satisfy `b > 0` ([1]_). 

3523 :math:`K_p` is the modified Bessel function of second kind of order `p` 

3524 (`scipy.special.kv`). 

3525 

3526 %(after_notes)s 

3527 

3528 The inverse Gaussian distribution `stats.invgauss(mu)` is a special case of 

3529 `geninvgauss` with `p = -1/2`, `b = 1 / mu` and `scale = mu`. 

3530 

3531 Generating random variates is challenging for this distribution. The 

3532 implementation is based on [2]_. 

3533 

3534 References 

3535 ---------- 

3536 .. [1] O. Barndorff-Nielsen, P. Blaesild, C. Halgreen, "First hitting time 

3537 models for the generalized inverse gaussian distribution", 

3538 Stochastic Processes and their Applications 7, pp. 49--54, 1978. 

3539 

3540 .. [2] W. Hoermann and J. Leydold, "Generating generalized inverse Gaussian 

3541 random variates", Statistics and Computing, 24(4), p. 547--557, 2014. 

3542 

3543 %(example)s 

3544 

3545 """ 

3546 def _argcheck(self, p, b): 

3547 return (p == p) & (b > 0) 

3548 

3549 def _logpdf(self, x, p, b): 

3550 # kve instead of kv works better for large values of b 

3551 # warn if kve produces infinite values and replace by nan 

3552 # otherwise c = -inf and the results are often incorrect 

3553 z = sc.kve(p, b) 

3554 z_inf = np.isinf(z) 

3555 if z_inf.any(): 

3556 msg = ("Infinite values encountered in scipy.special.kve(p, b). " 

3557 "Values replaced by NaN to avoid incorrect results.") 

3558 warnings.warn(msg, RuntimeWarning) 

3559 z[z_inf] = np.nan 

3560 c = -np.log(2) - np.log(z) + b 

3561 return _lazywhere(x > 0, (x, p, b, c), 

3562 lambda x, p, b, c: 

3563 c + (p - 1)*np.log(x) - b*(x + 1/x)/2, 

3564 -np.inf) 

3565 

3566 def _pdf(self, x, p, b): 

3567 # relying on logpdf avoids overflow of x**(p-1) for large x and p 

3568 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, p, b)) 

3569 

3570 def _logquasipdf(self, x, p, b): 

3571 # log of the quasi-density (w/o normalizing constant) used in _rvs 

3572 return _lazywhere(x > 0, (x, p, b), 

3573 lambda x, p, b: (p - 1)*np.log(x) - b*(x + 1/x)/2, 

3574 -np.inf) 

3575 

3576 def _rvs(self, p, b): 

3577 # if p and b are scalar, use _rvs_scalar, otherwise need to create 

3578 # output by iterating over parameters 

3579 if np.isscalar(p) and np.isscalar(b): 

3580 out = self._rvs_scalar(p, b, self._size) 

3581 elif p.size == 1 and b.size == 1: 

3582 out = self._rvs_scalar(p.item(), b.item(), self._size) 

3583 else: 

3584 # When this method is called, self._size will be a (possibly empty) 

3585 # tuple of integers. It will not be None; if `size=None` is passed 

3586 # to `rvs()`, self._size will be the empty tuple (). 

3587 

3588 p, b = np.broadcast_arrays(p, b) 

3589 # p and b now have the same shape. 

3590 

3591 # `shp` is the shape of the blocks of random variates that are 

3592 # generated for each combination of parameters associated with 

3593 # broadcasting p and b. 

3594 # bc is a tuple the same lenth as self._size. The values 

3595 # in bc are bools. If bc[j] is True, it means that 

3596 # entire axis is filled in for a given combination of the 

3597 # broadcast arguments. 

3598 shp, bc = _check_shape(p.shape, self._size) 

3599 

3600 # `numsamples` is the total number of variates to be generated 

3601 # for each combination of the input arguments. 

3602 numsamples = int(np.prod(shp)) 

3603 

3604 # `out` is the array to be returned. It is filled in in the 

3605 # loop below. 

3606 out = np.empty(self._size) 

3607 

3608 it = np.nditer([p, b], 

3609 flags=['multi_index'], 

3610 op_flags=[['readonly'], ['readonly']]) 

3611 while not it.finished: 

3612 # Convert the iterator's multi_index into an index into the 

3613 # `out` array where the call to _rvs_scalar() will be stored. 

3614 # Where bc is True, we use a full slice; otherwise we use the 

3615 # index value from it.multi_index. len(it.multi_index) might 

3616 # be less than len(bc), and in that case we want to align these 

3617 # two sequences to the right, so the loop variable j runs from 

3618 # -len(self._size) to 0. This doesn't cause an IndexError, as 

3619 # bc[j] will be True in those cases where it.multi_index[j] 

3620 # would cause an IndexError. 

3621 idx = tuple((it.multi_index[j] if not bc[j] else slice(None)) 

3622 for j in range(-len(self._size), 0)) 

3623 out[idx] = self._rvs_scalar(it[0], it[1], 

3624 numsamples).reshape(shp) 

3625 it.iternext() 

3626 

3627 if self._size == (): 

3628 out = out[()] 

3629 return out 

3630 

3631 def _rvs_scalar(self, p, b, numsamples=None): 

3632 # following [2], the quasi-pdf is used instead of the pdf for the 

3633 # generation of rvs 

3634 invert_res = False 

3635 if not(numsamples): 

3636 numsamples = 1 

3637 if p < 0: 

3638 # note: if X is geninvgauss(p, b), then 1/X is geninvgauss(-p, b) 

3639 p = -p 

3640 invert_res = True 

3641 m = self._mode(p, b) 

3642 

3643 # determine method to be used following [2] 

3644 ratio_unif = True 

3645 if p >= 1 or b > 1: 

3646 # ratio of uniforms with mode shift below 

3647 mode_shift = True 

3648 elif b >= min(0.5, 2 * np.sqrt(1 - p) / 3): 

3649 # ratio of uniforms without mode shift below 

3650 mode_shift = False 

3651 else: 

3652 # new algorithm in [2] 

3653 ratio_unif = False 

3654 

3655 # prepare sampling of rvs 

3656 size1d = tuple(np.atleast_1d(numsamples)) 

3657 N = np.prod(size1d) # number of rvs needed, reshape upon return 

3658 x = np.zeros(N) 

3659 simulated = 0 

3660 

3661 if ratio_unif: 

3662 # use ratio of uniforms method 

3663 if mode_shift: 

3664 a2 = -2 * (p + 1) / b - m 

3665 a1 = 2 * m * (p - 1) / b - 1 

3666 # find roots of x**3 + a2*x**2 + a1*x + m (Cardano's formula) 

3667 p1 = a1 - a2**2 / 3 

3668 q1 = 2 * a2**3 / 27 - a2 * a1 / 3 + m 

3669 phi = np.arccos(-q1 * np.sqrt(-27 / p1**3) / 2) 

3670 s1 = -np.sqrt(-4 * p1 / 3) 

3671 root1 = s1 * np.cos(phi / 3 + np.pi / 3) - a2 / 3 

3672 root2 = -s1 * np.cos(phi / 3) - a2 / 3 

3673 # root3 = s1 * np.cos(phi / 3 - np.pi / 3) - a2 / 3 

3674 

3675 # if g is the quasipdf, rescale: g(x) / g(m) which we can write 

3676 # as exp(log(g(x)) - log(g(m))). This is important 

3677 # since for large values of p and b, g cannot be evaluated. 

3678 # denote the rescaled quasipdf by h 

3679 lm = self._logquasipdf(m, p, b) 

3680 d1 = self._logquasipdf(root1, p, b) - lm 

3681 d2 = self._logquasipdf(root2, p, b) - lm 

3682 # compute the bounding rectangle w.r.t. h. Note that 

3683 # np.exp(0.5*d1) = np.sqrt(g(root1)/g(m)) = np.sqrt(h(root1)) 

3684 vmin = (root1 - m) * np.exp(0.5 * d1) 

3685 vmax = (root2 - m) * np.exp(0.5 * d2) 

3686 umax = 1 # umax = sqrt(h(m)) = 1 

3687 

3688 logqpdf = lambda x: self._logquasipdf(x, p, b) - lm 

3689 c = m 

3690 else: 

3691 # ratio of uniforms without mode shift 

3692 # compute np.sqrt(quasipdf(m)) 

3693 umax = np.exp(0.5*self._logquasipdf(m, p, b)) 

3694 xplus = ((1 + p) + np.sqrt((1 + p)**2 + b**2))/b 

3695 vmin = 0 

3696 # compute xplus * np.sqrt(quasipdf(xplus)) 

3697 vmax = xplus * np.exp(0.5 * self._logquasipdf(xplus, p, b)) 

3698 c = 0 

3699 logqpdf = lambda x: self._logquasipdf(x, p, b) 

3700 

3701 if vmin >= vmax: 

3702 raise ValueError("vmin must be smaller than vmax.") 

3703 if umax <= 0: 

3704 raise ValueError("umax must be positive.") 

3705 

3706 i = 1 

3707 while simulated < N: 

3708 k = N - simulated 

3709 # simulate uniform rvs on [0, umax] and [vmin, vmax] 

3710 u = umax * self._random_state.random_sample(size=k) 

3711 v = self._random_state.random_sample(size=k) 

3712 v = vmin + (vmax - vmin) * v 

3713 rvs = v / u + c 

3714 # rewrite acceptance condition u**2 <= pdf(rvs) by taking logs 

3715 accept = (2*np.log(u) <= logqpdf(rvs)) 

3716 num_accept = np.sum(accept) 

3717 if num_accept > 0: 

3718 x[simulated:(simulated + num_accept)] = rvs[accept] 

3719 simulated += num_accept 

3720 

3721 if (simulated == 0) and (i*N >= 50000): 

3722 msg = ("Not a single random variate could be generated " 

3723 "in {} attempts. Sampling does not appear to " 

3724 "work for the provided parameters.".format(i*N)) 

3725 raise RuntimeError(msg) 

3726 i += 1 

3727 else: 

3728 # use new algorithm in [2] 

3729 x0 = b / (1 - p) 

3730 xs = np.max((x0, 2 / b)) 

3731 k1 = np.exp(self._logquasipdf(m, p, b)) 

3732 A1 = k1 * x0 

3733 if x0 < 2 / b: 

3734 k2 = np.exp(-b) 

3735 if p > 0: 

3736 A2 = k2 * ((2 / b)**p - x0**p) / p 

3737 else: 

3738 A2 = k2 * np.log(2 / b**2) 

3739 else: 

3740 k2, A2 = 0, 0 

3741 k3 = xs**(p - 1) 

3742 A3 = 2 * k3 * np.exp(-xs * b / 2) / b 

3743 A = A1 + A2 + A3 

3744 

3745 # [2]: rejection constant is < 2.73; so expected runtime is finite 

3746 while simulated < N: 

3747 k = N - simulated 

3748 h, rvs = np.zeros(k), np.zeros(k) 

3749 # simulate uniform rvs on [x1, x2] and [0, y2] 

3750 u = self._random_state.random_sample(size=k) 

3751 v = A * self._random_state.random_sample(size=k) 

3752 cond1 = v <= A1 

3753 cond2 = np.logical_not(cond1) & (v <= A1 + A2) 

3754 cond3 = np.logical_not(cond1 | cond2) 

3755 # subdomain (0, x0) 

3756 rvs[cond1] = x0 * v[cond1] / A1 

3757 h[cond1] = k1 

3758 # subdomain (x0, 2 / b) 

3759 if p > 0: 

3760 rvs[cond2] = (x0**p + (v[cond2] - A1) * p / k2)**(1 / p) 

3761 else: 

3762 rvs[cond2] = b * np.exp((v[cond2] - A1) * np.exp(b)) 

3763 h[cond2] = k2 * rvs[cond2]**(p - 1) 

3764 # subdomain (xs, infinity) 

3765 z = np.exp(-xs * b / 2) - b * (v[cond3] - A1 - A2) / (2 * k3) 

3766 rvs[cond3] = -2 / b * np.log(z) 

3767 h[cond3] = k3 * np.exp(-rvs[cond3] * b / 2) 

3768 # apply rejection method 

3769 accept = (np.log(u * h) <= self._logquasipdf(rvs, p, b)) 

3770 num_accept = sum(accept) 

3771 if num_accept > 0: 

3772 x[simulated:(simulated + num_accept)] = rvs[accept] 

3773 simulated += num_accept 

3774 

3775 rvs = np.reshape(x, size1d) 

3776 if invert_res: 

3777 rvs = 1 / rvs 

3778 if self._size == (): 

3779 # return scalar in that case; however, return array if size == 1 

3780 return rvs[0] 

3781 return rvs 

3782 

3783 def _mode(self, p, b): 

3784 # distinguish cases to avoid catastrophic cancellation (see [2]) 

3785 if p < 1: 

3786 return b / (np.sqrt((p - 1)**2 + b**2) + 1 - p) 

3787 else: 

3788 return (np.sqrt((1 - p)**2 + b**2) - (1 - p)) / b 

3789 

3790 def _munp(self, n, p, b): 

3791 num = sc.kve(p + n, b) 

3792 denom = sc.kve(p, b) 

3793 inf_vals = np.isinf(num) | np.isinf(denom) 

3794 if inf_vals.any(): 

3795 msg = ("Infinite values encountered in the moment calculation " 

3796 "involving scipy.special.kve. Values replaced by NaN to " 

3797 "avoid incorrect results.") 

3798 warnings.warn(msg, RuntimeWarning) 

3799 m = np.full_like(num, np.nan, dtype=np.double) 

3800 m[~inf_vals] = num[~inf_vals] / denom[~inf_vals] 

3801 else: 

3802 m = num / denom 

3803 return m 

3804 

3805 

3806geninvgauss = geninvgauss_gen(a=0.0, name="geninvgauss") 

3807 

3808 

3809class norminvgauss_gen(rv_continuous): 

3810 r"""A Normal Inverse Gaussian continuous random variable. 

3811 

3812 %(before_notes)s 

3813 

3814 Notes 

3815 ----- 

3816 The probability density function for `norminvgauss` is: 

3817 

3818 .. math:: 

3819 

3820 f(x, a, b) = (a \exp(\sqrt{a^2 - b^2} + b x)) / 

3821 (\pi \sqrt{1 + x^2} \, K_1(a \sqrt{1 + x^2})) 

3822 

3823 where :math:`x` is a real number, the parameter :math:`a` is the tail 

3824 heaviness and :math:`b` is the asymmetry parameter satisfying 

3825 :math:`a > 0` and :math:`|b| <= a`. 

3826 :math:`K_1` is the modified Bessel function of second kind 

3827 (`scipy.special.k1`). 

3828 

3829 %(after_notes)s 

3830 

3831 A normal inverse Gaussian random variable `Y` with parameters `a` and `b` 

3832 can be expressed as a normal mean-variance mixture: 

3833 `Y = b * V + sqrt(V) * X` where `X` is `norm(0,1)` and `V` is 

3834 `invgauss(mu=1/sqrt(a**2 - b**2))`. This representation is used 

3835 to generate random variates. 

3836 

3837 References 

3838 ---------- 

3839 O. Barndorff-Nielsen, "Hyperbolic Distributions and Distributions on 

3840 Hyperbolae", Scandinavian Journal of Statistics, Vol. 5(3), 

3841 pp. 151-157, 1978. 

3842 

3843 O. Barndorff-Nielsen, "Normal Inverse Gaussian Distributions and Stochastic 

3844 Volatility Modelling", Scandinavian Journal of Statistics, Vol. 24, 

3845 pp. 1-13, 1997. 

3846 

3847 %(example)s 

3848 

3849 """ 

3850 _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask 

3851 

3852 def _argcheck(self, a, b): 

3853 return (a > 0) & (np.absolute(b) < a) 

3854 

3855 def _pdf(self, x, a, b): 

3856 gamma = np.sqrt(a**2 - b**2) 

3857 fac1 = a / np.pi * np.exp(gamma) 

3858 sq = np.hypot(1, x) # reduce overflows 

3859 return fac1 * sc.k1e(a * sq) * np.exp(b*x - a*sq) / sq 

3860 

3861 def _rvs(self, a, b): 

3862 # note: X = b * V + sqrt(V) * X is norminvgaus(a,b) if X is standard 

3863 # normal and V is invgauss(mu=1/sqrt(a**2 - b**2)) 

3864 gamma = np.sqrt(a**2 - b**2) 

3865 sz, rndm = self._size, self._random_state 

3866 ig = invgauss.rvs(mu=1/gamma, size=sz, random_state=rndm) 

3867 return b * ig + np.sqrt(ig) * norm.rvs(size=sz, random_state=rndm) 

3868 

3869 def _stats(self, a, b): 

3870 gamma = np.sqrt(a**2 - b**2) 

3871 mean = b / gamma 

3872 variance = a**2 / gamma**3 

3873 skewness = 3.0 * b / (a * np.sqrt(gamma)) 

3874 kurtosis = 3.0 * (1 + 4 * b**2 / a**2) / gamma 

3875 return mean, variance, skewness, kurtosis 

3876 

3877 

3878norminvgauss = norminvgauss_gen(name="norminvgauss") 

3879 

3880 

3881class invweibull_gen(rv_continuous): 

3882 u"""An inverted Weibull continuous random variable. 

3883 

3884 This distribution is also known as the Fréchet distribution or the 

3885 type II extreme value distribution. 

3886 

3887 %(before_notes)s 

3888 

3889 Notes 

3890 ----- 

3891 The probability density function for `invweibull` is: 

3892 

3893 .. math:: 

3894 

3895 f(x, c) = c x^{-c-1} \\exp(-x^{-c}) 

3896 

3897 for :math:`x > 0`, :math:`c > 0`. 

3898 

3899 `invweibull` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 

3900 

3901 %(after_notes)s 

3902 

3903 References 

3904 ---------- 

3905 F.R.S. de Gusmao, E.M.M Ortega and G.M. Cordeiro, "The generalized inverse 

3906 Weibull distribution", Stat. Papers, vol. 52, pp. 591-619, 2011. 

3907 

3908 %(example)s 

3909 

3910 """ 

3911 _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask 

3912 

3913 def _pdf(self, x, c): 

3914 # invweibull.pdf(x, c) = c * x**(-c-1) * exp(-x**(-c)) 

3915 xc1 = np.power(x, -c - 1.0) 

3916 xc2 = np.power(x, -c) 

3917 xc2 = np.exp(-xc2) 

3918 return c * xc1 * xc2 

3919 

3920 def _cdf(self, x, c): 

3921 xc1 = np.power(x, -c) 

3922 return np.exp(-xc1) 

3923 

3924 def _ppf(self, q, c): 

3925 return np.power(-np.log(q), -1.0/c) 

3926 

3927 def _munp(self, n, c): 

3928 return sc.gamma(1 - n / c) 

3929 

3930 def _entropy(self, c): 

3931 return 1+_EULER + _EULER / c - np.log(c) 

3932 

3933 

3934invweibull = invweibull_gen(a=0, name='invweibull') 

3935 

3936 

3937class johnsonsb_gen(rv_continuous): 

3938 r"""A Johnson SB continuous random variable. 

3939 

3940 %(before_notes)s 

3941 

3942 See Also 

3943 -------- 

3944 johnsonsu 

3945 

3946 Notes 

3947 ----- 

3948 The probability density function for `johnsonsb` is: 

3949 

3950 .. math:: 

3951 

3952 f(x, a, b) = \frac{b}{x(1-x)} \phi(a + b \log \frac{x}{1-x} ) 

3953 

3954 for :math:`0 <= x < =1` and :math:`a, b > 0`, and :math:`\phi` is the normal 

3955 pdf. 

3956 

3957 `johnsonsb` takes :math:`a` and :math:`b` as shape parameters. 

3958 

3959 %(after_notes)s 

3960 

3961 %(example)s 

3962 

3963 """ 

3964 _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask 

3965 

3966 def _argcheck(self, a, b): 

3967 return (b > 0) & (a == a) 

3968 

3969 def _pdf(self, x, a, b): 

3970 # johnsonsb.pdf(x, a, b) = b / (x*(1-x)) * phi(a + b * log(x/(1-x))) 

3971 trm = _norm_pdf(a + b*np.log(x/(1.0-x))) 

3972 return b*1.0/(x*(1-x))*trm 

3973 

3974 def _cdf(self, x, a, b): 

3975 return _norm_cdf(a + b*np.log(x/(1.0-x))) 

3976 

3977 def _ppf(self, q, a, b): 

3978 return 1.0 / (1 + np.exp(-1.0 / b * (_norm_ppf(q) - a))) 

3979 

3980 

3981johnsonsb = johnsonsb_gen(a=0.0, b=1.0, name='johnsonsb') 

3982 

3983 

3984class johnsonsu_gen(rv_continuous): 

3985 r"""A Johnson SU continuous random variable. 

3986 

3987 %(before_notes)s 

3988 

3989 See Also 

3990 -------- 

3991 johnsonsb 

3992 

3993 Notes 

3994 ----- 

3995 The probability density function for `johnsonsu` is: 

3996 

3997 .. math:: 

3998 

3999 f(x, a, b) = \frac{b}{\sqrt{x^2 + 1}} 

4000 \phi(a + b \log(x + \sqrt{x^2 + 1})) 

4001 

4002 for all :math:`x, a, b > 0`, and :math:`\phi` is the normal pdf. 

4003 

4004 `johnsonsu` takes :math:`a` and :math:`b` as shape parameters. 

4005 

4006 %(after_notes)s 

4007 

4008 %(example)s 

4009 

4010 """ 

4011 def _argcheck(self, a, b): 

4012 return (b > 0) & (a == a) 

4013 

4014 def _pdf(self, x, a, b): 

4015 # johnsonsu.pdf(x, a, b) = b / sqrt(x**2 + 1) * 

4016 # phi(a + b * log(x + sqrt(x**2 + 1))) 

4017 x2 = x*x 

4018 trm = _norm_pdf(a + b * np.log(x + np.sqrt(x2+1))) 

4019 return b*1.0/np.sqrt(x2+1.0)*trm 

4020 

4021 def _cdf(self, x, a, b): 

4022 return _norm_cdf(a + b * np.log(x + np.sqrt(x*x + 1))) 

4023 

4024 def _ppf(self, q, a, b): 

4025 return np.sinh((_norm_ppf(q) - a) / b) 

4026 

4027 

4028johnsonsu = johnsonsu_gen(name='johnsonsu') 

4029 

4030 

4031class laplace_gen(rv_continuous): 

4032 r"""A Laplace continuous random variable. 

4033 

4034 %(before_notes)s 

4035 

4036 Notes 

4037 ----- 

4038 The probability density function for `laplace` is 

4039 

4040 .. math:: 

4041 

4042 f(x) = \frac{1}{2} \exp(-|x|) 

4043 

4044 for a real number :math:`x`. 

4045 

4046 %(after_notes)s 

4047 

4048 %(example)s 

4049 

4050 """ 

4051 def _rvs(self): 

4052 return self._random_state.laplace(0, 1, size=self._size) 

4053 

4054 def _pdf(self, x): 

4055 # laplace.pdf(x) = 1/2 * exp(-abs(x)) 

4056 return 0.5*np.exp(-abs(x)) 

4057 

4058 def _cdf(self, x): 

4059 return np.where(x > 0, 1.0-0.5*np.exp(-x), 0.5*np.exp(x)) 

4060 

4061 def _ppf(self, q): 

4062 return np.where(q > 0.5, -np.log(2*(1-q)), np.log(2*q)) 

4063 

4064 def _stats(self): 

4065 return 0, 2, 0, 3 

4066 

4067 def _entropy(self): 

4068 return np.log(2)+1 

4069 

4070 

4071laplace = laplace_gen(name='laplace') 

4072 

4073 

4074class levy_gen(rv_continuous): 

4075 r"""A Levy continuous random variable. 

4076 

4077 %(before_notes)s 

4078 

4079 See Also 

4080 -------- 

4081 levy_stable, levy_l 

4082 

4083 Notes 

4084 ----- 

4085 The probability density function for `levy` is: 

4086 

4087 .. math:: 

4088 

4089 f(x) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi x^3}} \exp\left(-\frac{1}{2x}\right) 

4090 

4091 for :math:`x >= 0`. 

4092 

4093 This is the same as the Levy-stable distribution with :math:`a=1/2` and 

4094 :math:`b=1`. 

4095 

4096 %(after_notes)s 

4097 

4098 %(example)s 

4099 

4100 """ 

4101 _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask 

4102 

4103 def _pdf(self, x): 

4104 # levy.pdf(x) = 1 / (x * sqrt(2*pi*x)) * exp(-1/(2*x)) 

4105 return 1 / np.sqrt(2*np.pi*x) / x * np.exp(-1/(2*x)) 

4106 

4107 def _cdf(self, x): 

4108 # Equivalent to 2*norm.sf(np.sqrt(1/x)) 

4109 return sc.erfc(np.sqrt(0.5 / x)) 

4110 

4111 def _ppf(self, q): 

4112 # Equivalent to 1.0/(norm.isf(q/2)**2) or 0.5/(erfcinv(q)**2) 

4113 val = -sc.ndtri(q/2) 

4114 return 1.0 / (val * val) 

4115 

4116 def _stats(self): 

4117 return np.inf, np.inf, np.nan, np.nan 

4118 

4119 

4120levy = levy_gen(a=0.0, name="levy") 

4121 

4122 

4123class levy_l_gen(rv_continuous): 

4124 r"""A left-skewed Levy continuous random variable. 

4125 

4126 %(before_notes)s 

4127 

4128 See Also 

4129 -------- 

4130 levy, levy_stable 

4131 

4132 Notes 

4133 ----- 

4134 The probability density function for `levy_l` is: 

4135 

4136 .. math:: 

4137 f(x) = \frac{1}{|x| \sqrt{2\pi |x|}} \exp{ \left(-\frac{1}{2|x|} \right)} 

4138 

4139 for :math:`x <= 0`. 

4140 

4141 This is the same as the Levy-stable distribution with :math:`a=1/2` and 

4142 :math:`b=-1`. 

4143 

4144 %(after_notes)s 

4145 

4146 %(example)s 

4147 

4148 """ 

4149 _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask 

4150 

4151 def _pdf(self, x): 

4152 # levy_l.pdf(x) = 1 / (abs(x) * sqrt(2*pi*abs(x))) * exp(-1/(2*abs(x))) 

4153 ax = abs(x) 

4154 return 1/np.sqrt(2*np.pi*ax)/ax*np.exp(-1/(2*ax)) 

4155 

4156 def _cdf(self, x): 

4157 ax = abs(x) 

4158 return 2 * _norm_cdf(1 / np.sqrt(ax)) - 1 

4159 

4160 def _ppf(self, q): 

4161 val = _norm_ppf((q + 1.0) / 2) 

4162 return -1.0 / (val * val) 

4163 

4164 def _stats(self): 

4165 return np.inf, np.inf, np.nan, np.nan 

4166 

4167 

4168levy_l = levy_l_gen(b=0.0, name="levy_l") 

4169 

4170 

4171class levy_stable_gen(rv_continuous): 

4172 r"""A Levy-stable continuous random variable. 

4173 

4174 %(before_notes)s 

4175 

4176 See Also 

4177 -------- 

4178 levy, levy_l 

4179 

4180 Notes 

4181 ----- 

4182 The distribution for `levy_stable` has characteristic function: 

4183 

4184 .. math:: 

4185 

4186 \varphi(t, \alpha, \beta, c, \mu) = 

4187 e^{it\mu -|ct|^{\alpha}(1-i\beta \operatorname{sign}(t)\Phi(\alpha, t))} 

4188 

4189 where: 

4190 

4191 .. math:: 

4192 

4193 \Phi = \begin{cases} 

4194 \tan \left({\frac {\pi \alpha }{2}}\right)&\alpha \neq 1\\ 

4195 -{\frac {2}{\pi }}\log |t|&\alpha =1 

4196 \end{cases} 

4197 

4198 The probability density function for `levy_stable` is: 

4199 

4200 .. math:: 

4201 

4202 f(x) = \frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\infty}^\infty \varphi(t)e^{-ixt}\,dt 

4203 

4204 where :math:`-\infty < t < \infty`. This integral does not have a known closed form. 

4205 

4206 For evaluation of pdf we use either Zolotarev :math:`S_0` parameterization with integration, 

4207 direct integration of standard parameterization of characteristic function or FFT of 

4208 characteristic function. If set to other than None and if number of points is greater than 

4209 ``levy_stable.pdf_fft_min_points_threshold`` (defaults to None) we use FFT otherwise we use one 

4210 of the other methods. 

4211 

4212 The default method is 'best' which uses Zolotarev's method if alpha = 1 and integration of 

4213 characteristic function otherwise. The default method can be changed by setting 

4214 ``levy_stable.pdf_default_method`` to either 'zolotarev', 'quadrature' or 'best'. 

4215 

4216 To increase accuracy of FFT calculation one can specify ``levy_stable.pdf_fft_grid_spacing`` 

4217 (defaults to 0.001) and ``pdf_fft_n_points_two_power`` (defaults to a value that covers the 

4218 input range * 4). Setting ``pdf_fft_n_points_two_power`` to 16 should be sufficiently accurate 

4219 in most cases at the expense of CPU time. 

4220 

4221 For evaluation of cdf we use Zolatarev :math:`S_0` parameterization with integration or integral of 

4222 the pdf FFT interpolated spline. The settings affecting FFT calculation are the same as 

4223 for pdf calculation. Setting the threshold to ``None`` (default) will disable FFT. For cdf 

4224 calculations the Zolatarev method is superior in accuracy, so FFT is disabled by default. 

4225 

4226 Fitting estimate uses quantile estimation method in [MC]. MLE estimation of parameters in 

4227 fit method uses this quantile estimate initially. Note that MLE doesn't always converge if 

4228 using FFT for pdf calculations; so it's best that ``pdf_fft_min_points_threshold`` is left unset. 

4229 

4230 .. warning:: 

4231 

4232 For pdf calculations implementation of Zolatarev is unstable for values where alpha = 1 and 

4233 beta != 0. In this case the quadrature method is recommended. FFT calculation is also 

4234 considered experimental. 

4235 

4236 For cdf calculations FFT calculation is considered experimental. Use Zolatarev's method 

4237 instead (default). 

4238 

4239 %(after_notes)s 

4240 

4241 References 

4242 ---------- 

4243 .. [MC] McCulloch, J., 1986. Simple consistent estimators of stable distribution parameters. 

4244 Communications in Statistics - Simulation and Computation 15, 11091136. 

4245 .. [MS] Mittnik, S.T. Rachev, T. Doganoglu, D. Chenyao, 1999. Maximum likelihood estimation 

4246 of stable Paretian models, Mathematical and Computer Modelling, Volume 29, Issue 10, 

4247 1999, Pages 275-293. 

4248 .. [BS] Borak, S., Hardle, W., Rafal, W. 2005. Stable distributions, Economic Risk. 

4249 

4250 %(example)s 

4251 

4252 """ 

4253 

4254 def _rvs(self, alpha, beta): 

4255 

4256 def alpha1func(alpha, beta, TH, aTH, bTH, cosTH, tanTH, W): 

4257 return (2/np.pi*(np.pi/2 + bTH)*tanTH - 

4258 beta*np.log((np.pi/2*W*cosTH)/(np.pi/2 + bTH))) 

4259 

4260 def beta0func(alpha, beta, TH, aTH, bTH, cosTH, tanTH, W): 

4261 return (W/(cosTH/np.tan(aTH) + np.sin(TH)) * 

4262 ((np.cos(aTH) + np.sin(aTH)*tanTH)/W)**(1.0/alpha)) 

4263 

4264 def otherwise(alpha, beta, TH, aTH, bTH, cosTH, tanTH, W): 

4265 # alpha is not 1 and beta is not 0 

4266 val0 = beta*np.tan(np.pi*alpha/2) 

4267 th0 = np.arctan(val0)/alpha 

4268 val3 = W/(cosTH/np.tan(alpha*(th0 + TH)) + np.sin(TH)) 

4269 res3 = val3*((np.cos(aTH) + np.sin(aTH)*tanTH - 

4270 val0*(np.sin(aTH) - np.cos(aTH)*tanTH))/W)**(1.0/alpha) 

4271 return res3 

4272 

4273 def alphanot1func(alpha, beta, TH, aTH, bTH, cosTH, tanTH, W): 

4274 res = _lazywhere(beta == 0, 

4275 (alpha, beta, TH, aTH, bTH, cosTH, tanTH, W), 

4276 beta0func, f2=otherwise) 

4277 return res 

4278 

4279 sz = self._size 

4280 alpha = broadcast_to(alpha, sz) 

4281 beta = broadcast_to(beta, sz) 

4282 TH = uniform.rvs(loc=-np.pi/2.0, scale=np.pi, size=sz, 

4283 random_state=self._random_state) 

4284 W = expon.rvs(size=sz, random_state=self._random_state) 

4285 aTH = alpha*TH 

4286 bTH = beta*TH 

4287 cosTH = np.cos(TH) 

4288 tanTH = np.tan(TH) 

4289 res = _lazywhere(alpha == 1, 

4290 (alpha, beta, TH, aTH, bTH, cosTH, tanTH, W), 

4291 alpha1func, f2=alphanot1func) 

4292 return res 

4293 

4294 def _argcheck(self, alpha, beta): 

4295 return (alpha > 0) & (alpha <= 2) & (beta <= 1) & (beta >= -1) 

4296 

4297 @staticmethod 

4298 def _cf(t, alpha, beta): 

4299 Phi = lambda alpha, t: np.tan(np.pi*alpha/2) if alpha != 1 else -2.0*np.log(np.abs(t))/np.pi 

4300 return np.exp(-(np.abs(t)**alpha)*(1-1j*beta*np.sign(t)*Phi(alpha, t))) 

4301 

4302 @staticmethod 

4303 def _pdf_from_cf_with_fft(cf, h=0.01, q=9): 

4304 """Calculates pdf from cf using fft. Using region around 0 with N=2**q points 

4305 separated by distance h. As suggested by [MS]. 

4306 """ 

4307 N = 2**q 

4308 n = np.arange(1,N+1) 

4309 density = ((-1)**(n-1-N/2))*np.fft.fft(((-1)**(n-1))*cf(2*np.pi*(n-1-N/2)/h/N))/h/N 

4310 x = (n-1-N/2)*h 

4311 return (x, density) 

4312 

4313 @staticmethod 

4314 def _pdf_single_value_best(x, alpha, beta): 

4315 if alpha != 1. or (alpha == 1. and beta == 0.): 

4316 return levy_stable_gen._pdf_single_value_zolotarev(x, alpha, beta) 

4317 else: 

4318 return levy_stable_gen._pdf_single_value_cf_integrate(x, alpha, beta) 

4319 

4320 @staticmethod 

4321 def _pdf_single_value_cf_integrate(x, alpha, beta): 

4322 cf = lambda t: levy_stable_gen._cf(t, alpha, beta) 

4323 return integrate.quad(lambda t: np.real(np.exp(-1j*t*x)*cf(t)), -np.inf, np.inf, limit=1000)[0]/np.pi/2 

4324 

4325 @staticmethod 

4326 def _pdf_single_value_zolotarev(x, alpha, beta): 

4327 """Calculate pdf using Zolotarev's methods as detailed in [BS]. 

4328 """ 

4329 zeta = -beta*np.tan(np.pi*alpha/2.) 

4330 if alpha != 1: 

4331 x0 = x + zeta # convert to S_0 parameterization 

4332 xi = np.arctan(-zeta)/alpha 

4333 

4334 def V(theta): 

4335 return np.cos(alpha*xi)**(1/(alpha-1)) * \ 

4336 (np.cos(theta)/np.sin(alpha*(xi+theta)))**(alpha/(alpha-1)) * \ 

4337 (np.cos(alpha*xi+(alpha-1)*theta)/np.cos(theta)) 

4338 if x0 > zeta: 

4339 def g(theta): 

4340 return V(theta)*np.real(np.complex(x0-zeta)**(alpha/(alpha-1))) 

4341 

4342 def f(theta): 

4343 return g(theta) * np.exp(-g(theta)) 

4344 

4345 # spare calculating integral on null set 

4346 # use isclose as macos has fp differences 

4347 if np.isclose(-xi, np.pi/2, rtol=1e-014, atol=1e-014): 

4348 return 0. 

4349 

4350 with np.errstate(all="ignore"): 

4351 intg_max = optimize.minimize_scalar(lambda theta: -f(theta), bounds=[-xi, np.pi/2]) 

4352 intg_kwargs = {} 

4353 # windows quadpack less forgiving with points out of bounds 

4354 if intg_max.success and not np.isnan(intg_max.fun)\ 

4355 and intg_max.x > -xi and intg_max.x < np.pi/2: 

4356 intg_kwargs["points"] = [intg_max.x] 

4357 intg = integrate.quad(f, -xi, np.pi/2, **intg_kwargs)[0] 

4358 return alpha * intg / np.pi / np.abs(alpha-1) / (x0-zeta) 

4359 elif x0 == zeta: 

4360 return sc.gamma(1+1/alpha)*np.cos(xi)/np.pi/((1+zeta**2)**(1/alpha/2)) 

4361 else: 

4362 return levy_stable_gen._pdf_single_value_zolotarev(-x, alpha, -beta) 

4363 else: 

4364 # since location zero, no need to reposition x for S_0 parameterization 

4365 xi = np.pi/2 

4366 if beta != 0: 

4367 warnings.warn('Density calculation unstable for alpha=1 and beta!=0.' + 

4368 ' Use quadrature method instead.', RuntimeWarning) 

4369 

4370 def V(theta): 

4371 expr_1 = np.pi/2+beta*theta 

4372 return 2. * expr_1 * np.exp(expr_1*np.tan(theta)/beta) / np.cos(theta) / np.pi 

4373 

4374 def g(theta): 

4375 return np.exp(-np.pi * x / 2. / beta) * V(theta) 

4376 

4377 def f(theta): 

4378 return g(theta) * np.exp(-g(theta)) 

4379 

4380 with np.errstate(all="ignore"): 

4381 intg_max = optimize.minimize_scalar(lambda theta: -f(theta), bounds=[-np.pi/2, np.pi/2]) 

4382 intg = integrate.fixed_quad(f, -np.pi/2, intg_max.x)[0] + integrate.fixed_quad(f, intg_max.x, np.pi/2)[0] 

4383 return intg / np.abs(beta) / 2. 

4384 else: 

4385 return 1/(1+x**2)/np.pi 

4386 

4387 @staticmethod 

4388 def _cdf_single_value_zolotarev(x, alpha, beta): 

4389 """Calculate cdf using Zolotarev's methods as detailed in [BS]. 

4390 """ 

4391 zeta = -beta*np.tan(np.pi*alpha/2.) 

4392 if alpha != 1: 

4393 x0 = x + zeta # convert to S_0 parameterization 

4394 xi = np.arctan(-zeta)/alpha 

4395 

4396 def V(theta): 

4397 return np.cos(alpha*xi)**(1/(alpha-1)) * \ 

4398 (np.cos(theta)/np.sin(alpha*(xi+theta)))**(alpha/(alpha-1)) * \ 

4399 (np.cos(alpha*xi+(alpha-1)*theta)/np.cos(theta)) 

4400 if x0 > zeta: 

4401 c_1 = 1 if alpha > 1 else .5 - xi/np.pi 

4402 

4403 def f(theta): 

4404 return np.exp(-V(theta)*np.real(np.complex(x0-zeta)**(alpha/(alpha-1)))) 

4405 

4406 with np.errstate(all="ignore"): 

4407 # spare calculating integral on null set 

4408 # use isclose as macos has fp differences 

4409 if np.isclose(-xi, np.pi/2, rtol=1e-014, atol=1e-014): 

4410 intg = 0 

4411 else: 

4412 intg = integrate.quad(f, -xi, np.pi/2)[0] 

4413 return c_1 + np.sign(1-alpha) * intg / np.pi 

4414 elif x0 == zeta: 

4415 return .5 - xi/np.pi 

4416 else: 

4417 return 1 - levy_stable_gen._cdf_single_value_zolotarev(-x, alpha, -beta) 

4418 

4419 else: 

4420 # since location zero, no need to reposition x for S_0 parameterization 

4421 xi = np.pi/2 

4422 if beta > 0: 

4423 

4424 def V(theta): 

4425 expr_1 = np.pi/2+beta*theta 

4426 return 2. * expr_1 * np.exp(expr_1*np.tan(theta)/beta) / np.cos(theta) / np.pi 

4427 

4428 with np.errstate(all="ignore"): 

4429 expr_1 = np.exp(-np.pi*x/beta/2.) 

4430 int_1 = integrate.quad(lambda theta: np.exp(-expr_1 * V(theta)), -np.pi/2, np.pi/2)[0] 

4431 return int_1 / np.pi 

4432 elif beta == 0: 

4433 return .5 + np.arctan(x)/np.pi 

4434 else: 

4435 return 1 - levy_stable_gen._cdf_single_value_zolotarev(-x, 1, -beta) 

4436 

4437 def _pdf(self, x, alpha, beta): 

4438 

4439 x = np.asarray(x).reshape(1, -1)[0,:] 

4440 

4441 x, alpha, beta = np.broadcast_arrays(x, alpha, beta) 

4442 

4443 data_in = np.dstack((x, alpha, beta))[0] 

4444 data_out = np.empty(shape=(len(data_in),1)) 

4445 

4446 pdf_default_method_name = getattr(self, 'pdf_default_method', 'best') 

4447 if pdf_default_method_name == 'best': 

4448 pdf_single_value_method = levy_stable_gen._pdf_single_value_best 

4449 elif pdf_default_method_name == 'zolotarev': 

4450 pdf_single_value_method = levy_stable_gen._pdf_single_value_zolotarev 

4451 else: 

4452 pdf_single_value_method = levy_stable_gen._pdf_single_value_cf_integrate 

4453 

4454 fft_min_points_threshold = getattr(self, 'pdf_fft_min_points_threshold', None) 

4455 fft_grid_spacing = getattr(self, 'pdf_fft_grid_spacing', 0.001) 

4456 fft_n_points_two_power = getattr(self, 'pdf_fft_n_points_two_power', None) 

4457 

4458 # group data in unique arrays of alpha, beta pairs 

4459 uniq_param_pairs = np.vstack(list({tuple(row) for row in 

4460 data_in[:, 1:]})) 

4461 for pair in uniq_param_pairs: 

4462 data_mask = np.all(data_in[:,1:] == pair, axis=-1) 

4463 data_subset = data_in[data_mask] 

4464 if fft_min_points_threshold is None or len(data_subset) < fft_min_points_threshold: 

4465 data_out[data_mask] = np.array([pdf_single_value_method(_x, _alpha, _beta) 

4466 for _x, _alpha, _beta in data_subset]).reshape(len(data_subset), 1) 

4467 else: 

4468 warnings.warn('Density calculations experimental for FFT method.' + 

4469 ' Use combination of zolatarev and quadrature methods instead.', RuntimeWarning) 

4470 _alpha, _beta = pair 

4471 _x = data_subset[:,(0,)] 

4472 

4473 # need enough points to "cover" _x for interpolation 

4474 h = fft_grid_spacing 

4475 q = np.ceil(np.log(2*np.max(np.abs(_x))/h)/np.log(2)) + 2 if fft_n_points_two_power is None else int(fft_n_points_two_power) 

4476 

4477 density_x, density = levy_stable_gen._pdf_from_cf_with_fft(lambda t: levy_stable_gen._cf(t, _alpha, _beta), h=h, q=q) 

4478 f = interpolate.interp1d(density_x, np.real(density)) 

4479 data_out[data_mask] = f(_x) 

4480 

4481 return data_out.T[0] 

4482 

4483 def _cdf(self, x, alpha, beta): 

4484 

4485 x = np.asarray(x).reshape(1, -1)[0,:] 

4486 

4487 x, alpha, beta = np.broadcast_arrays(x, alpha, beta) 

4488 

4489 data_in = np.dstack((x, alpha, beta))[0] 

4490 data_out = np.empty(shape=(len(data_in),1)) 

4491 

4492 fft_min_points_threshold = getattr(self, 'pdf_fft_min_points_threshold', None) 

4493 fft_grid_spacing = getattr(self, 'pdf_fft_grid_spacing', 0.001) 

4494 fft_n_points_two_power = getattr(self, 'pdf_fft_n_points_two_power', None) 

4495 

4496 # group data in unique arrays of alpha, beta pairs 

4497 uniq_param_pairs = np.vstack( 

4498 list({tuple(row) for row in data_in[:,1:]})) 

4499 for pair in uniq_param_pairs: 

4500 data_mask = np.all(data_in[:,1:] == pair, axis=-1) 

4501 data_subset = data_in[data_mask] 

4502 if fft_min_points_threshold is None or len(data_subset) < fft_min_points_threshold: 

4503 data_out[data_mask] = np.array([levy_stable._cdf_single_value_zolotarev(_x, _alpha, _beta) 

4504 for _x, _alpha, _beta in data_subset]).reshape(len(data_subset), 1) 

4505 else: 

4506 warnings.warn(u'FFT method is considered experimental for ' + 

4507 u'cumulative distribution function ' + 

4508 u'evaluations. Use Zolotarev’s method instead).', 

4509 RuntimeWarning) 

4510 _alpha, _beta = pair 

4511 _x = data_subset[:,(0,)] 

4512 

4513 # need enough points to "cover" _x for interpolation 

4514 h = fft_grid_spacing 

4515 q = 16 if fft_n_points_two_power is None else int(fft_n_points_two_power) 

4516 

4517 density_x, density = levy_stable_gen._pdf_from_cf_with_fft(lambda t: levy_stable_gen._cf(t, _alpha, _beta), h=h, q=q) 

4518 f = interpolate.InterpolatedUnivariateSpline(density_x, np.real(density)) 

4519 data_out[data_mask] = np.array([f.integral(self.a, x_1) for x_1 in _x]).reshape(data_out[data_mask].shape) 

4520 

4521 return data_out.T[0] 

4522 

4523 def _fitstart(self, data): 

4524 # We follow McCullock 1986 method - Simple Consistent Estimators 

4525 # of Stable Distribution Parameters 

4526 

4527 # Table III and IV 

4528 nu_alpha_range = [2.439, 2.5, 2.6, 2.7, 2.8, 3, 3.2, 3.5, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 15, 25] 

4529 nu_beta_range = [0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7, 1] 

4530 

4531 # table III - alpha = psi_1(nu_alpha, nu_beta) 

4532 alpha_table = [ 

4533 [2.000, 2.000, 2.000, 2.000, 2.000, 2.000, 2.000], 

4534 [1.916, 1.924, 1.924, 1.924, 1.924, 1.924, 1.924], 

4535 [1.808, 1.813, 1.829, 1.829, 1.829, 1.829, 1.829], 

4536 [1.729, 1.730, 1.737, 1.745, 1.745, 1.745, 1.745], 

4537 [1.664, 1.663, 1.663, 1.668, 1.676, 1.676, 1.676], 

4538 [1.563, 1.560, 1.553, 1.548, 1.547, 1.547, 1.547], 

4539 [1.484, 1.480, 1.471, 1.460, 1.448, 1.438, 1.438], 

4540 [1.391, 1.386, 1.378, 1.364, 1.337, 1.318, 1.318], 

4541 [1.279, 1.273, 1.266, 1.250, 1.210, 1.184, 1.150], 

4542 [1.128, 1.121, 1.114, 1.101, 1.067, 1.027, 0.973], 

4543 [1.029, 1.021, 1.014, 1.004, 0.974, 0.935, 0.874], 

4544 [0.896, 0.892, 0.884, 0.883, 0.855, 0.823, 0.769], 

4545 [0.818, 0.812, 0.806, 0.801, 0.780, 0.756, 0.691], 

4546 [0.698, 0.695, 0.692, 0.689, 0.676, 0.656, 0.597], 

4547 [0.593, 0.590, 0.588, 0.586, 0.579, 0.563, 0.513]] 

4548 

4549 # table IV - beta = psi_2(nu_alpha, nu_beta) 

4550 beta_table = [ 

4551 [0, 2.160, 1.000, 1.000, 1.000, 1.000, 1.000], 

4552 [0, 1.592, 3.390, 1.000, 1.000, 1.000, 1.000], 

4553 [0, 0.759, 1.800, 1.000, 1.000, 1.000, 1.000], 

4554 [0, 0.482, 1.048, 1.694, 1.000, 1.000, 1.000], 

4555 [0, 0.360, 0.760, 1.232, 2.229, 1.000, 1.000], 

4556 [0, 0.253, 0.518, 0.823, 1.575, 1.000, 1.000], 

4557 [0, 0.203, 0.410, 0.632, 1.244, 1.906, 1.000], 

4558 [0, 0.165, 0.332, 0.499, 0.943, 1.560, 1.000], 

4559 [0, 0.136, 0.271, 0.404, 0.689, 1.230, 2.195], 

4560 [0, 0.109, 0.216, 0.323, 0.539, 0.827, 1.917], 

4561 [0, 0.096, 0.190, 0.284, 0.472, 0.693, 1.759], 

4562 [0, 0.082, 0.163, 0.243, 0.412, 0.601, 1.596], 

4563 [0, 0.074, 0.147, 0.220, 0.377, 0.546, 1.482], 

4564 [0, 0.064, 0.128, 0.191, 0.330, 0.478, 1.362], 

4565 [0, 0.056, 0.112, 0.167, 0.285, 0.428, 1.274]] 

4566 

4567 # Table V and VII 

4568 alpha_range = [2, 1.9, 1.8, 1.7, 1.6, 1.5, 1.4, 1.3, 1.2, 1.1, 1, 0.9, 0.8, 0.7, 0.6, 0.5] 

4569 beta_range = [0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1] 

4570 

4571 # Table V - nu_c = psi_3(alpha, beta) 

4572 nu_c_table = [ 

4573 [1.908, 1.908, 1.908, 1.908, 1.908], 

4574 [1.914, 1.915, 1.916, 1.918, 1.921], 

4575 [1.921, 1.922, 1.927, 1.936, 1.947], 

4576 [1.927, 1.930, 1.943, 1.961, 1.987], 

4577 [1.933, 1.940, 1.962, 1.997, 2.043], 

4578 [1.939, 1.952, 1.988, 2.045, 2.116], 

4579 [1.946, 1.967, 2.022, 2.106, 2.211], 

4580 [1.955, 1.984, 2.067, 2.188, 2.333], 

4581 [1.965, 2.007, 2.125, 2.294, 2.491], 

4582 [1.980, 2.040, 2.205, 2.435, 2.696], 

4583 [2.000, 2.085, 2.311, 2.624, 2.973], 

4584 [2.040, 2.149, 2.461, 2.886, 3.356], 

4585 [2.098, 2.244, 2.676, 3.265, 3.912], 

4586 [2.189, 2.392, 3.004, 3.844, 4.775], 

4587 [2.337, 2.634, 3.542, 4.808, 6.247], 

4588 [2.588, 3.073, 4.534, 6.636, 9.144]] 

4589 

4590 # Table VII - nu_zeta = psi_5(alpha, beta) 

4591 nu_zeta_table = [ 

4592 [0, 0.000, 0.000, 0.000, 0.000], 

4593 [0, -0.017, -0.032, -0.049, -0.064], 

4594 [0, -0.030, -0.061, -0.092, -0.123], 

4595 [0, -0.043, -0.088, -0.132, -0.179], 

4596 [0, -0.056, -0.111, -0.170, -0.232], 

4597 [0, -0.066, -0.134, -0.206, -0.283], 

4598 [0, -0.075, -0.154, -0.241, -0.335], 

4599 [0, -0.084, -0.173, -0.276, -0.390], 

4600 [0, -0.090, -0.192, -0.310, -0.447], 

4601 [0, -0.095, -0.208, -0.346, -0.508], 

4602 [0, -0.098, -0.223, -0.380, -0.576], 

4603 [0, -0.099, -0.237, -0.424, -0.652], 

4604 [0, -0.096, -0.250, -0.469, -0.742], 

4605 [0, -0.089, -0.262, -0.520, -0.853], 

4606 [0, -0.078, -0.272, -0.581, -0.997], 

4607 [0, -0.061, -0.279, -0.659, -1.198]] 

4608 

4609 psi_1 = interpolate.interp2d(nu_beta_range, nu_alpha_range, alpha_table, kind='linear') 

4610 psi_2 = interpolate.interp2d(nu_beta_range, nu_alpha_range, beta_table, kind='linear') 

4611 psi_2_1 = lambda nu_beta, nu_alpha: psi_2(nu_beta, nu_alpha) if nu_beta > 0 else -psi_2(-nu_beta, nu_alpha) 

4612 

4613 phi_3 = interpolate.interp2d(beta_range, alpha_range, nu_c_table, kind='linear') 

4614 phi_3_1 = lambda beta, alpha: phi_3(beta, alpha) if beta > 0 else phi_3(-beta, alpha) 

4615 phi_5 = interpolate.interp2d(beta_range, alpha_range, nu_zeta_table, kind='linear') 

4616 phi_5_1 = lambda beta, alpha: phi_5(beta, alpha) if beta > 0 else -phi_5(-beta, alpha) 

4617 

4618 # quantiles 

4619 p05 = np.percentile(data, 5) 

4620 p50 = np.percentile(data, 50) 

4621 p95 = np.percentile(data, 95) 

4622 p25 = np.percentile(data, 25) 

4623 p75 = np.percentile(data, 75) 

4624 

4625 nu_alpha = (p95 - p05)/(p75 - p25) 

4626 nu_beta = (p95 + p05 - 2*p50)/(p95 - p05) 

4627 

4628 if nu_alpha >= 2.439: 

4629 alpha = np.clip(psi_1(nu_beta, nu_alpha)[0], np.finfo(float).eps, 2.) 

4630 beta = np.clip(psi_2_1(nu_beta, nu_alpha)[0], -1., 1.) 

4631 else: 

4632 alpha = 2.0 

4633 beta = np.sign(nu_beta) 

4634 c = (p75 - p25) / phi_3_1(beta, alpha)[0] 

4635 zeta = p50 + c*phi_5_1(beta, alpha)[0] 

4636 delta = np.clip(zeta-beta*c*np.tan(np.pi*alpha/2.) if alpha == 1. else zeta, np.finfo(float).eps, np.inf) 

4637 

4638 return (alpha, beta, delta, c) 

4639 

4640 def _stats(self, alpha, beta): 

4641 mu = 0 if alpha > 1 else np.nan 

4642 mu2 = 2 if alpha == 2 else np.inf 

4643 g1 = 0. if alpha == 2. else np.NaN 

4644 g2 = 0. if alpha == 2. else np.NaN 

4645 return mu, mu2, g1, g2 

4646 

4647 

4648levy_stable = levy_stable_gen(name='levy_stable') 

4649 

4650 

4651class logistic_gen(rv_continuous): 

4652 r"""A logistic (or Sech-squared) continuous random variable. 

4653 

4654 %(before_notes)s 

4655 

4656 Notes 

4657 ----- 

4658 The probability density function for `logistic` is: 

4659 

4660 .. math:: 

4661 

4662 f(x) = \frac{\exp(-x)} 

4663 {(1+\exp(-x))^2} 

4664 

4665 `logistic` is a special case of `genlogistic` with ``c=1``. 

4666 

4667 %(after_notes)s 

4668 

4669 %(example)s 

4670 

4671 """ 

4672 def _rvs(self): 

4673 return self._random_state.logistic(size=self._size) 

4674 

4675 def _pdf(self, x): 

4676 # logistic.pdf(x) = exp(-x) / (1+exp(-x))**2 

4677 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x)) 

4678 

4679 def _logpdf(self, x): 

4680 return -x - 2. * sc.log1p(np.exp(-x)) 

4681 

4682 def _cdf(self, x): 

4683 return sc.expit(x) 

4684 

4685 def _ppf(self, q): 

4686 return sc.logit(q) 

4687 

4688 def _sf(self, x): 

4689 return sc.expit(-x) 

4690 

4691 def _isf(self, q): 

4692 return -sc.logit(q) 

4693 

4694 def _stats(self): 

4695 return 0, np.pi*np.pi/3.0, 0, 6.0/5.0 

4696 

4697 def _entropy(self): 

4698 # https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistic_distribution 

4699 return 2.0 

4700 

4701 

4702logistic = logistic_gen(name='logistic') 

4703 

4704 

4705class loggamma_gen(rv_continuous): 

4706 r"""A log gamma continuous random variable. 

4707 

4708 %(before_notes)s 

4709 

4710 Notes 

4711 ----- 

4712 The probability density function for `loggamma` is: 

4713 

4714 .. math:: 

4715 

4716 f(x, c) = \frac{\exp(c x - \exp(x))} 

4717 {\Gamma(c)} 

4718 

4719 for all :math:`x, c > 0`. Here, :math:`\Gamma` is the 

4720 gamma function (`scipy.special.gamma`). 

4721 

4722 `loggamma` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 

4723 

4724 %(after_notes)s 

4725 

4726 %(example)s 

4727 

4728 """ 

4729 def _rvs(self, c): 

4730 return np.log(self._random_state.gamma(c, size=self._size)) 

4731 

4732 def _pdf(self, x, c): 

4733 # loggamma.pdf(x, c) = exp(c*x-exp(x)) / gamma(c) 

4734 return np.exp(c*x-np.exp(x)-sc.gammaln(c)) 

4735 

4736 def _cdf(self, x, c): 

4737 return sc.gammainc(c, np.exp(x)) 

4738 

4739 def _ppf(self, q, c): 

4740 return np.log(sc.gammaincinv(c, q)) 

4741 

4742 def _stats(self, c): 

4743 # See, for example, "A Statistical Study of Log-Gamma Distribution", by 

4744 # Ping Shing Chan (thesis, McMaster University, 1993). 

4745 mean = sc.digamma(c) 

4746 var = sc.polygamma(1, c) 

4747 skewness = sc.polygamma(2, c) / np.power(var, 1.5) 

4748 excess_kurtosis = sc.polygamma(3, c) / (var*var) 

4749 return mean, var, skewness, excess_kurtosis 

4750 

4751 

4752loggamma = loggamma_gen(name='loggamma') 

4753 

4754 

4755class loglaplace_gen(rv_continuous): 

4756 r"""A log-Laplace continuous random variable. 

4757 

4758 %(before_notes)s 

4759 

4760 Notes 

4761 ----- 

4762 The probability density function for `loglaplace` is: 

4763 

4764 .. math:: 

4765 

4766 f(x, c) = \begin{cases}\frac{c}{2} x^{ c-1} &\text{for } 0 < x < 1\\ 

4767 \frac{c}{2} x^{-c-1} &\text{for } x \ge 1 

4768 \end{cases} 

4769 

4770 for :math:`c > 0`. 

4771 

4772 `loglaplace` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 

4773 

4774 %(after_notes)s 

4775 

4776 References 

4777 ---------- 

4778 T.J. Kozubowski and K. Podgorski, "A log-Laplace growth rate model", 

4779 The Mathematical Scientist, vol. 28, pp. 49-60, 2003. 

4780 

4781 %(example)s 

4782 

4783 """ 

4784 def _pdf(self, x, c): 

4785 # loglaplace.pdf(x, c) = c / 2 * x**(c-1), for 0 < x < 1 

4786 # = c / 2 * x**(-c-1), for x >= 1 

4787 cd2 = c/2.0 

4788 c = np.where(x < 1, c, -c) 

4789 return cd2*x**(c-1) 

4790 

4791 def _cdf(self, x, c): 

4792 return np.where(x < 1, 0.5*x**c, 1-0.5*x**(-c)) 

4793 

4794 def _ppf(self, q, c): 

4795 return np.where(q < 0.5, (2.0*q)**(1.0/c), (2*(1.0-q))**(-1.0/c)) 

4796 

4797 def _munp(self, n, c): 

4798 return c**2 / (c**2 - n**2) 

4799 

4800 def _entropy(self, c): 

4801 return np.log(2.0/c) + 1.0 

4802 

4803 

4804loglaplace = loglaplace_gen(a=0.0, name='loglaplace') 

4805 

4806 

4807def _lognorm_logpdf(x, s): 

4808 return _lazywhere(x != 0, (x, s), 

4809 lambda x, s: -np.log(x)**2 / (2*s**2) - np.log(s*x*np.sqrt(2*np.pi)), 

4810 -np.inf) 

4811 

4812 

4813class lognorm_gen(rv_continuous): 

4814 r"""A lognormal continuous random variable. 

4815 

4816 %(before_notes)s 

4817 

4818 Notes 

4819 ----- 

4820 The probability density function for `lognorm` is: 

4821 

4822 .. math:: 

4823 

4824 f(x, s) = \frac{1}{s x \sqrt{2\pi}} 

4825 \exp\left(-\frac{\log^2(x)}{2s^2}\right) 

4826 

4827 for :math:`x > 0`, :math:`s > 0`. 

4828 

4829 `lognorm` takes ``s`` as a shape parameter for :math:`s`. 

4830 

4831 %(after_notes)s 

4832 

4833 A common parametrization for a lognormal random variable ``Y`` is in 

4834 terms of the mean, ``mu``, and standard deviation, ``sigma``, of the 

4835 unique normally distributed random variable ``X`` such that exp(X) = Y. 

4836 This parametrization corresponds to setting ``s = sigma`` and ``scale = 

4837 exp(mu)``. 

4838 

4839 %(example)s 

4840 

4841 """ 

4842 _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask 

4843 

4844 def _rvs(self, s): 

4845 return np.exp(s * self._random_state.standard_normal(self._size)) 

4846 

4847 def _pdf(self, x, s): 

4848 # lognorm.pdf(x, s) = 1 / (s*x*sqrt(2*pi)) * exp(-1/2*(log(x)/s)**2) 

4849 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, s)) 

4850 

4851 def _logpdf(self, x, s): 

4852 return _lognorm_logpdf(x, s) 

4853 

4854 def _cdf(self, x, s): 

4855 return _norm_cdf(np.log(x) / s) 

4856 

4857 def _logcdf(self, x, s): 

4858 return _norm_logcdf(np.log(x) / s) 

4859 

4860 def _ppf(self, q, s): 

4861 return np.exp(s * _norm_ppf(q)) 

4862 

4863 def _sf(self, x, s): 

4864 return _norm_sf(np.log(x) / s) 

4865 

4866 def _logsf(self, x, s): 

4867 return _norm_logsf(np.log(x) / s) 

4868 

4869 def _stats(self, s): 

4870 p = np.exp(s*s) 

4871 mu = np.sqrt(p) 

4872 mu2 = p*(p-1) 

4873 g1 = np.sqrt((p-1))*(2+p) 

4874 g2 = np.polyval([1, 2, 3, 0, -6.0], p) 

4875 return mu, mu2, g1, g2 

4876 

4877 def _entropy(self, s): 

4878 return 0.5 * (1 + np.log(2*np.pi) + 2 * np.log(s)) 

4879 

4880 @extend_notes_in_docstring(rv_continuous, notes="""\ 

4881 When the location parameter is fixed by using the `floc` argument, 

4882 this function uses explicit formulas for the maximum likelihood 

4883 estimation of the log-normal shape and scale parameters, so the 

4884 `optimizer`, `loc` and `scale` keyword arguments are ignored.\n\n""") 

4885 def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds): 

4886 floc = kwds.get('floc', None) 

4887 if floc is None: 

4888 # loc is not fixed. Use the default fit method. 

4889 return super(lognorm_gen, self).fit(data, *args, **kwds) 

4890 

4891 f0 = (kwds.get('f0', None) or kwds.get('fs', None) or 

4892 kwds.get('fix_s', None)) 

4893 fscale = kwds.get('fscale', None) 

4894 

4895 if len(args) > 1: 

4896 raise TypeError("Too many input arguments.") 

4897 for name in ['f0', 'fs', 'fix_s', 'floc', 'fscale', 'loc', 'scale', 

4898 'optimizer']: 

4899 kwds.pop(name, None) 

4900 if kwds: 

4901 raise TypeError("Unknown arguments: %s." % kwds) 

4902 

4903 # Special case: loc is fixed. Use the maximum likelihood formulas 

4904 # instead of the numerical solver. 

4905 

4906 if f0 is not None and fscale is not None: 

4907 # This check is for consistency with `rv_continuous.fit`. 

4908 raise ValueError("All parameters fixed. There is nothing to " 

4909 "optimize.") 

4910 

4911 data = np.asarray(data) 

4912 

4913 if not np.isfinite(data).all(): 

4914 raise RuntimeError("The data contains non-finite values.") 

4915 

4916 floc = float(floc) 

4917 if floc != 0: 

4918 # Shifting the data by floc. Don't do the subtraction in-place, 

4919 # because `data` might be a view of the input array. 

4920 data = data - floc 

4921 if np.any(data <= 0): 

4922 raise FitDataError("lognorm", lower=floc, upper=np.inf) 

4923 lndata = np.log(data) 

4924 

4925 # Three cases to handle: 

4926 # * shape and scale both free 

4927 # * shape fixed, scale free 

4928 # * shape free, scale fixed 

4929 

4930 if fscale is None: 

4931 # scale is free. 

4932 scale = np.exp(lndata.mean()) 

4933 if f0 is None: 

4934 # shape is free. 

4935 shape = lndata.std() 

4936 else: 

4937 # shape is fixed. 

4938 shape = float(f0) 

4939 else: 

4940 # scale is fixed, shape is free 

4941 scale = float(fscale) 

4942 shape = np.sqrt(((lndata - np.log(scale))**2).mean()) 

4943 

4944 return shape, floc, scale 

4945 

4946 

4947lognorm = lognorm_gen(a=0.0, name='lognorm') 

4948 

4949 

4950class gilbrat_gen(rv_continuous): 

4951 r"""A Gilbrat continuous random variable. 

4952 

4953 %(before_notes)s 

4954 

4955 Notes 

4956 ----- 

4957 The probability density function for `gilbrat` is: 

4958 

4959 .. math:: 

4960 

4961 f(x) = \frac{1}{x \sqrt{2\pi}} \exp(-\frac{1}{2} (\log(x))^2) 

4962 

4963 `gilbrat` is a special case of `lognorm` with ``s=1``. 

4964 

4965 %(after_notes)s 

4966 

4967 %(example)s 

4968 

4969 """ 

4970 _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask 

4971 

4972 def _rvs(self): 

4973 return np.exp(self._random_state.standard_normal(self._size)) 

4974 

4975 def _pdf(self, x): 

4976 # gilbrat.pdf(x) = 1/(x*sqrt(2*pi)) * exp(-1/2*(log(x))**2) 

4977 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x)) 

4978 

4979 def _logpdf(self, x): 

4980 return _lognorm_logpdf(x, 1.0) 

4981 

4982 def _cdf(self, x): 

4983 return _norm_cdf(np.log(x)) 

4984 

4985 def _ppf(self, q): 

4986 return np.exp(_norm_ppf(q)) 

4987 

4988 def _stats(self): 

4989 p = np.e 

4990 mu = np.sqrt(p) 

4991 mu2 = p * (p - 1) 

4992 g1 = np.sqrt((p - 1)) * (2 + p) 

4993 g2 = np.polyval([1, 2, 3, 0, -6.0], p) 

4994 return mu, mu2, g1, g2 

4995 

4996 def _entropy(self): 

4997 return 0.5 * np.log(2 * np.pi) + 0.5 

4998 

4999 

5000gilbrat = gilbrat_gen(a=0.0, name='gilbrat') 

5001 

5002 

5003class maxwell_gen(rv_continuous): 

5004 r"""A Maxwell continuous random variable. 

5005 

5006 %(before_notes)s 

5007 

5008 Notes 

5009 ----- 

5010 A special case of a `chi` distribution, with ``df=3``, ``loc=0.0``, 

5011 and given ``scale = a``, where ``a`` is the parameter used in the 

5012 Mathworld description [1]_. 

5013 

5014 The probability density function for `maxwell` is: 

5015 

5016 .. math:: 

5017 

5018 f(x) = \sqrt{2/\pi}x^2 \exp(-x^2/2) 

5019 

5020 for :math:`x >= 0`. 

5021 

5022 %(after_notes)s 

5023 

5024 References 

5025 ---------- 

5026 .. [1] http://mathworld.wolfram.com/MaxwellDistribution.html 

5027 

5028 %(example)s 

5029 """ 

5030 def _rvs(self): 

5031 return chi.rvs(3.0, size=self._size, random_state=self._random_state) 

5032 

5033 def _pdf(self, x): 

5034 # maxwell.pdf(x) = sqrt(2/pi)x**2 * exp(-x**2/2) 

5035 return np.sqrt(2.0/np.pi)*x*x*np.exp(-x*x/2.0) 

5036 

5037 def _cdf(self, x): 

5038 return sc.gammainc(1.5, x*x/2.0) 

5039 

5040 def _ppf(self, q): 

5041 return np.sqrt(2*sc.gammaincinv(1.5, q)) 

5042 

5043 def _stats(self): 

5044 val = 3*np.pi-8 

5045 return (2*np.sqrt(2.0/np.pi), 

5046 3-8/np.pi, 

5047 np.sqrt(2)*(32-10*np.pi)/val**1.5, 

5048 (-12*np.pi*np.pi + 160*np.pi - 384) / val**2.0) 

5049 

5050 def _entropy(self): 

5051 return _EULER + 0.5*np.log(2*np.pi)-0.5 

5052 

5053 

5054maxwell = maxwell_gen(a=0.0, name='maxwell') 

5055 

5056 

5057class mielke_gen(rv_continuous): 

5058 r"""A Mielke Beta-Kappa / Dagum continuous random variable. 

5059 

5060 %(before_notes)s 

5061 

5062 Notes 

5063 ----- 

5064 The probability density function for `mielke` is: 

5065 

5066 .. math:: 

5067 

5068 f(x, k, s) = \frac{k x^{k-1}}{(1+x^s)^{1+k/s}} 

5069 

5070 for :math:`x > 0` and :math:`k, s > 0`. The distribution is sometimes 

5071 called Dagum distribution ([2]_). It was already defined in [3]_, called 

5072 a Burr Type III distribution (`burr` with parameters ``c=s`` and 

5073 ``d=k/s``). 

5074 

5075 `mielke` takes ``k`` and ``s`` as shape parameters. 

5076 

5077 %(after_notes)s 

5078 

5079 References 

5080 ---------- 

5081 .. [1] Mielke, P.W., 1973 "Another Family of Distributions for Describing 

5082 and Analyzing Precipitation Data." J. Appl. Meteor., 12, 275-280 

5083 .. [2] Dagum, C., 1977 "A new model for personal income distribution." 

5084 Economie Appliquee, 33, 327-367. 

5085 .. [3] Burr, I. W. "Cumulative frequency functions", Annals of 

5086 Mathematical Statistics, 13(2), pp 215-232 (1942). 

5087 

5088 %(example)s 

5089 

5090 """ 

5091 def _argcheck(self, k, s): 

5092 return (k > 0) & (s > 0) 

5093 

5094 def _pdf(self, x, k, s): 

5095 return k*x**(k-1.0) / (1.0+x**s)**(1.0+k*1.0/s) 

5096 

5097 def _logpdf(self, x, k, s): 

5098 return np.log(k) + np.log(x)*(k-1.0) - np.log1p(x**s)*(1.0+k*1.0/s) 

5099 

5100 def _cdf(self, x, k, s): 

5101 return x**k / (1.0+x**s)**(k*1.0/s) 

5102 

5103 def _ppf(self, q, k, s): 

5104 qsk = pow(q, s*1.0/k) 

5105 return pow(qsk/(1.0-qsk), 1.0/s) 

5106 

5107 def _munp(self, n, k, s): 

5108 def nth_moment(n, k, s): 

5109 # n-th moment is defined for -k < n < s 

5110 return sc.gamma((k+n)/s)*sc.gamma(1-n/s)/sc.gamma(k/s) 

5111 

5112 return _lazywhere(n < s, (n, k, s), nth_moment, np.inf) 

5113 

5114 

5115mielke = mielke_gen(a=0.0, name='mielke') 

5116 

5117 

5118class kappa4_gen(rv_continuous): 

5119 r"""Kappa 4 parameter distribution. 

5120 

5121 %(before_notes)s 

5122 

5123 Notes 

5124 ----- 

5125 The probability density function for kappa4 is: 

5126 

5127 .. math:: 

5128 

5129 f(x, h, k) = (1 - k x)^{1/k - 1} (1 - h (1 - k x)^{1/k})^{1/h-1} 

5130 

5131 if :math:`h` and :math:`k` are not equal to 0. 

5132 

5133 If :math:`h` or :math:`k` are zero then the pdf can be simplified: 

5134 

5135 h = 0 and k != 0:: 

5136 

5137 kappa4.pdf(x, h, k) = (1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k - 1.0)* 

5138 exp(-(1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k)) 

5139 

5140 h != 0 and k = 0:: 

5141 

5142 kappa4.pdf(x, h, k) = exp(-x)*(1.0 - h*exp(-x))**(1.0/h - 1.0) 

5143 

5144 h = 0 and k = 0:: 

5145 

5146 kappa4.pdf(x, h, k) = exp(-x)*exp(-exp(-x)) 

5147 

5148 kappa4 takes :math:`h` and :math:`k` as shape parameters. 

5149 

5150 The kappa4 distribution returns other distributions when certain 

5151 :math:`h` and :math:`k` values are used. 

5152 

5153 +------+-------------+----------------+------------------+ 

5154 | h | k=0.0 | k=1.0 | -inf<=k<=inf | 

5155 +======+=============+================+==================+ 

5156 | -1.0 | Logistic | | Generalized | 

5157 | | | | Logistic(1) | 

5158 | | | | | 

5159 | | logistic(x) | | | 

5160 +------+-------------+----------------+------------------+ 

5161 | 0.0 | Gumbel | Reverse | Generalized | 

5162 | | | Exponential(2) | Extreme Value | 

5163 | | | | | 

5164 | | gumbel_r(x) | | genextreme(x, k) | 

5165 +------+-------------+----------------+------------------+ 

5166 | 1.0 | Exponential | Uniform | Generalized | 

5167 | | | | Pareto | 

5168 | | | | | 

5169 | | expon(x) | uniform(x) | genpareto(x, -k) | 

5170 +------+-------------+----------------+------------------+ 

5171 

5172 (1) There are at least five generalized logistic distributions. 

5173 Four are described here: 

5174 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generalized_logistic_distribution 

5175 The "fifth" one is the one kappa4 should match which currently 

5176 isn't implemented in scipy: 

5177 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Generalized_logistic_distribution 

5178 https://www.mathwave.com/help/easyfit/html/analyses/distributions/gen_logistic.html 

5179 (2) This distribution is currently not in scipy. 

5180 

5181 References 

5182 ----------
