5183 J.C. Finney, "Optimization of a Skewed Logistic Distribution With Respect 

5184 to the Kolmogorov-Smirnov Test", A Dissertation Submitted to the Graduate 

5185 Faculty of the Louisiana State University and Agricultural and Mechanical 

5186 College, (August, 2004), 

5187 https://digitalcommons.lsu.edu/gradschool_dissertations/3672 

5188 

5189 J.R.M. Hosking, "The four-parameter kappa distribution". IBM J. Res. 

5190 Develop. 38 (3), 25 1-258 (1994). 

5191 

5192 B. Kumphon, A. Kaew-Man, P. Seenoi, "A Rainfall Distribution for the Lampao 

5193 Site in the Chi River Basin, Thailand", Journal of Water Resource and 

5194 Protection, vol. 4, 866-869, (2012). 

5195 https://doi.org/10.4236/jwarp.2012.410101 

5196 

5197 C. Winchester, "On Estimation of the Four-Parameter Kappa Distribution", A 

5198 Thesis Submitted to Dalhousie University, Halifax, Nova Scotia, (March 

5199 2000). 

5200 http://www.nlc-bnc.ca/obj/s4/f2/dsk2/ftp01/MQ57336.pdf 

5201 

5202 %(after_notes)s 

5203 

5204 %(example)s 

5205 

5206 """ 

5207 def _argcheck(self, h, k): 

5208 return h == h 

5209 

5210 def _get_support(self, h, k): 

5211 condlist = [np.logical_and(h > 0, k > 0), 

5212 np.logical_and(h > 0, k == 0), 

5213 np.logical_and(h > 0, k < 0), 

5214 np.logical_and(h <= 0, k > 0), 

5215 np.logical_and(h <= 0, k == 0), 

5216 np.logical_and(h <= 0, k < 0)] 

5217 

5218 def f0(h, k): 

5219 return (1.0 - float_power(h, -k))/k 

5220 

5221 def f1(h, k): 

5222 return np.log(h) 

5223 

5224 def f3(h, k): 

5225 a = np.empty(np.shape(h)) 

5226 a[:] = -np.inf 

5227 return a 

5228 

5229 def f5(h, k): 

5230 return 1.0/k 

5231 

5232 _a = _lazyselect(condlist, 

5233 [f0, f1, f0, f3, f3, f5], 

5234 [h, k], 

5235 default=np.nan) 

5236 

5237 def f0(h, k): 

5238 return 1.0/k 

5239 

5240 def f1(h, k): 

5241 a = np.empty(np.shape(h)) 

5242 a[:] = np.inf 

5243 return a 

5244 

5245 _b = _lazyselect(condlist, 

5246 [f0, f1, f1, f0, f1, f1], 

5247 [h, k], 

5248 default=np.nan) 

5249 return _a, _b 

5250 

5251 def _pdf(self, x, h, k): 

5252 # kappa4.pdf(x, h, k) = (1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k - 1.0)* 

5253 # (1.0 - h*(1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k))**(1.0/h-1) 

5254 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, h, k)) 

5255 

5256 def _logpdf(self, x, h, k): 

5257 condlist = [np.logical_and(h != 0, k != 0), 

5258 np.logical_and(h == 0, k != 0), 

5259 np.logical_and(h != 0, k == 0), 

5260 np.logical_and(h == 0, k == 0)] 

5261 

5262 def f0(x, h, k): 

5263 '''pdf = (1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k - 1.0)*( 

5264 1.0 - h*(1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k))**(1.0/h-1.0) 

5265 logpdf = ... 

5266 ''' 

5267 return (sc.xlog1py(1.0/k - 1.0, -k*x) + 

5268 sc.xlog1py(1.0/h - 1.0, -h*(1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k))) 

5269 

5270 def f1(x, h, k): 

5271 '''pdf = (1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k - 1.0)*np.exp(-( 

5272 1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k)) 

5273 logpdf = ... 

5274 ''' 

5275 return sc.xlog1py(1.0/k - 1.0, -k*x) - (1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k) 

5276 

5277 def f2(x, h, k): 

5278 '''pdf = np.exp(-x)*(1.0 - h*np.exp(-x))**(1.0/h - 1.0) 

5279 logpdf = ... 

5280 ''' 

5281 return -x + sc.xlog1py(1.0/h - 1.0, -h*np.exp(-x)) 

5282 

5283 def f3(x, h, k): 

5284 '''pdf = np.exp(-x-np.exp(-x)) 

5285 logpdf = ... 

5286 ''' 

5287 return -x - np.exp(-x) 

5288 

5289 return _lazyselect(condlist, 

5290 [f0, f1, f2, f3], 

5291 [x, h, k], 

5292 default=np.nan) 

5293 

5294 def _cdf(self, x, h, k): 

5295 return np.exp(self._logcdf(x, h, k)) 

5296 

5297 def _logcdf(self, x, h, k): 

5298 condlist = [np.logical_and(h != 0, k != 0), 

5299 np.logical_and(h == 0, k != 0), 

5300 np.logical_and(h != 0, k == 0), 

5301 np.logical_and(h == 0, k == 0)] 

5302 

5303 def f0(x, h, k): 

5304 '''cdf = (1.0 - h*(1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k))**(1.0/h) 

5305 logcdf = ... 

5306 ''' 

5307 return (1.0/h)*sc.log1p(-h*(1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k)) 

5308 

5309 def f1(x, h, k): 

5310 '''cdf = np.exp(-(1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k)) 

5311 logcdf = ... 

5312 ''' 

5313 return -(1.0 - k*x)**(1.0/k) 

5314 

5315 def f2(x, h, k): 

5316 '''cdf = (1.0 - h*np.exp(-x))**(1.0/h) 

5317 logcdf = ... 

5318 ''' 

5319 return (1.0/h)*sc.log1p(-h*np.exp(-x)) 

5320 

5321 def f3(x, h, k): 

5322 '''cdf = np.exp(-np.exp(-x)) 

5323 logcdf = ... 

5324 ''' 

5325 return -np.exp(-x) 

5326 

5327 return _lazyselect(condlist, 

5328 [f0, f1, f2, f3], 

5329 [x, h, k], 

5330 default=np.nan) 

5331 

5332 def _ppf(self, q, h, k): 

5333 condlist = [np.logical_and(h != 0, k != 0), 

5334 np.logical_and(h == 0, k != 0), 

5335 np.logical_and(h != 0, k == 0), 

5336 np.logical_and(h == 0, k == 0)] 

5337 

5338 def f0(q, h, k): 

5339 return 1.0/k*(1.0 - ((1.0 - (q**h))/h)**k) 

5340 

5341 def f1(q, h, k): 

5342 return 1.0/k*(1.0 - (-np.log(q))**k) 

5343 

5344 def f2(q, h, k): 

5345 '''ppf = -np.log((1.0 - (q**h))/h) 

5346 ''' 

5347 return -sc.log1p(-(q**h)) + np.log(h) 

5348 

5349 def f3(q, h, k): 

5350 return -np.log(-np.log(q)) 

5351 

5352 return _lazyselect(condlist, 

5353 [f0, f1, f2, f3], 

5354 [q, h, k], 

5355 default=np.nan) 

5356 

5357 def _stats(self, h, k): 

5358 if h >= 0 and k >= 0: 

5359 maxr = 5 

5360 elif h < 0 and k >= 0: 

5361 maxr = int(-1.0/h*k) 

5362 elif k < 0: 

5363 maxr = int(-1.0/k) 

5364 else: 

5365 maxr = 5 

5366 

5367 outputs = [None if r < maxr else np.nan for r in range(1, 5)] 

5368 return outputs[:] 

5369 

5370 

5371kappa4 = kappa4_gen(name='kappa4') 

5372 

5373 

5374class kappa3_gen(rv_continuous): 

5375 r"""Kappa 3 parameter distribution. 

5376 

5377 %(before_notes)s 

5378 

5379 Notes 

5380 ----- 

5381 The probability density function for `kappa3` is: 

5382 

5383 .. math:: 

5384 

5385 f(x, a) = a (a + x^a)^{-(a + 1)/a} 

5386 

5387 for :math:`x > 0` and :math:`a > 0`. 

5388 

5389 `kappa3` takes ``a`` as a shape parameter for :math:`a`. 

5390 

5391 References 

5392 ---------- 

5393 P.W. Mielke and E.S. Johnson, "Three-Parameter Kappa Distribution Maximum 

5394 Likelihood and Likelihood Ratio Tests", Methods in Weather Research, 

5395 701-707, (September, 1973), 

5396 https://doi.org/10.1175/1520-0493(1973)101<0701:TKDMLE>2.3.CO;2 

5397 

5398 B. Kumphon, "Maximum Entropy and Maximum Likelihood Estimation for the 

5399 Three-Parameter Kappa Distribution", Open Journal of Statistics, vol 2, 

5400 415-419 (2012), https://doi.org/10.4236/ojs.2012.24050 

5401 

5402 %(after_notes)s 

5403 

5404 %(example)s 

5405 

5406 """ 

5407 def _argcheck(self, a): 

5408 return a > 0 

5409 

5410 def _pdf(self, x, a): 

5411 # kappa3.pdf(x, a) = a*(a + x**a)**(-(a + 1)/a), for x > 0 

5412 return a*(a + x**a)**(-1.0/a-1) 

5413 

5414 def _cdf(self, x, a): 

5415 return x*(a + x**a)**(-1.0/a) 

5416 

5417 def _ppf(self, q, a): 

5418 return (a/(q**-a - 1.0))**(1.0/a) 

5419 

5420 def _stats(self, a): 

5421 outputs = [None if i < a else np.nan for i in range(1, 5)] 

5422 return outputs[:] 

5423 

5424 

5425kappa3 = kappa3_gen(a=0.0, name='kappa3') 

5426 

5427class moyal_gen(rv_continuous): 

5428 r"""A Moyal continuous random variable. 

5429 

5430 %(before_notes)s 

5431 

5432 Notes 

5433 ----- 

5434 The probability density function for `moyal` is: 

5435 

5436 .. math:: 

5437 

5438 f(x) = \exp(-(x + \exp(-x))/2) / \sqrt{2\pi} 

5439 

5440 for a real number :math:`x`. 

5441 

5442 %(after_notes)s 

5443 

5444 This distribution has utility in high-energy physics and radiation 

5445 detection. It describes the energy loss of a charged relativistic 

5446 particle due to ionization of the medium [1]_. It also provides an 

5447 approximation for the Landau distribution. For an in depth description 

5448 see [2]_. For additional description, see [3]_. 

5449 

5450 References 

5451 ---------- 

5452 .. [1] J.E. Moyal, "XXX. Theory of ionization fluctuations", 

5453 The London, Edinburgh, and Dublin Philosophical Magazine 

5454 and Journal of Science, vol 46, 263-280, (1955). 

5455 :doi:`10.1080/14786440308521076` (gated) 

5456 .. [2] G. Cordeiro et al., "The beta Moyal: a useful skew distribution", 

5457 International Journal of Research and Reviews in Applied Sciences, 

5458 vol 10, 171-192, (2012). 

5459 http://www.arpapress.com/Volumes/Vol10Issue2/IJRRAS_10_2_02.pdf 

5460 .. [3] C. Walck, "Handbook on Statistical Distributions for 

5461 Experimentalists; International Report SUF-PFY/96-01", Chapter 26, 

5462 University of Stockholm: Stockholm, Sweden, (2007). 

5463 http://www.stat.rice.edu/~dobelman/textfiles/DistributionsHandbook.pdf 

5464 

5465 .. versionadded:: 1.1.0 

5466 

5467 %(example)s 

5468 

5469 """ 

5470 def _rvs(self): 

5471 sz, rndm = self._size, self._random_state 

5472 u1 = gamma.rvs(a = 0.5, scale = 2, size=sz, random_state=rndm) 

5473 return -np.log(u1) 

5474 

5475 def _pdf(self, x): 

5476 return np.exp(-0.5 * (x + np.exp(-x))) / np.sqrt(2*np.pi) 

5477 

5478 def _cdf(self, x): 

5479 return sc.erfc(np.exp(-0.5 * x) / np.sqrt(2)) 

5480 

5481 def _sf(self, x): 

5482 return sc.erf(np.exp(-0.5 * x) / np.sqrt(2)) 

5483 

5484 def _ppf(self, x): 

5485 return -np.log(2 * sc.erfcinv(x)**2) 

5486 

5487 def _stats(self): 

5488 mu = np.log(2) + np.euler_gamma 

5489 mu2 = np.pi**2 / 2 

5490 g1 = 28 * np.sqrt(2) * sc.zeta(3) / np.pi**3 

5491 g2 = 4. 

5492 return mu, mu2, g1, g2 

5493 

5494 def _munp(self, n): 

5495 if n == 1.0: 

5496 return np.log(2) + np.euler_gamma 

5497 elif n == 2.0: 

5498 return np.pi**2 / 2 + (np.log(2) + np.euler_gamma)**2 

5499 elif n == 3.0: 

5500 tmp1 = 1.5 * np.pi**2 * (np.log(2)+np.euler_gamma) 

5501 tmp2 = (np.log(2)+np.euler_gamma)**3 

5502 tmp3 = 14 * sc.zeta(3) 

5503 return tmp1 + tmp2 + tmp3 

5504 elif n == 4.0: 

5505 tmp1 = 4 * 14 * sc.zeta(3) * (np.log(2) + np.euler_gamma) 

5506 tmp2 = 3 * np.pi**2 * (np.log(2) + np.euler_gamma)**2 

5507 tmp3 = (np.log(2) + np.euler_gamma)**4 

5508 tmp4 = 7 * np.pi**4 / 4 

5509 return tmp1 + tmp2 + tmp3 + tmp4 

5510 else: 

5511 # return generic for higher moments 

5512 # return rv_continuous._mom1_sc(self, n, b) 

5513 return self._mom1_sc(n) 

5514 

5515 

5516moyal = moyal_gen(name="moyal") 

5517 

5518 

5519class nakagami_gen(rv_continuous): 

5520 r"""A Nakagami continuous random variable. 

5521 

5522 %(before_notes)s 

5523 

5524 Notes 

5525 ----- 

5526 The probability density function for `nakagami` is: 

5527 

5528 .. math:: 

5529 

5530 f(x, \nu) = \frac{2 \nu^\nu}{\Gamma(\nu)} x^{2\nu-1} \exp(-\nu x^2) 

5531 

5532 for :math:`x >= 0`, :math:`\nu > 0`. 

5533 

5534 `nakagami` takes ``nu`` as a shape parameter for :math:`\nu`. 

5535 

5536 %(after_notes)s 

5537 

5538 %(example)s 

5539 

5540 """ 

5541 def _pdf(self, x, nu): 

5542 # nakagami.pdf(x, nu) = 2 * nu**nu / gamma(nu) * 

5543 # x**(2*nu-1) * exp(-nu*x**2) 

5544 return 2*nu**nu/sc.gamma(nu)*(x**(2*nu-1.0))*np.exp(-nu*x*x) 

5545 

5546 def _cdf(self, x, nu): 

5547 return sc.gammainc(nu, nu*x*x) 

5548 

5549 def _ppf(self, q, nu): 

5550 return np.sqrt(1.0/nu*sc.gammaincinv(nu, q)) 

5551 

5552 def _stats(self, nu): 

5553 mu = sc.gamma(nu+0.5)/sc.gamma(nu)/np.sqrt(nu) 

5554 mu2 = 1.0-mu*mu 

5555 g1 = mu * (1 - 4*nu*mu2) / 2.0 / nu / np.power(mu2, 1.5) 

5556 g2 = -6*mu**4*nu + (8*nu-2)*mu**2-2*nu + 1 

5557 g2 /= nu*mu2**2.0 

5558 return mu, mu2, g1, g2 

5559 

5560 

5561nakagami = nakagami_gen(a=0.0, name="nakagami") 

5562 

5563 

5564class ncx2_gen(rv_continuous): 

5565 r"""A non-central chi-squared continuous random variable. 

5566 

5567 %(before_notes)s 

5568 

5569 Notes 

5570 ----- 

5571 The probability density function for `ncx2` is: 

5572 

5573 .. math:: 

5574 

5575 f(x, k, \lambda) = \frac{1}{2} \exp(-(\lambda+x)/2) 

5576 (x/\lambda)^{(k-2)/4} I_{(k-2)/2}(\sqrt{\lambda x}) 

5577 

5578 for :math:`x >= 0` and :math:`k, \lambda > 0`. :math:`k` specifies the 

5579 degrees of freedom (denoted ``df`` in the implementation) and 

5580 :math:`\lambda` is the non-centrality parameter (denoted ``nc`` in the 

5581 implementation). :math:`I_\nu` denotes the modified Bessel function of 

5582 first order of degree :math:`\nu` (`scipy.special.iv`). 

5583 

5584 `ncx2` takes ``df`` and ``nc`` as shape parameters. 

5585 

5586 %(after_notes)s 

5587 

5588 %(example)s 

5589 

5590 """ 

5591 def _argcheck(self, df, nc): 

5592 return (df > 0) & (nc >= 0) 

5593 

5594 def _rvs(self, df, nc): 

5595 return self._random_state.noncentral_chisquare(df, nc, self._size) 

5596 

5597 def _logpdf(self, x, df, nc): 

5598 cond = np.ones_like(x, dtype=bool) & (nc != 0) 

5599 return _lazywhere(cond, (x, df, nc), f=_ncx2_log_pdf, f2=chi2.logpdf) 

5600 

5601 def _pdf(self, x, df, nc): 

5602 # ncx2.pdf(x, df, nc) = exp(-(nc+x)/2) * 1/2 * (x/nc)**((df-2)/4) 

5603 # * I[(df-2)/2](sqrt(nc*x)) 

5604 cond = np.ones_like(x, dtype=bool) & (nc != 0) 

5605 return _lazywhere(cond, (x, df, nc), f=_ncx2_pdf, f2=chi2.pdf) 

5606 

5607 def _cdf(self, x, df, nc): 

5608 cond = np.ones_like(x, dtype=bool) & (nc != 0) 

5609 return _lazywhere(cond, (x, df, nc), f=_ncx2_cdf, f2=chi2.cdf) 

5610 

5611 def _ppf(self, q, df, nc): 

5612 cond = np.ones_like(q, dtype=bool) & (nc != 0) 

5613 return _lazywhere(cond, (q, df, nc), f=sc.chndtrix, f2=chi2.ppf) 

5614 

5615 def _stats(self, df, nc): 

5616 val = df + 2.0*nc 

5617 return (df + nc, 

5618 2*val, 

5619 np.sqrt(8)*(val+nc)/val**1.5, 

5620 12.0*(val+2*nc)/val**2.0) 

5621 

5622 

5623ncx2 = ncx2_gen(a=0.0, name='ncx2') 

5624 

5625 

5626class ncf_gen(rv_continuous): 

5627 r"""A non-central F distribution continuous random variable. 

5628 

5629 %(before_notes)s 

5630 

5631 Notes 

5632 ----- 

5633 The probability density function for `ncf` is: 

5634 

5635 .. math:: 

5636 

5637 f(x, n_1, n_2, \lambda) = 

5638 \exp(\frac{\lambda}{2} + \lambda n_1 \frac{x}{2(n_1 x+n_2)}) 

5639 n_1^{n_1/2} n_2^{n_2/2} x^{n_1/2 - 1} \\ 

5640 (n_2+n_1 x)^{-(n_1+n_2)/2} 

5641 \gamma(n_1/2) \gamma(1+n_2/2) \\ 

5642 \frac{L^{\frac{v_1}{2}-1}_{v_2/2} 

5643 (-\lambda v_1 \frac{x}{2(v_1 x+v_2)})} 

5644 {B(v_1/2, v_2/2) \gamma(\frac{v_1+v_2}{2})} 

5645 

5646 for :math:`n_1 > 1`, :math:`n_2, \lambda > 0`. Here :math:`n_1` is the 

5647 degrees of freedom in the numerator, :math:`n_2` the degrees of freedom in 

5648 the denominator, :math:`\lambda` the non-centrality parameter, 

5649 :math:`\gamma` is the logarithm of the Gamma function, :math:`L_n^k` is a 

5650 generalized Laguerre polynomial and :math:`B` is the beta function. 

5651 

5652 `ncf` takes ``df1``, ``df2`` and ``nc`` as shape parameters. 

5653 

5654 %(after_notes)s 

5655 

5656 %(example)s 

5657 

5658 """ 

5659 def _rvs(self, dfn, dfd, nc): 

5660 return self._random_state.noncentral_f(dfn, dfd, nc, self._size) 

5661 

5662 def _pdf_skip(self, x, dfn, dfd, nc): 

5663 # ncf.pdf(x, df1, df2, nc) = exp(nc/2 + nc*df1*x/(2*(df1*x+df2))) * 

5664 # df1**(df1/2) * df2**(df2/2) * x**(df1/2-1) * 

5665 # (df2+df1*x)**(-(df1+df2)/2) * 

5666 # gamma(df1/2)*gamma(1+df2/2) * 

5667 # L^{v1/2-1}^{v2/2}(-nc*v1*x/(2*(v1*x+v2))) / 

5668 # (B(v1/2, v2/2) * gamma((v1+v2)/2)) 

5669 n1, n2 = dfn, dfd 

5670 term = -nc/2+nc*n1*x/(2*(n2+n1*x)) + sc.gammaln(n1/2.)+sc.gammaln(1+n2/2.) 

5671 term -= sc.gammaln((n1+n2)/2.0) 

5672 Px = np.exp(term) 

5673 Px *= n1**(n1/2) * n2**(n2/2) * x**(n1/2-1) 

5674 Px *= (n2+n1*x)**(-(n1+n2)/2) 

5675 Px *= sc.assoc_laguerre(-nc*n1*x/(2.0*(n2+n1*x)), n2/2, n1/2-1) 

5676 Px /= sc.beta(n1/2, n2/2) 

5677 # This function does not have a return. Drop it for now, the generic 

5678 # function seems to work OK. 

5679 

5680 def _cdf(self, x, dfn, dfd, nc): 

5681 return sc.ncfdtr(dfn, dfd, nc, x) 

5682 

5683 def _ppf(self, q, dfn, dfd, nc): 

5684 return sc.ncfdtri(dfn, dfd, nc, q) 

5685 

5686 def _munp(self, n, dfn, dfd, nc): 

5687 val = (dfn * 1.0/dfd)**n 

5688 term = sc.gammaln(n+0.5*dfn) + sc.gammaln(0.5*dfd-n) - sc.gammaln(dfd*0.5) 

5689 val *= np.exp(-nc / 2.0+term) 

5690 val *= sc.hyp1f1(n+0.5*dfn, 0.5*dfn, 0.5*nc) 

5691 return val 

5692 

5693 def _stats(self, dfn, dfd, nc): 

5694 # Note: the rv_continuous class ensures that dfn > 0 when this function 

5695 # is called, so we don't have to check for division by zero with dfn 

5696 # in the following. 

5697 mu_num = dfd * (dfn + nc) 

5698 mu_den = dfn * (dfd - 2) 

5699 mu = np.full_like(mu_num, dtype=np.float64, fill_value=np.inf) 

5700 np.true_divide(mu_num, mu_den, where=dfd > 2, out=mu) 

5701 

5702 mu2_num = 2*((dfn + nc)**2 + (dfn + 2*nc)*(dfd - 2))*(dfd/dfn)**2 

5703 mu2_den = (dfd - 2)**2 * (dfd - 4) 

5704 mu2 = np.full_like(mu2_num, dtype=np.float64, fill_value=np.inf) 

5705 np.true_divide(mu2_num, mu2_den, where=dfd > 4, out=mu2) 

5706 

5707 return mu, mu2, None, None 

5708 

5709 

5710ncf = ncf_gen(a=0.0, name='ncf') 

5711 

5712 

5713class t_gen(rv_continuous): 

5714 r"""A Student's t continuous random variable. 

5715 

5716 %(before_notes)s 

5717 

5718 Notes 

5719 ----- 

5720 The probability density function for `t` is: 

5721 

5722 .. math:: 

5723 

5724 f(x, \nu) = \frac{\Gamma((\nu+1)/2)} 

5725 {\sqrt{\pi \nu} \Gamma(\nu/2)} 

5726 (1+x^2/\nu)^{-(\nu+1)/2} 

5727 

5728 where :math:`x` is a real number and the degrees of freedom parameter 

5729 :math:`\nu` (denoted ``df`` in the implementation) satisfies 

5730 :math:`\nu > 0`. :math:`\Gamma` is the gamma function 

5731 (`scipy.special.gamma`). 

5732 

5733 %(after_notes)s 

5734 

5735 %(example)s 

5736 

5737 """ 

5738 def _argcheck(self, df): 

5739 return df > 0 

5740 

5741 def _rvs(self, df): 

5742 return self._random_state.standard_t(df, size=self._size) 

5743 

5744 def _pdf(self, x, df): 

5745 # gamma((df+1)/2) 

5746 # t.pdf(x, df) = --------------------------------------------------- 

5747 # sqrt(pi*df) * gamma(df/2) * (1+x**2/df)**((df+1)/2) 

5748 r = np.asarray(df*1.0) 

5749 Px = np.exp(sc.gammaln((r+1)/2)-sc.gammaln(r/2)) 

5750 Px /= np.sqrt(r*np.pi)*(1+(x**2)/r)**((r+1)/2) 

5751 return Px 

5752 

5753 def _logpdf(self, x, df): 

5754 r = df*1.0 

5755 lPx = sc.gammaln((r+1)/2)-sc.gammaln(r/2) 

5756 lPx -= 0.5*np.log(r*np.pi) + (r+1)/2*np.log(1+(x**2)/r) 

5757 return lPx 

5758 

5759 def _cdf(self, x, df): 

5760 return sc.stdtr(df, x) 

5761 

5762 def _sf(self, x, df): 

5763 return sc.stdtr(df, -x) 

5764 

5765 def _ppf(self, q, df): 

5766 return sc.stdtrit(df, q) 

5767 

5768 def _isf(self, q, df): 

5769 return -sc.stdtrit(df, q) 

5770 

5771 def _stats(self, df): 

5772 mu = np.where(df > 1, 0.0, np.inf) 

5773 mu2 = _lazywhere(df > 2, (df,), 

5774 lambda df: df / (df-2.0), 

5775 np.inf) 

5776 mu2 = np.where(df <= 1, np.nan, mu2) 

5777 g1 = np.where(df > 3, 0.0, np.nan) 

5778 g2 = _lazywhere(df > 4, (df,), 

5779 lambda df: 6.0 / (df-4.0), 

5780 np.inf) 

5781 g2 = np.where(df <= 2, np.nan, g2) 

5782 return mu, mu2, g1, g2 

5783 

5784 

5785t = t_gen(name='t') 

5786 

5787 

5788class nct_gen(rv_continuous): 

5789 r"""A non-central Student's t continuous random variable. 

5790 

5791 %(before_notes)s 

5792 

5793 Notes 

5794 ----- 

5795 If :math:`Y` is a standard normal random variable and :math:`V` is 

5796 an independent chi-square random variable (`chi2`) with :math:`k` degrees 

5797 of freedom, then 

5798 

5799 .. math:: 

5800 

5801 X = \frac{Y + c}{\sqrt{V/k}} 

5802 

5803 has a non-central Student's t distribution on the real line. 

5804 The degrees of freedom parameter :math:`k` (denoted ``df`` in the 

5805 implementation) satisfies :math:`k > 0` and the noncentrality parameter 

5806 :math:`c` (denoted ``nc`` in the implementation) is a real number. 

5807 

5808 %(after_notes)s 

5809 

5810 %(example)s 

5811 

5812 """ 

5813 def _argcheck(self, df, nc): 

5814 return (df > 0) & (nc == nc) 

5815 

5816 def _rvs(self, df, nc): 

5817 sz, rndm = self._size, self._random_state 

5818 n = norm.rvs(loc=nc, size=sz, random_state=rndm) 

5819 c2 = chi2.rvs(df, size=sz, random_state=rndm) 

5820 return n * np.sqrt(df) / np.sqrt(c2) 

5821 

5822 def _pdf(self, x, df, nc): 

5823 n = df*1.0 

5824 nc = nc*1.0 

5825 x2 = x*x 

5826 ncx2 = nc*nc*x2 

5827 fac1 = n + x2 

5828 trm1 = n/2.*np.log(n) + sc.gammaln(n+1) 

5829 trm1 -= n*np.log(2)+nc*nc/2.+(n/2.)*np.log(fac1)+sc.gammaln(n/2.) 

5830 Px = np.exp(trm1) 

5831 valF = ncx2 / (2*fac1) 

5832 trm1 = np.sqrt(2)*nc*x*sc.hyp1f1(n/2+1, 1.5, valF) 

5833 trm1 /= np.asarray(fac1*sc.gamma((n+1)/2)) 

5834 trm2 = sc.hyp1f1((n+1)/2, 0.5, valF) 

5835 trm2 /= np.asarray(np.sqrt(fac1)*sc.gamma(n/2+1)) 

5836 Px *= trm1+trm2 

5837 return Px 

5838 

5839 def _cdf(self, x, df, nc): 

5840 return sc.nctdtr(df, nc, x) 

5841 

5842 def _ppf(self, q, df, nc): 

5843 return sc.nctdtrit(df, nc, q) 

5844 

5845 def _stats(self, df, nc, moments='mv'): 

5846 # 

5847 # See D. Hogben, R.S. Pinkham, and M.B. Wilk, 

5848 # 'The moments of the non-central t-distribution' 

5849 # Biometrika 48, p. 465 (2961). 

5850 # e.g. https://www.jstor.org/stable/2332772 (gated) 

5851 # 

5852 mu, mu2, g1, g2 = None, None, None, None 

5853 

5854 gfac = sc.gamma(df/2.-0.5) / sc.gamma(df/2.) 

5855 c11 = np.sqrt(df/2.) * gfac 

5856 c20 = df / (df-2.) 

5857 c22 = c20 - c11*c11 

5858 mu = np.where(df > 1, nc*c11, np.inf) 

5859 mu2 = np.where(df > 2, c22*nc*nc + c20, np.inf) 

5860 if 's' in moments: 

5861 c33t = df * (7.-2.*df) / (df-2.) / (df-3.) + 2.*c11*c11 

5862 c31t = 3.*df / (df-2.) / (df-3.) 

5863 mu3 = (c33t*nc*nc + c31t) * c11*nc 

5864 g1 = np.where(df > 3, mu3 / np.power(mu2, 1.5), np.nan) 

5865 # kurtosis 

5866 if 'k' in moments: 

5867 c44 = df*df / (df-2.) / (df-4.) 

5868 c44 -= c11*c11 * 2.*df*(5.-df) / (df-2.) / (df-3.) 

5869 c44 -= 3.*c11**4 

5870 c42 = df / (df-4.) - c11*c11 * (df-1.) / (df-3.) 

5871 c42 *= 6.*df / (df-2.) 

5872 c40 = 3.*df*df / (df-2.) / (df-4.) 

5873 

5874 mu4 = c44 * nc**4 + c42*nc**2 + c40 

5875 g2 = np.where(df > 4, mu4/mu2**2 - 3., np.nan) 

5876 return mu, mu2, g1, g2 

5877 

5878 

5879nct = nct_gen(name="nct") 

5880 

5881 

5882class pareto_gen(rv_continuous): 

5883 r"""A Pareto continuous random variable. 

5884 

5885 %(before_notes)s 

5886 

5887 Notes 

5888 ----- 

5889 The probability density function for `pareto` is: 

5890 

5891 .. math:: 

5892 

5893 f(x, b) = \frac{b}{x^{b+1}} 

5894 

5895 for :math:`x \ge 1`, :math:`b > 0`. 

5896 

5897 `pareto` takes ``b`` as a shape parameter for :math:`b`. 

5898 

5899 %(after_notes)s 

5900 

5901 %(example)s 

5902 

5903 """ 

5904 def _pdf(self, x, b): 

5905 # pareto.pdf(x, b) = b / x**(b+1) 

5906 return b * x**(-b-1) 

5907 

5908 def _cdf(self, x, b): 

5909 return 1 - x**(-b) 

5910 

5911 def _ppf(self, q, b): 

5912 return pow(1-q, -1.0/b) 

5913 

5914 def _sf(self, x, b): 

5915 return x**(-b) 

5916 

5917 def _stats(self, b, moments='mv'): 

5918 mu, mu2, g1, g2 = None, None, None, None 

5919 if 'm' in moments: 

5920 mask = b > 1 

5921 bt = np.extract(mask, b) 

5922 mu = valarray(np.shape(b), value=np.inf) 

5923 np.place(mu, mask, bt / (bt-1.0)) 

5924 if 'v' in moments: 

5925 mask = b > 2 

5926 bt = np.extract(mask, b) 

5927 mu2 = valarray(np.shape(b), value=np.inf) 

5928 np.place(mu2, mask, bt / (bt-2.0) / (bt-1.0)**2) 

5929 if 's' in moments: 

5930 mask = b > 3 

5931 bt = np.extract(mask, b) 

5932 g1 = valarray(np.shape(b), value=np.nan) 

5933 vals = 2 * (bt + 1.0) * np.sqrt(bt - 2.0) / ((bt - 3.0) * np.sqrt(bt)) 

5934 np.place(g1, mask, vals) 

5935 if 'k' in moments: 

5936 mask = b > 4 

5937 bt = np.extract(mask, b) 

5938 g2 = valarray(np.shape(b), value=np.nan) 

5939 vals = (6.0*np.polyval([1.0, 1.0, -6, -2], bt) / 

5940 np.polyval([1.0, -7.0, 12.0, 0.0], bt)) 

5941 np.place(g2, mask, vals) 

5942 return mu, mu2, g1, g2 

5943 

5944 def _entropy(self, c): 

5945 return 1 + 1.0/c - np.log(c) 

5946 

5947 

5948pareto = pareto_gen(a=1.0, name="pareto") 

5949 

5950 

5951class lomax_gen(rv_continuous): 

5952 r"""A Lomax (Pareto of the second kind) continuous random variable. 

5953 

5954 %(before_notes)s 

5955 

5956 Notes 

5957 ----- 

5958 The probability density function for `lomax` is: 

5959 

5960 .. math:: 

5961 

5962 f(x, c) = \frac{c}{(1+x)^{c+1}} 

5963 

5964 for :math:`x \ge 0`, :math:`c > 0`. 

5965 

5966 `lomax` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 

5967 

5968 `lomax` is a special case of `pareto` with ``loc=-1.0``. 

5969 

5970 %(after_notes)s 

5971 

5972 %(example)s 

5973 

5974 """ 

5975 def _pdf(self, x, c): 

5976 # lomax.pdf(x, c) = c / (1+x)**(c+1) 

5977 return c*1.0/(1.0+x)**(c+1.0) 

5978 

5979 def _logpdf(self, x, c): 

5980 return np.log(c) - (c+1)*sc.log1p(x) 

5981 

5982 def _cdf(self, x, c): 

5983 return -sc.expm1(-c*sc.log1p(x)) 

5984 

5985 def _sf(self, x, c): 

5986 return np.exp(-c*sc.log1p(x)) 

5987 

5988 def _logsf(self, x, c): 

5989 return -c*sc.log1p(x) 

5990 

5991 def _ppf(self, q, c): 

5992 return sc.expm1(-sc.log1p(-q)/c) 

5993 

5994 def _stats(self, c): 

5995 mu, mu2, g1, g2 = pareto.stats(c, loc=-1.0, moments='mvsk') 

5996 return mu, mu2, g1, g2 

5997 

5998 def _entropy(self, c): 

5999 return 1+1.0/c-np.log(c) 

6000 

6001 

6002lomax = lomax_gen(a=0.0, name="lomax") 

6003 

6004 

6005class pearson3_gen(rv_continuous): 

6006 r"""A pearson type III continuous random variable. 

6007 

6008 %(before_notes)s 

6009 

6010 Notes 

6011 ----- 

6012 The probability density function for `pearson3` is: 

6013 

6014 .. math:: 

6015 

6016 f(x, skew) = \frac{|\beta|}{\Gamma(\alpha)} 

6017 (\beta (x - \zeta))^{\alpha - 1} 

6018 \exp(-\beta (x - \zeta)) 

6019 

6020 where: 

6021 

6022 .. math:: 

6023 

6024 \beta = \frac{2}{skew stddev} 

6025 \alpha = (stddev \beta)^2 

6026 \zeta = loc - \frac{\alpha}{\beta} 

6027 

6028 :math:`\Gamma` is the gamma function (`scipy.special.gamma`). 

6029 `pearson3` takes ``skew`` as a shape parameter for :math:`skew`. 

6030 

6031 %(after_notes)s 

6032 

6033 %(example)s 

6034 

6035 References 

6036 ---------- 

6037 R.W. Vogel and D.E. McMartin, "Probability Plot Goodness-of-Fit and 

6038 Skewness Estimation Procedures for the Pearson Type 3 Distribution", Water 

6039 Resources Research, Vol.27, 3149-3158 (1991). 

6040 

6041 L.R. Salvosa, "Tables of Pearson's Type III Function", Ann. Math. Statist., 

6042 Vol.1, 191-198 (1930). 

6043 

6044 "Using Modern Computing Tools to Fit the Pearson Type III Distribution to 

6045 Aviation Loads Data", Office of Aviation Research (2003). 

6046 

6047 """ 

6048 def _preprocess(self, x, skew): 

6049 # The real 'loc' and 'scale' are handled in the calling pdf(...). The 

6050 # local variables 'loc' and 'scale' within pearson3._pdf are set to 

6051 # the defaults just to keep them as part of the equations for 

6052 # documentation. 

6053 loc = 0.0 

6054 scale = 1.0 

6055 

6056 # If skew is small, return _norm_pdf. The divide between pearson3 

6057 # and norm was found by brute force and is approximately a skew of 

6058 # 0.000016. No one, I hope, would actually use a skew value even 

6059 # close to this small. 

6060 norm2pearson_transition = 0.000016 

6061 

6062 ans, x, skew = np.broadcast_arrays([1.0], x, skew) 

6063 ans = ans.copy() 

6064 

6065 # mask is True where skew is small enough to use the normal approx. 

6066 mask = np.absolute(skew) < norm2pearson_transition 

6067 invmask = ~mask 

6068 

6069 beta = 2.0 / (skew[invmask] * scale) 

6070 alpha = (scale * beta)**2 

6071 zeta = loc - alpha / beta 

6072 

6073 transx = beta * (x[invmask] - zeta) 

6074 return ans, x, transx, mask, invmask, beta, alpha, zeta 

6075 

6076 def _argcheck(self, skew): 

6077 # The _argcheck function in rv_continuous only allows positive 

6078 # arguments. The skew argument for pearson3 can be zero (which I want 

6079 # to handle inside pearson3._pdf) or negative. So just return True 

6080 # for all skew args. 

6081 return np.ones(np.shape(skew), dtype=bool) 

6082 

6083 def _stats(self, skew): 

6084 _, _, _, _, _, beta, alpha, zeta = ( 

6085 self._preprocess([1], skew)) 

6086 m = zeta + alpha / beta 

6087 v = alpha / (beta**2) 

6088 s = 2.0 / (alpha**0.5) * np.sign(beta) 

6089 k = 6.0 / alpha 

6090 return m, v, s, k 

6091 

6092 def _pdf(self, x, skew): 

6093 # pearson3.pdf(x, skew) = abs(beta) / gamma(alpha) * 

6094 # (beta * (x - zeta))**(alpha - 1) * exp(-beta*(x - zeta)) 

6095 # Do the calculation in _logpdf since helps to limit 

6096 # overflow/underflow problems 

6097 ans = np.exp(self._logpdf(x, skew)) 

6098 if ans.ndim == 0: 

6099 if np.isnan(ans): 

6100 return 0.0 

6101 return ans 

6102 ans[np.isnan(ans)] = 0.0 

6103 return ans 

6104 

6105 def _logpdf(self, x, skew): 

6106 # PEARSON3 logpdf GAMMA logpdf 

6107 # np.log(abs(beta)) 

6108 # + (alpha - 1)*np.log(beta*(x - zeta)) + (a - 1)*np.log(x) 

6109 # - beta*(x - zeta) - x 

6110 # - sc.gammalnalpha) - sc.gammalna) 

6111 ans, x, transx, mask, invmask, beta, alpha, _ = ( 

6112 self._preprocess(x, skew)) 

6113 

6114 ans[mask] = np.log(_norm_pdf(x[mask])) 

6115 ans[invmask] = np.log(abs(beta)) + gamma._logpdf(transx, alpha) 

6116 return ans 

6117 

6118 def _cdf(self, x, skew): 

6119 ans, x, transx, mask, invmask, _, alpha, _ = ( 

6120 self._preprocess(x, skew)) 

6121 

6122 ans[mask] = _norm_cdf(x[mask]) 

6123 ans[invmask] = gamma._cdf(transx, alpha) 

6124 return ans 

6125 

6126 def _rvs(self, skew): 

6127 skew = broadcast_to(skew, self._size) 

6128 ans, _, _, mask, invmask, beta, alpha, zeta = ( 

6129 self._preprocess([0], skew)) 

6130 

6131 nsmall = mask.sum() 

6132 nbig = mask.size - nsmall 

6133 ans[mask] = self._random_state.standard_normal(nsmall) 

6134 ans[invmask] = (self._random_state.standard_gamma(alpha, nbig)/beta + 

6135 zeta) 

6136 

6137 if self._size == (): 

6138 ans = ans[0] 

6139 return ans 

6140 

6141 def _ppf(self, q, skew): 

6142 ans, q, _, mask, invmask, beta, alpha, zeta = ( 

6143 self._preprocess(q, skew)) 

6144 ans[mask] = _norm_ppf(q[mask]) 

6145 ans[invmask] = sc.gammaincinv(alpha, q[invmask])/beta + zeta 

6146 return ans 

6147 

6148 

6149pearson3 = pearson3_gen(name="pearson3") 

6150 

6151 

6152class powerlaw_gen(rv_continuous): 

6153 r"""A power-function continuous random variable. 

6154 

6155 %(before_notes)s 

6156 

6157 Notes 

6158 ----- 

6159 The probability density function for `powerlaw` is: 

6160 

6161 .. math:: 

6162 

6163 f(x, a) = a x^{a-1} 

6164 

6165 for :math:`0 \le x \le 1`, :math:`a > 0`. 

6166 

6167 `powerlaw` takes ``a`` as a shape parameter for :math:`a`. 

6168 

6169 %(after_notes)s 

6170 

6171 `powerlaw` is a special case of `beta` with ``b=1``. 

6172 

6173 %(example)s 

6174 

6175 """ 

6176 def _pdf(self, x, a): 

6177 # powerlaw.pdf(x, a) = a * x**(a-1) 

6178 return a*x**(a-1.0) 

6179 

6180 def _logpdf(self, x, a): 

6181 return np.log(a) + sc.xlogy(a - 1, x) 

6182 

6183 def _cdf(self, x, a): 

6184 return x**(a*1.0) 

6185 

6186 def _logcdf(self, x, a): 

6187 return a*np.log(x) 

6188 

6189 def _ppf(self, q, a): 

6190 return pow(q, 1.0/a) 

6191 

6192 def _stats(self, a): 

6193 return (a / (a + 1.0), 

6194 a / (a + 2.0) / (a + 1.0) ** 2, 

6195 -2.0 * ((a - 1.0) / (a + 3.0)) * np.sqrt((a + 2.0) / a), 

6196 6 * np.polyval([1, -1, -6, 2], a) / (a * (a + 3.0) * (a + 4))) 

6197 

6198 def _entropy(self, a): 

6199 return 1 - 1.0/a - np.log(a) 

6200 

6201 

6202powerlaw = powerlaw_gen(a=0.0, b=1.0, name="powerlaw") 

6203 

6204 

6205class powerlognorm_gen(rv_continuous): 

6206 r"""A power log-normal continuous random variable. 

6207 

6208 %(before_notes)s 

6209 

6210 Notes 

6211 ----- 

6212 The probability density function for `powerlognorm` is: 

6213 

6214 .. math:: 

6215 

6216 f(x, c, s) = \frac{c}{x s} \phi(\log(x)/s) 

6217 (\Phi(-\log(x)/s))^{c-1} 

6218 

6219 where :math:`\phi` is the normal pdf, and :math:`\Phi` is the normal cdf, 

6220 and :math:`x > 0`, :math:`s, c > 0`. 

6221 

6222 `powerlognorm` takes :math:`c` and :math:`s` as shape parameters. 

6223 

6224 %(after_notes)s 

6225 

6226 %(example)s 

6227 

6228 """ 

6229 _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask 

6230 

6231 def _pdf(self, x, c, s): 

6232 # powerlognorm.pdf(x, c, s) = c / (x*s) * phi(log(x)/s) * 

6233 # (Phi(-log(x)/s))**(c-1), 

6234 return (c/(x*s) * _norm_pdf(np.log(x)/s) * 

6235 pow(_norm_cdf(-np.log(x)/s), c*1.0-1.0)) 

6236 

6237 def _cdf(self, x, c, s): 

6238 return 1.0 - pow(_norm_cdf(-np.log(x)/s), c*1.0) 

6239 

6240 def _ppf(self, q, c, s): 

6241 return np.exp(-s * _norm_ppf(pow(1.0 - q, 1.0 / c))) 

6242 

6243 

6244powerlognorm = powerlognorm_gen(a=0.0, name="powerlognorm") 

6245 

6246 

6247class powernorm_gen(rv_continuous): 

6248 r"""A power normal continuous random variable. 

6249 

6250 %(before_notes)s 

6251 

6252 Notes 

6253 ----- 

6254 The probability density function for `powernorm` is: 

6255 

6256 .. math:: 

6257 

6258 f(x, c) = c \phi(x) (\Phi(-x))^{c-1} 

6259 

6260 where :math:`\phi` is the normal pdf, and :math:`\Phi` is the normal cdf, 

6261 and :math:`x >= 0`, :math:`c > 0`. 

6262 

6263 `powernorm` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 

6264 

6265 %(after_notes)s 

6266 

6267 %(example)s 

6268 

6269 """ 

6270 def _pdf(self, x, c): 

6271 # powernorm.pdf(x, c) = c * phi(x) * (Phi(-x))**(c-1) 

6272 return c*_norm_pdf(x) * (_norm_cdf(-x)**(c-1.0)) 

6273 

6274 def _logpdf(self, x, c): 

6275 return np.log(c) + _norm_logpdf(x) + (c-1)*_norm_logcdf(-x) 

6276 

6277 def _cdf(self, x, c): 

6278 return 1.0-_norm_cdf(-x)**(c*1.0) 

6279 

6280 def _ppf(self, q, c): 

6281 return -_norm_ppf(pow(1.0 - q, 1.0 / c)) 

6282 

6283 

6284powernorm = powernorm_gen(name='powernorm') 

6285 

6286 

6287class rdist_gen(rv_continuous): 

6288 r"""An R-distributed (symmetric beta) continuous random variable. 

6289 

6290 %(before_notes)s 

6291 

6292 Notes 

6293 ----- 

6294 The probability density function for `rdist` is: 

6295 

6296 .. math:: 

6297 

6298 f(x, c) = \frac{(1-x^2)^{c/2-1}}{B(1/2, c/2)} 

6299 

6300 for :math:`-1 \le x \le 1`, :math:`c > 0`. `rdist` is also called the 

6301 symmetric beta distribution: if B has a `beta` distribution with 

6302 parameters (c/2, c/2), then X = 2*B - 1 follows a R-distribution with 

6303 parameter c. 

6304 

6305 `rdist` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 

6306 

6307 This distribution includes the following distribution kernels as 

6308 special cases:: 

6309 

6310 c = 2: uniform 

6311 c = 3: `semicircular` 

6312 c = 4: Epanechnikov (parabolic) 

6313 c = 6: quartic (biweight) 

6314 c = 8: triweight 

6315 

6316 %(after_notes)s 

6317 

6318 %(example)s 

6319 

6320 """ 

6321 # use relation to the beta distribution for pdf, cdf, etc 

6322 def _pdf(self, x, c): 

6323 return 0.5*beta._pdf((x + 1)/2, c/2, c/2) 

6324 

6325 def _logpdf(self, x, c): 

6326 return -np.log(2) + beta._logpdf((x + 1)/2, c/2, c/2) 

6327 

6328 def _cdf(self, x, c): 

6329 return beta._cdf((x + 1)/2, c/2, c/2) 

6330 

6331 def _ppf(self, q, c): 

6332 return 2*beta._ppf(q, c/2, c/2) - 1 

6333 

6334 def _rvs(self, c): 

6335 return 2 * self._random_state.beta(c/2, c/2, self._size) - 1 

6336 

6337 def _munp(self, n, c): 

6338 numerator = (1 - (n % 2)) * sc.beta((n + 1.0) / 2, c / 2.0) 

6339 return numerator / sc.beta(1. / 2, c / 2.) 

6340 

6341 

6342rdist = rdist_gen(a=-1.0, b=1.0, name="rdist") 

6343 

6344 

6345class rayleigh_gen(rv_continuous): 

6346 r"""A Rayleigh continuous random variable. 

6347 

6348 %(before_notes)s 

6349 

6350 Notes 

6351 ----- 

6352 The probability density function for `rayleigh` is: 

6353 

6354 .. math:: 

6355 

6356 f(x) = x \exp(-x^2/2) 

6357 

6358 for :math:`x \ge 0`. 

6359 

6360 `rayleigh` is a special case of `chi` with ``df=2``. 

6361 

6362 %(after_notes)s 

6363 

6364 %(example)s 

6365 

6366 """ 

6367 _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask 

6368 

6369 def _rvs(self): 

6370 return chi.rvs(2, size=self._size, random_state=self._random_state) 

6371 

6372 def _pdf(self, r): 

6373 # rayleigh.pdf(r) = r * exp(-r**2/2) 

6374 return np.exp(self._logpdf(r)) 

6375 

6376 def _logpdf(self, r): 

6377 return np.log(r) - 0.5 * r * r 

6378 

6379 def _cdf(self, r): 

6380 return -sc.expm1(-0.5 * r**2) 

6381 

6382 def _ppf(self, q): 

6383 return np.sqrt(-2 * sc.log1p(-q)) 

6384 

6385 def _sf(self, r): 

6386 return np.exp(self._logsf(r)) 

6387 

6388 def _logsf(self, r): 

6389 return -0.5 * r * r 

6390 

6391 def _isf(self, q): 

6392 return np.sqrt(-2 * np.log(q)) 

6393 

6394 def _stats(self): 

6395 val = 4 - np.pi 

6396 return (np.sqrt(np.pi/2), 

6397 val/2, 

6398 2*(np.pi-3)*np.sqrt(np.pi)/val**1.5, 

6399 6*np.pi/val-16/val**2) 

6400 

6401 def _entropy(self): 

6402 return _EULER/2.0 + 1 - 0.5*np.log(2) 

6403 

6404 

6405rayleigh = rayleigh_gen(a=0.0, name="rayleigh") 

6406 

6407 

6408class reciprocal_gen(rv_continuous): 

6409 r"""A loguniform or reciprocal continuous random variable. 

6410 

6411 %(before_notes)s 

6412 

6413 Notes 

6414 ----- 

6415 The probability density function for this class is: 

6416 

6417 .. math:: 

6418 

6419 f(x, a, b) = \frac{1}{x \log(b/a)} 

6420 

6421 for :math:`a \le x \le b`, :math:`b > a > 0`. This class takes 

6422 :math:`a` and :math:`b` as shape parameters. %(after_notes)s 

6423 

6424 %(example)s 

6425 

6426 This doesn't show the equal probability of ``0.01``, ``0.1`` and 

6427 ``1``. This is best when the x-axis is log-scaled: 

6428 

6429 >>> import numpy as np 

6430 >>> fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1) 

6431 >>> ax.hist(np.log10(r)) 

6432 >>> ax.set_ylabel("Frequency") 

6433 >>> ax.set_xlabel("Value of random variable") 

6434 >>> ax.xaxis.set_major_locator(plt.FixedLocator([-2, -1, 0])) 

6435 >>> ticks = ["$10^{{ {} }}$".format(i) for i in [-2, -1, 0]] 

6436 >>> ax.set_xticklabels(ticks) # doctest: +SKIP 

6437 >>> plt.show() 

6438 

6439 This random variable will be log-uniform regardless of the base chosen for 

6440 ``a`` and ``b``. Let's specify with base ``2`` instead: 

6441 

6442 >>> rvs = %(name)s(2**-2, 2**0).rvs(size=1000) 

6443 

6444 Values of ``1/4``, ``1/2`` and ``1`` are equally likely with this random 

6445 variable. Here's the histogram: 

6446 

6447 >>> fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1) 

6448 >>> ax.hist(np.log2(rvs)) 

6449 >>> ax.set_ylabel("Frequency") 

6450 >>> ax.set_xlabel("Value of random variable") 

6451 >>> ax.xaxis.set_major_locator(plt.FixedLocator([-2, -1, 0])) 

6452 >>> ticks = ["$2^{{ {} }}$".format(i) for i in [-2, -1, 0]] 

6453 >>> ax.set_xticklabels(ticks) # doctest: +SKIP 

6454 >>> plt.show() 

6455 

6456 """ 

6457 def _argcheck(self, a, b): 

6458 return (a > 0) & (b > a) 

6459 

6460 def _get_support(self, a, b): 

6461 return a, b 

6462 

6463 def _pdf(self, x, a, b): 

6464 # reciprocal.pdf(x, a, b) = 1 / (x*log(b/a)) 

6465 return 1.0 / (x * np.log(b * 1.0 / a)) 

6466 

6467 def _logpdf(self, x, a, b): 

6468 return -np.log(x) - np.log(np.log(b * 1.0 / a)) 

6469 

6470 def _cdf(self, x, a, b): 

6471 return (np.log(x)-np.log(a)) / np.log(b * 1.0 / a) 

6472 

6473 def _ppf(self, q, a, b): 

6474 return a*pow(b*1.0/a, q) 

6475 

6476 def _munp(self, n, a, b): 

6477 return 1.0/np.log(b*1.0/a) / n * (pow(b*1.0, n) - pow(a*1.0, n)) 

6478 

6479 def _entropy(self, a, b): 

6480 return 0.5*np.log(a*b)+np.log(np.log(b*1.0/a)) 

6481 

6482 

6483loguniform = reciprocal_gen(name="loguniform") 

6484reciprocal = reciprocal_gen(name="reciprocal") 

6485 

6486 

6487class rice_gen(rv_continuous): 

6488 r"""A Rice continuous random variable. 

6489 

6490 %(before_notes)s 

6491 

6492 Notes 

6493 ----- 

6494 The probability density function for `rice` is: 

6495 

6496 .. math:: 

6497 

6498 f(x, b) = x \exp(- \frac{x^2 + b^2}{2}) I_0(x b) 

6499 

6500 for :math:`x >= 0`, :math:`b > 0`. :math:`I_0` is the modified Bessel 

6501 function of order zero (`scipy.special.i0`). 

6502 

6503 `rice` takes ``b`` as a shape parameter for :math:`b`. 

6504 

6505 %(after_notes)s 

6506 

6507 The Rice distribution describes the length, :math:`r`, of a 2-D vector with 

6508 components :math:`(U+u, V+v)`, where :math:`U, V` are constant, :math:`u, 

6509 v` are independent Gaussian random variables with standard deviation 

6510 :math:`s`. Let :math:`R = \sqrt{U^2 + V^2}`. Then the pdf of :math:`r` is 

6511 ``rice.pdf(x, R/s, scale=s)``. 

6512 

6513 %(example)s 

6514 

6515 """ 

6516 def _argcheck(self, b): 

6517 return b >= 0 

6518 

6519 def _rvs(self, b): 

6520 # https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rice_distribution 

6521 t = b/np.sqrt(2) + self._random_state.standard_normal(size=(2,) + 

6522 self._size) 

6523 return np.sqrt((t*t).sum(axis=0)) 

6524 

6525 def _cdf(self, x, b): 

6526 return sc.chndtr(np.square(x), 2, np.square(b)) 

6527 

6528 def _ppf(self, q, b): 

6529 return np.sqrt(sc.chndtrix(q, 2, np.square(b))) 

6530 

6531 def _pdf(self, x, b): 

6532 # rice.pdf(x, b) = x * exp(-(x**2+b**2)/2) * I[0](x*b) 

6533 # 

6534 # We use (x**2 + b**2)/2 = ((x-b)**2)/2 + xb. 

6535 # The factor of np.exp(-xb) is then included in the i0e function 

6536 # in place of the modified Bessel function, i0, improving 

6537 # numerical stability for large values of xb. 

6538 return x * np.exp(-(x-b)*(x-b)/2.0) * sc.i0e(x*b) 

6539 

6540 def _munp(self, n, b): 

6541 nd2 = n/2.0 

6542 n1 = 1 + nd2 

6543 b2 = b*b/2.0 

6544 return (2.0**(nd2) * np.exp(-b2) * sc.gamma(n1) * 

6545 sc.hyp1f1(n1, 1, b2)) 

6546 

6547 

6548rice = rice_gen(a=0.0, name="rice") 

6549 

6550 

6551# FIXME: PPF does not work. 

6552class recipinvgauss_gen(rv_continuous): 

6553 r"""A reciprocal inverse Gaussian continuous random variable. 

6554 

6555 %(before_notes)s 

6556 

6557 Notes 

6558 ----- 

6559 The probability density function for `recipinvgauss` is: 

6560 

6561 .. math:: 

6562 

6563 f(x, \mu) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi x}} 

6564 \exp\left(\frac{-(1-\mu x)^2}{2\mu^2x}\right) 

6565 

6566 for :math:`x \ge 0`. 

6567 

6568 `recipinvgauss` takes ``mu`` as a shape parameter for :math:`\mu`. 

6569 

6570 %(after_notes)s 

6571 

6572 %(example)s 

6573 

6574 """ 

6575 

6576 def _pdf(self, x, mu): 

6577 # recipinvgauss.pdf(x, mu) = 

6578 # 1/sqrt(2*pi*x) * exp(-(1-mu*x)**2/(2*x*mu**2)) 

6579 return 1.0/np.sqrt(2*np.pi*x)*np.exp(-(1-mu*x)**2.0 / (2*x*mu**2.0)) 

6580 

6581 def _logpdf(self, x, mu): 

6582 return -(1-mu*x)**2.0 / (2*x*mu**2.0) - 0.5*np.log(2*np.pi*x) 

6583 

6584 def _cdf(self, x, mu): 

6585 trm1 = 1.0/mu - x 

6586 trm2 = 1.0/mu + x 

6587 isqx = 1.0/np.sqrt(x) 

6588 return 1.0-_norm_cdf(isqx*trm1)-np.exp(2.0/mu)*_norm_cdf(-isqx*trm2) 

6589 

6590 def _rvs(self, mu): 

6591 return 1.0/self._random_state.wald(mu, 1.0, size=self._size) 

6592 

6593 

6594recipinvgauss = recipinvgauss_gen(a=0.0, name='recipinvgauss') 

6595 

6596 

6597class semicircular_gen(rv_continuous): 

6598 r"""A semicircular continuous random variable. 

6599 

6600 %(before_notes)s 

6601 

6602 Notes 

6603 ----- 

6604 The probability density function for `semicircular` is: 

6605 

6606 .. math:: 

6607 

6608 f(x) = \frac{2}{\pi} \sqrt{1-x^2} 

6609 

6610 for :math:`-1 \le x \le 1`. 

6611 

6612 The distribution is a special case of `rdist` with `c = 3`. 

6613 

6614 %(after_notes)s 

6615 

6616 See Also 

6617 -------- 

6618 rdist 

6619 

6620 References 

6621 ---------- 

6622 .. [1] "Wigner semicircle distribution", 

6623 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wigner_semicircle_distribution 

6624 

6625 %(example)s 

6626 

6627 """ 

6628 def _pdf(self, x): 

6629 return 2.0/np.pi*np.sqrt(1-x*x) 

6630 

6631 def _logpdf(self, x): 

6632 return np.log(2/np.pi) + 0.5*np.log1p(-x*x) 

6633 

6634 def _cdf(self, x): 

6635 return 0.5+1.0/np.pi*(x*np.sqrt(1-x*x) + np.arcsin(x)) 

6636 

6637 def _ppf(self, q): 

6638 return rdist._ppf(q, 3) 

6639 

6640 def _rvs(self): 

6641 # generate values uniformly distributed on the area under the pdf 

6642 # (semi-circle) by randomly generating the radius and angle 

6643 r = np.sqrt(self._random_state.random_sample(size=self._size)) 

6644 a = np.cos(np.pi * self._random_state.random_sample(size=self._size)) 

6645 return r * a 

6646 

6647 def _stats(self): 

6648 return 0, 0.25, 0, -1.0 

6649 

6650 def _entropy(self): 

6651 return 0.64472988584940017414 

6652 

6653 

6654semicircular = semicircular_gen(a=-1.0, b=1.0, name="semicircular") 

6655 

6656 

6657class skew_norm_gen(rv_continuous): 

6658 r"""A skew-normal random variable. 

6659 

6660 %(before_notes)s 

6661 

6662 Notes 

6663 ----- 

6664 The pdf is:: 

6665 

6666 skewnorm.pdf(x, a) = 2 * norm.pdf(x) * norm.cdf(a*x) 

6667 

6668 `skewnorm` takes a real number :math:`a` as a skewness parameter 

6669 When ``a = 0`` the distribution is identical to a normal distribution 

6670 (`norm`). `rvs` implements the method of [1]_. 

6671 

6672 %(after_notes)s 

6673 

6674 %(example)s 

6675 

6676 References 

6677 ---------- 

6678 .. [1] A. Azzalini and A. Capitanio (1999). Statistical applications of the 

6679 multivariate skew-normal distribution. J. Roy. Statist. Soc., B 61, 579-602. 

6680 https://arxiv.org/abs/0911.2093 

6681 

6682 """ 

6683 def _argcheck(self, a): 

6684 return np.isfinite(a) 

6685 

6686 def _pdf(self, x, a): 

6687 return 2.*_norm_pdf(x)*_norm_cdf(a*x) 

6688 

6689 def _cdf_single(self, x, *args): 

6690 _a, _b = self._get_support(*args) 

6691 if x <= 0: 

6692 cdf = integrate.quad(self._pdf, _a, x, args=args)[0] 

6693 else: 

6694 t1 = integrate.quad(self._pdf, _a, 0, args=args)[0] 

6695 t2 = integrate.quad(self._pdf, 0, x, args=args)[0] 

6696 cdf = t1 + t2 

6697 if cdf > 1: 

6698 # Presumably numerical noise, e.g. 1.0000000000000002 

6699 cdf = 1.0 

6700 return cdf 

6701 

6702 def _sf(self, x, a): 

6703 return self._cdf(-x, -a) 

6704 

6705 def _rvs(self, a): 

6706 u0 = self._random_state.normal(size=self._size) 

6707 v = self._random_state.normal(size=self._size) 

6708 d = a/np.sqrt(1 + a**2) 

6709 u1 = d*u0 + v*np.sqrt(1 - d**2) 

6710 return np.where(u0 >= 0, u1, -u1) 

6711 

6712 def _stats(self, a, moments='mvsk'): 

6713 output = [None, None, None, None] 

6714 const = np.sqrt(2/np.pi) * a/np.sqrt(1 + a**2) 

6715 

6716 if 'm' in moments: 

6717 output[0] = const 

6718 if 'v' in moments: 

6719 output[1] = 1 - const**2 

6720 if 's' in moments: 

6721 output[2] = ((4 - np.pi)/2) * (const/np.sqrt(1 - const**2))**3 

6722 if 'k' in moments: 

6723 output[3] = (2*(np.pi - 3)) * (const**4/(1 - const**2)**2) 

6724 

6725 return output 

6726 

6727 

6728skewnorm = skew_norm_gen(name='skewnorm') 

6729 

6730 

6731class trapz_gen(rv_continuous): 

6732 r"""A trapezoidal continuous random variable. 

6733 

6734 %(before_notes)s 

6735 

6736 Notes 

6737 ----- 

6738 The trapezoidal distribution can be represented with an up-sloping line 

6739 from ``loc`` to ``(loc + c*scale)``, then constant to ``(loc + d*scale)`` 

6740 and then downsloping from ``(loc + d*scale)`` to ``(loc+scale)``. 

6741 

6742 `trapz` takes :math:`c` and :math:`d` as shape parameters. 

6743 

6744 %(after_notes)s 

6745 

6746 The standard form is in the range [0, 1] with c the mode. 

6747 The location parameter shifts the start to `loc`. 

6748 The scale parameter changes the width from 1 to `scale`. 

6749 

6750 %(example)s 

6751 

6752 """ 

6753 def _argcheck(self, c, d): 

6754 return (c >= 0) & (c <= 1) & (d >= 0) & (d <= 1) & (d >= c) 

6755 

6756 def _pdf(self, x, c, d): 

6757 u = 2 / (d-c+1) 

6758 

6759 return _lazyselect([x < c, 

6760 (c <= x) & (x <= d), 

6761 x > d], 

6762 [lambda x, c, d, u: u * x / c, 

6763 lambda x, c, d, u: u, 

6764 lambda x, c, d, u: u * (1-x) / (1-d)], 

6765 (x, c, d, u)) 

6766 

6767 def _cdf(self, x, c, d): 

6768 return _lazyselect([x < c, 

6769 (c <= x) & (x <= d), 

6770 x > d], 

6771 [lambda x, c, d: x**2 / c / (d-c+1), 

6772 lambda x, c, d: (c + 2 * (x-c)) / (d-c+1), 

6773 lambda x, c, d: 1-((1-x) ** 2 

6774 / (d-c+1) / (1-d))], 

6775 (x, c, d)) 

6776 

6777 def _ppf(self, q, c, d): 

6778 qc, qd = self._cdf(c, c, d), self._cdf(d, c, d) 

6779 condlist = [q < qc, q <= qd, q > qd] 

6780 choicelist = [np.sqrt(q * c * (1 + d - c)), 

6781 0.5 * q * (1 + d - c) + 0.5 * c, 

6782 1 - np.sqrt((1 - q) * (d - c + 1) * (1 - d))] 

6783 return np.select(condlist, choicelist) 

6784 

6785 

6786trapz = trapz_gen(a=0.0, b=1.0, name="trapz") 

6787 

6788 

6789class triang_gen(rv_continuous): 

6790 r"""A triangular continuous random variable. 

6791 

6792 %(before_notes)s 

6793 

6794 Notes 

6795 ----- 

6796 The triangular distribution can be represented with an up-sloping line from 

6797 ``loc`` to ``(loc + c*scale)`` and then downsloping for ``(loc + c*scale)`` 

6798 to ``(loc + scale)``. 

6799 

6800 `triang` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 

6801 

6802 %(after_notes)s 

6803 

6804 The standard form is in the range [0, 1] with c the mode. 

6805 The location parameter shifts the start to `loc`. 

6806 The scale parameter changes the width from 1 to `scale`. 

6807 

6808 %(example)s 

6809 

6810 """ 

6811 def _rvs(self, c): 

6812 return self._random_state.triangular(0, c, 1, self._size) 

6813 

6814 def _argcheck(self, c): 

6815 return (c >= 0) & (c <= 1) 

6816 

6817 def _pdf(self, x, c): 

6818 # 0: edge case where c=0 

6819 # 1: generalised case for x < c, don't use x <= c, as it doesn't cope 

6820 # with c = 0. 

6821 # 2: generalised case for x >= c, but doesn't cope with c = 1 

6822 # 3: edge case where c=1 

6823 r = _lazyselect([c == 0, 

6824 x < c, 

6825 (x >= c) & (c != 1), 

6826 c == 1], 

6827 [lambda x, c: 2 - 2 * x, 

6828 lambda x, c: 2 * x / c, 

6829 lambda x, c: 2 * (1 - x) / (1 - c), 

6830 lambda x, c: 2 * x], 

6831 (x, c)) 

6832 return r 

6833 

6834 def _cdf(self, x, c): 

6835 r = _lazyselect([c == 0, 

6836 x < c, 

6837 (x >= c) & (c != 1), 

6838 c == 1], 

6839 [lambda x, c: 2*x - x*x, 

6840 lambda x, c: x * x / c, 

6841 lambda x, c: (x*x - 2*x + c) / (c-1), 

6842 lambda x, c: x * x], 

6843 (x, c)) 

6844 return r 

6845 

6846 def _ppf(self, q, c): 

6847 return np.where(q < c, np.sqrt(c * q), 1-np.sqrt((1-c) * (1-q))) 

6848 

6849 def _stats(self, c): 

6850 return ((c+1.0)/3.0, 

6851 (1.0-c+c*c)/18, 

6852 np.sqrt(2)*(2*c-1)*(c+1)*(c-2) / (5*np.power((1.0-c+c*c), 1.5)), 

6853 -3.0/5.0) 

6854 

6855 def _entropy(self, c): 

6856 return 0.5-np.log(2) 

6857 

6858 

6859triang = triang_gen(a=0.0, b=1.0, name="triang") 

6860 

6861 

6862class truncexpon_gen(rv_continuous): 

6863 r"""A truncated exponential continuous random variable. 

6864 

6865 %(before_notes)s 

6866 

6867 Notes 

6868 ----- 

6869 The probability density function for `truncexpon` is: 

6870 

6871 .. math:: 

6872 

6873 f(x, b) = \frac{\exp(-x)}{1 - \exp(-b)} 

6874 

6875 for :math:`0 <= x <= b`. 

6876 

6877 `truncexpon` takes ``b`` as a shape parameter for :math:`b`. 

6878 

6879 %(after_notes)s 

6880 

6881 %(example)s 

6882 

6883 """ 

6884 def _argcheck(self, b): 

6885 return b > 0 

6886 

6887 def _get_support(self, b): 

6888 return self.a, b 

6889 

6890 def _pdf(self, x, b): 

6891 # truncexpon.pdf(x, b) = exp(-x) / (1-exp(-b)) 

6892 return np.exp(-x)/(-sc.expm1(-b)) 

6893 

6894 def _logpdf(self, x, b): 

6895 return -x - np.log(-sc.expm1(-b)) 

6896 

6897 def _cdf(self, x, b): 

6898 return sc.expm1(-x)/sc.expm1(-b) 

6899 

6900 def _ppf(self, q, b): 

6901 return -sc.log1p(q*sc.expm1(-b)) 

6902 

6903 def _munp(self, n, b): 

6904 # wrong answer with formula, same as in continuous.pdf 

6905 # return sc.gamman+1)-sc.gammainc1+n, b) 

6906 if n == 1: 

6907 return (1-(b+1)*np.exp(-b))/(-sc.expm1(-b)) 

6908 elif n == 2: 

6909 return 2*(1-0.5*(b*b+2*b+2)*np.exp(-b))/(-sc.expm1(-b)) 

6910 else: 

6911 # return generic for higher moments 

6912 # return rv_continuous._mom1_sc(self, n, b) 

6913 return self._mom1_sc(n, b) 

6914 

6915 def _entropy(self, b): 

6916 eB = np.exp(b) 

6917 return np.log(eB-1)+(1+eB*(b-1.0))/(1.0-eB) 

6918 

6919 

6920truncexpon = truncexpon_gen(a=0.0, name='truncexpon') 

6921 

6922 

6923TRUNCNORM_TAIL_X = 30 

6924TRUNCNORM_MAX_BRENT_ITERS = 40 

6925 

6926# Want np.vectorize(f, otypes=['float']) which doesn't decorate well. 

6927def _vectorize(**kwargs): 

6928 def vectorize_decorator(f): 

6929 vf = np.vectorize(f, **kwargs) 

6930 

6931 @functools.wraps(f) 

6932 def vf_wrapper(*args): 

6933 return vf(*args) 

6934 return vf_wrapper 

6935 return vectorize_decorator 

6936 

6937 

6938def _truncnorm_get_delta(a, b): 

6939 if (a > TRUNCNORM_TAIL_X) or (b < -TRUNCNORM_TAIL_X): 

6940 return 0 

6941 if a > 0: 

6942 delta = _norm_cdf(b) - _norm_cdf(a) 

6943 else: 

6944 delta = _norm_sf(a) - _norm_sf(b) 

6945 delta = max(delta, 0) 

6946 return delta 

6947 

6948 

6949def _truncnorm_get_logdelta(a, b): 

6950 if (a <= TRUNCNORM_TAIL_X) and (b >= -TRUNCNORM_TAIL_X): 

6951 if a > 0: 

6952 delta = _norm_cdf(b) - _norm_cdf(a) 

6953 else: 

6954 delta = _norm_sf(a) - _norm_sf(b) 

6955 delta = max(delta, 0) 

6956 if delta > 0: 

6957 return np.log(delta) 

6958 

6959 if b < 0 or (np.abs(a) >= np.abs(b)): 

6960 nla = _norm_logcdf(a) 

6961 nlb = _norm_logcdf(b) 

6962 logdelta = nlb + np.log1p(-np.exp(nla - nlb)) 

6963 else: 

6964 sla = _norm_logsf(a) 

6965 slb = _norm_logsf(b) 

6966 logdelta = sla + np.log1p(-np.exp(slb - sla)) 

6967 return logdelta 

6968 

6969 

6970@_vectorize(otypes=['float']) 

6971def _truncnorm_logpdf(x, a, b): 

6972 _logdelta = _truncnorm_get_logdelta(a, b) 

6973 return _norm_logpdf(x) - _logdelta 

6974 

6975 

6976@_vectorize(otypes=['float']) 

6977def _truncnorm_pdf(x, a, b): 

6978 delta = _truncnorm_get_delta(a, b) 

6979 if delta > 0: 

6980 return _norm_pdf(x) / delta 

6981 return np.exp(_truncnorm_logpdf(x, a, b)) 

6982 

6983 

6984@_vectorize(otypes=['float']) 

6985def _truncnorm_logcdf(x, a, b): 

6986 delta = _truncnorm_get_delta(a, b) 

6987 if delta > 0: 

6988 return np.log((_norm_cdf(x) - _norm_cdf(a)) / delta) 

6989 if x <= a: 

6990 return -np.inf 

6991 if x >= b: 

6992 return 0.0 

6993 if a < 0: 

6994 with np.errstate(divide='ignore'): 

6995 nla = _norm_logcdf(a) 

6996 nlb = _norm_logcdf(b) 

6997 tab = np.log1p(-np.exp(nla - nlb)) 

6998 nlx = _norm_logcdf(x) 

6999 tax = np.log1p(-np.exp(nla - nlx)) 

7000 return nlx + tax - (nlb + tab) 

7001 with np.errstate(divide='ignore'): 

7002 sla = _norm_logsf(a) 

7003 slb = _norm_logsf(b) 

7004 return (np.log1p(-np.exp(_norm_logsf(x) - sla)) 

7005 - np.log1p(-np.exp(slb - sla))) 

7006 

7007 

7008@_vectorize(otypes=['float']) 

7009def _truncnorm_cdf(x, a, b): 

7010 delta = _truncnorm_get_delta(a, b) 

7011 if delta > 0: 

7012 return (_norm_cdf(x) - _norm_cdf(a)) / delta 

7013 return np.exp(_truncnorm_logcdf(x, a, b)) 

7014 

7015 

7016@_vectorize(otypes=['float']) 

7017def _truncnorm_logsf(x, a, b): 

7018 delta = _truncnorm_get_delta(a, b) 

7019 if delta > 0: 

7020 return np.log((_norm_sf(x) - _norm_sf(b)) / delta) 

7021 if x <= a: 

7022 return 0 

7023 if x >= b: 

7024 return -np.inf 

7025 if b < 0: 

7026 with np.errstate(divide='ignore'): 

7027 nla = _norm_logcdf(a) 

7028 nlb = _norm_logcdf(b) 

7029 return (np.log1p(-np.exp(_norm_logcdf(x) - nlb)) 

7030 - np.log1p(-np.exp(nla - nlb))) 

7031 with np.errstate(divide='ignore'): 

7032 sla = _norm_logsf(a) 

7033 slb = _norm_logsf(b) 

7034 tab = np.log1p(-np.exp(slb - sla)) 

7035 slx = _norm_logsf(x) 

7036 tax = np.log1p(-np.exp(slb - slx)) 

7037 return slx + tax - (sla + tab) 

7038 

7039 

7040@_vectorize(otypes=['float']) 

7041def _truncnorm_sf(x, a, b): 

7042 delta = _truncnorm_get_delta(a, b) 

7043 if delta > 0: 

7044 return (_norm_sf(x) - _norm_sf(b)) / delta 

7045 return np.exp(_truncnorm_logsf(x, a, b)) 

7046 

7047 

7048def _norm_logcdfprime(z): 

7049 # derivative of special.log_ndtr 

7050 assert np.abs(z) > TRUNCNORM_TAIL_X/2 

7051 lhs = -z - 1/z 

7052 denom_cons = 1/z**2 

7053 numerator = 1 

7054 pwr = 1/z 

7055 i = 1 

7056 total = 0 

7057 while i < 10: 

7058 pwr *= denom_cons 

7059 numerator *= 2 * i - 1 

7060 term = numerator*pwr*(2*i) 

7061 total += term 

7062 i += 1 

7063 return lhs + total 

7064 

7065 

7066def _norm_ilogcdf(y): 

7067 """Inverse function to _norm_logcdf==sc.log_ndtr.""" 

7068 # Apply approximate Newton-Raphson 3 times 

7069 z = -np.sqrt(-2*(y + np.log(2*np.pi)/2)) 

7070 for _ in range(3): 

7071 z = z - (_norm_logcdf(z) - y) / _norm_logcdfprime(z) 

7072 return z 

7073 

7074 

7075@_vectorize(otypes=['float']) 

7076def _truncnorm_ppf(q, a, b): 

7077 if q <= 0: 

7078 return a 

7079 if q >= 1: 

7080 return b 

7081 delta = _truncnorm_get_delta(a, b) 

7082 if delta > 0: 

7083 if a > 0: 

7084 sa = _norm_sf(a) 

7085 sb = _norm_sf(b) 

7086 return _norm_isf(q * sb + sa * (1.0 - q)) 

7087 na = _norm_cdf(a) 

7088 nb = _norm_cdf(b) 

7089 return _norm_ppf(q * nb + na * (1.0 - q)) 

7090 

7091 if np.isinf(b): 

7092 x = -_norm_ilogcdf((np.log1p(-q) + _norm_logsf(a))) 

7093 return x 

7094 elif np.isinf(a): 

7095 x = _norm_ilogcdf(np.log(q) + _norm_logcdf(b)) 

7096 return x 

7097 if q <= 0.5: 

7098 def _f_cdf(x, _a, _b, alpha): 

7099 y = _truncnorm_logcdf(x, _a, _b) 

7100 return y - alpha 

7101 

7102 args = (a, b, np.log(q)) 

7103 ret = optimize.zeros.brentq(_f_cdf, a, b, args=args, 

7104 maxiter=TRUNCNORM_MAX_BRENT_ITERS) 

7105 return ret 

7106 else: 

7107 def _f_sf(x, _a, _b, alpha): 

7108 y = _truncnorm_logsf(x, _a, _b) 

7109 return y - alpha 

7110 

7111 args = (a, b, np.log(1.0 - q)) 

7112 ret = optimize.zeros.brentq(_f_sf, a, b, args=args, 

7113 maxiter=TRUNCNORM_MAX_BRENT_ITERS) 

7114 return ret 

7115 

7116 

7117class truncnorm_gen(rv_continuous): 

7118 r"""A truncated normal continuous random variable. 

7119 

7120 %(before_notes)s 

7121 

7122 Notes 

7123 ----- 

7124 The standard form of this distribution is a standard normal truncated to 

7125 the range [a, b] --- notice that a and b are defined over the domain of the 

7126 standard normal. To convert clip values for a specific mean and standard 

7127 deviation, use:: 

7128 

7129 a, b = (myclip_a - my_mean) / my_std, (myclip_b - my_mean) / my_std 

7130 

7131 `truncnorm` takes :math:`a` and :math:`b` as shape parameters. 

7132 

7133 %(after_notes)s 

7134 

7135 %(example)s 

7136 

7137 """ 

7138 def _argcheck(self, a, b): 

7139 return a < b 

7140 

7141 def _get_support(self, a, b): 

7142 return a, b 

7143 

7144 def _pdf(self, x, a, b): 

7145 return _truncnorm_pdf(x, a, b) 

7146 

7147 def _logpdf(self, x, a, b): 

7148 return _truncnorm_logpdf(x, a, b) 

7149 

7150 def _cdf(self, x, a, b): 

7151 return _truncnorm_cdf(x, a, b) 

7152 

7153 def _logcdf(self, x, a, b): 

7154 return _truncnorm_logcdf(x, a, b) 

7155 

7156 def _sf(self, x, a, b): 

7157 return _truncnorm_sf(x, a, b) 

7158 

7159 def _logsf(self, x, a, b): 

7160 return _truncnorm_logsf(x, a, b) 

7161 

7162 def _ppf(self, q, a, b): 

7163 return _truncnorm_ppf(q, a, b) 

7164 

7165 def _munp(self, n, a, b): 

7166 def n_th_moment(n, a, b): 

7167 """ 

7168 Returns n-th moment. Defined only if n >= 0. 

7169 Function cannot broadcast due to the loop over n 

7170 """ 

7171 pA, pB = self._pdf([a, b], a, b) 

7172 probs = [pA, -pB] 

7173 moments = [0, 1] 

7174 for k in range(1, n+1): 

7175 # a or b might be infinite, and the corresponding pdf value 

7176 # is 0 in that case, but nan is returned for the 

7177 # multiplication. However, as b->infinity, pdf(b)*b**k -> 0. 

7178 # So it is safe to use _lazywhere to avoid the nan. 

7179 vals = _lazywhere(probs, [probs, [a, b]], 

7180 lambda x, y: x * y**(k-1), fillvalue=0) 

7181 mk = np.sum(vals) + (k-1) * moments[-2] 

7182 moments.append(mk) 

7183 return moments[-1] 

7184 

7185 return _lazywhere((n >= 0) & (a == a) & (b == b), (n, a, b), 

7186 np.vectorize(n_th_moment, otypes=[np.float]), np.nan) 

7187 

7188 def _stats(self, a, b, moments='mv'): 

7189 pA, pB = self._pdf([a, b], a, b) 

7190 m1 = pA - pB 

7191 mu = m1 

7192 # use _lazywhere to avoid nan (See detailed comment in _munp) 

7193 probs = [pA, -pB] 

7194 vals = _lazywhere(probs, [probs, [a, b]], lambda x, y: x*y, 

7195 fillvalue=0) 

7196 m2 = 1 + np.sum(vals) 

7197 vals = _lazywhere(probs, [probs, [a-mu, b-mu]], lambda x, y: x*y, 

7198 fillvalue=0) 

7199 # mu2 = m2 - mu**2, but not as numerically stable as: 

7200 # mu2 = (a-mu)*pA - (b-mu)*pB + 1 

7201 mu2 = 1 + np.sum(vals) 

7202 vals = _lazywhere(probs, [probs, [a, b]], lambda x, y: x*y**2, 

7203 fillvalue=0) 

7204 m3 = 2*m1 + np.sum(vals) 

7205 vals = _lazywhere(probs, [probs, [a, b]], lambda x, y: x*y**3, 

7206 fillvalue=0) 

7207 m4 = 3*m2 + np.sum(vals) 

7208 

7209 mu3 = m3 + m1 * (-3*m2 + 2*m1**2) 

7210 g1 = mu3 / np.power(mu2, 1.5) 

7211 mu4 = m4 + m1*(-4*m3 + 3*m1*(2*m2 - m1**2)) 

7212 g2 = mu4 / mu2**2 - 3 

7213 return mu, mu2, g1, g2 

7214 

7215 

7216truncnorm = truncnorm_gen(name='truncnorm', momtype=1) 

7217 

7218 

7219# FIXME: RVS does not work. 

7220class tukeylambda_gen(rv_continuous): 

7221 r"""A Tukey-Lamdba continuous random variable. 

7222 

7223 %(before_notes)s 

7224 

7225 Notes 

7226 ----- 

7227 A flexible distribution, able to represent and interpolate between the 

7228 following distributions: 

7229 

7230 - Cauchy (:math:`lambda = -1`) 

7231 - logistic (:math:`lambda = 0`) 

7232 - approx Normal (:math:`lambda = 0.14`) 

7233 - uniform from -1 to 1 (:math:`lambda = 1`) 

7234 

7235 `tukeylambda` takes a real number :math:`lambda` (denoted ``lam`` 

7236 in the implementation) as a shape parameter. 

7237 

7238 %(after_notes)s 

7239 

7240 %(example)s 

7241 

7242 """ 

7243 def _argcheck(self, lam): 

7244 return np.ones(np.shape(lam), dtype=bool) 

7245 

7246 def _pdf(self, x, lam): 

7247 Fx = np.asarray(sc.tklmbda(x, lam)) 

7248 Px = Fx**(lam-1.0) + (np.asarray(1-Fx))**(lam-1.0) 

7249 Px = 1.0/np.asarray(Px) 

7250 return np.where((lam <= 0) | (abs(x) < 1.0/np.asarray(lam)), Px, 0.0) 

7251 

7252 def _cdf(self, x, lam): 

7253 return sc.tklmbda(x, lam) 

7254 

7255 def _ppf(self, q, lam): 

7256 return sc.boxcox(q, lam) - sc.boxcox1p(-q, lam) 

7257 

7258 def _stats(self, lam): 

7259 return 0, _tlvar(lam), 0, _tlkurt(lam) 

7260 

7261 def _entropy(self, lam): 

7262 def integ(p): 

7263 return np.log(pow(p, lam-1)+pow(1-p, lam-1)) 

7264 return integrate.quad(integ, 0, 1)[0] 

7265 

7266 

7267tukeylambda = tukeylambda_gen(name='tukeylambda') 

7268 

7269 

7270class FitUniformFixedScaleDataError(FitDataError): 

7271 def __init__(self, ptp, fscale): 

7272 self.args = ( 

7273 "Invalid values in `data`. Maximum likelihood estimation with " 

7274 "the uniform distribution and fixed scale requires that " 

7275 "data.ptp() <= fscale, but data.ptp() = %r and fscale = %r." % 

7276 (ptp, fscale), 

7277 ) 

7278 

7279 

7280class uniform_gen(rv_continuous): 

7281 r"""A uniform continuous random variable. 

7282 

7283 In the standard form, the distribution is uniform on ``[0, 1]``. Using 

7284 the parameters ``loc`` and ``scale``, one obtains the uniform distribution 

7285 on ``[loc, loc + scale]``. 

7286 

7287 %(before_notes)s 

7288 

7289 %(example)s 

7290 

7291 """ 

7292 def _rvs(self): 

7293 return self._random_state.uniform(0.0, 1.0, self._size) 

7294 

7295 def _pdf(self, x): 

7296 return 1.0*(x == x) 

7297 

7298 def _cdf(self, x): 

7299 return x 

7300 

7301 def _ppf(self, q): 

7302 return q 

7303 

7304 def _stats(self): 

7305 return 0.5, 1.0/12, 0, -1.2 

7306 

7307 def _entropy(self): 

7308 return 0.0 

7309 

7310 def fit(self, data, *args, **kwds): 

7311 """ 

7312 Maximum likelihood estimate for the location and scale parameters. 

7313 

7314 `uniform.fit` uses only the following parameters. Because exact 

7315 formulas are used, the parameters related to optimization that are 

7316 available in the `fit` method of other distributions are ignored 

7317 here. The only positional argument accepted is `data`. 

7318 

7319 Parameters 

7320 ---------- 

7321 data : array_like 

7322 Data to use in calculating the maximum likelihood estimate. 

7323 floc : float, optional 

7324 Hold the location parameter fixed to the specified value. 

7325 fscale : float, optional 

7326 Hold the scale parameter fixed to the specified value. 

7327 

7328 Returns 

7329 ------- 

7330 loc, scale : float 

7331 Maximum likelihood estimates for the location and scale. 

7332 

7333 Notes 

7334 ----- 

7335 An error is raised if `floc` is given and any values in `data` are 

7336 less than `floc`, or if `fscale` is given and `fscale` is less 

7337 than ``data.max() - data.min()``. An error is also raised if both 

7338 `floc` and `fscale` are given. 

7339 

7340 Examples 

7341 -------- 

7342 >>> from scipy.stats import uniform 

7343 

7344 We'll fit the uniform distribution to `x`: 

7345 

7346 >>> x = np.array([2, 2.5, 3.1, 9.5, 13.0]) 

7347 

7348 For a uniform distribution MLE, the location is the minimum of the 

7349 data, and the scale is the maximum minus the minimum. 

7350 

7351 >>> loc, scale = uniform.fit(x) 

7352 >>> loc 

7353 2.0 

7354 >>> scale 

7355 11.0 

7356 

7357 If we know the data comes from a uniform distribution where the support 

7358 starts at 0, we can use `floc=0`: 

7359 

7360 >>> loc, scale = uniform.fit(x, floc=0) 

7361 >>> loc 

7362 0.0 

7363 >>> scale 

7364 13.0 

7365 

7366 Alternatively, if we know the length of the support is 12, we can use 

7367 `fscale=12`: 

7368 

7369 >>> loc, scale = uniform.fit(x, fscale=12) 

7370 >>> loc 

7371 1.5 

7372 >>> scale 

7373 12.0 

7374 

7375 In that last example, the support interval is [1.5, 13.5]. This 

7376 solution is not unique. For example, the distribution with ``loc=2`` 

7377 and ``scale=12`` has the same likelihood as the one above. When 

7378 `fscale` is given and it is larger than ``data.max() - data.min()``, 

7379 the parameters returned by the `fit` method center the support over 

7380 the interval ``[data.min(), data.max()]``. 

7381 

7382 """ 

7383 if len(args) > 0: 

7384 raise TypeError("Too many arguments.") 

7385 

7386 floc = kwds.pop('floc', None) 

7387 fscale = kwds.pop('fscale', None) 

7388 

7389 _remove_optimizer_parameters(kwds) 

7390 

7391 if floc is not None and fscale is not None: 

7392 # This check is for consistency with `rv_continuous.fit`. 

7393 raise ValueError("All parameters fixed. There is nothing to " 

7394 "optimize.") 

7395 

7396 data = np.asarray(data) 

7397 

7398 if not np.isfinite(data).all(): 

7399 raise RuntimeError("The data contains non-finite values.") 

7400 

7401 # MLE for the uniform distribution 

7402 # -------------------------------- 

7403 # The PDF is 

7404 # 

7405 # f(x, loc, scale) = {1/scale for loc <= x <= loc + scale 

7406 # {0 otherwise} 

7407 # 

7408 # The likelihood function is 

7409 # L(x, loc, scale) = (1/scale)**n 

7410 # where n is len(x), assuming loc <= x <= loc + scale for all x. 

7411 # The log-likelihood is 

7412 # l(x, loc, scale) = -n*log(scale) 

7413 # The log-likelihood is maximized by making scale as small as possible, 

7414 # while keeping loc <= x <= loc + scale. So if neither loc nor scale 

7415 # are fixed, the log-likelihood is maximized by choosing 

7416 # loc = x.min() 

7417 # scale = x.ptp() 

7418 # If loc is fixed, it must be less than or equal to x.min(), and then 

7419 # the scale is 

7420 # scale = x.max() - loc 

7421 # If scale is fixed, it must not be less than x.ptp(). If scale is 

7422 # greater than x.ptp(), the solution is not unique. Note that the 

7423 # likelihood does not depend on loc, except for the requirement that 

7424 # loc <= x <= loc + scale. All choices of loc for which 

7425 # x.max() - scale <= loc <= x.min() 

7426 # have the same log-likelihood. In this case, we choose loc such that 

7427 # the support is centered over the interval [data.min(), data.max()]: 

7428 # loc = x.min() = 0.5*(scale - x.ptp()) 

7429 

7430 if fscale is None: 

7431 # scale is not fixed. 

7432 if floc is None: 

7433 # loc is not fixed, scale is not fixed. 

7434 loc = data.min() 

7435 scale = data.ptp() 

7436 else: 

7437 # loc is fixed, scale is not fixed. 

7438 loc = floc 

7439 scale = data.max() - loc 

7440 if data.min() < loc: 

7441 raise FitDataError("uniform", lower=loc, upper=loc + scale) 

7442 else: 

7443 # loc is not fixed, scale is fixed. 

7444 ptp = data.ptp() 

7445 if ptp > fscale: 

7446 raise FitUniformFixedScaleDataError(ptp=ptp, fscale=fscale) 

7447 # If ptp < fscale, the ML estimate is not unique; see the comments 

7448 # above. We choose the distribution for which the support is 

7449 # centered over the interval [data.min(), data.max()]. 

7450 loc = data.min() - 0.5*(fscale - ptp) 

7451 scale = fscale 

7452 

7453 # We expect the return values to be floating point, so ensure it 

7454 # by explicitly converting to float. 

7455 return float(loc), float(scale) 

7456 

7457 

7458uniform = uniform_gen(a=0.0, b=1.0, name='uniform') 

7459 

7460 

7461class vonmises_gen(rv_continuous): 

7462 r"""A Von Mises continuous random variable. 

7463 

7464 %(before_notes)s 

7465 

7466 Notes 

7467 ----- 

7468 The probability density function for `vonmises` and `vonmises_line` is: 

7469 

7470 .. math:: 

7471 

7472 f(x, \kappa) = \frac{ \exp(\kappa \cos(x)) }{ 2 \pi I_0(\kappa) } 

7473 

7474 for :math:`-\pi \le x \le \pi`, :math:`\kappa > 0`. :math:`I_0` is the 

7475 modified Bessel function of order zero (`scipy.special.i0`). 

7476 

7477 `vonmises` is a circular distribution which does not restrict the 

7478 distribution to a fixed interval. Currently, there is no circular 

7479 distribution framework in scipy. The ``cdf`` is implemented such that 

7480 ``cdf(x + 2*np.pi) == cdf(x) + 1``. 

7481 

7482 `vonmises_line` is the same distribution, defined on :math:`[-\pi, \pi]` 

7483 on the real line. This is a regular (i.e. non-circular) distribution. 

7484 

7485 `vonmises` and `vonmises_line` take ``kappa`` as a shape parameter. 

7486 

7487 %(after_notes)s 

7488 

7489 %(example)s 

7490 

7491 """ 

7492 def _rvs(self, kappa): 

7493 return self._random_state.vonmises(0.0, kappa, size=self._size) 

7494 

7495 def _pdf(self, x, kappa): 

7496 # vonmises.pdf(x, \kappa) = exp(\kappa * cos(x)) / (2*pi*I[0](\kappa)) 

7497 return np.exp(kappa * np.cos(x)) / (2*np.pi*sc.i0(kappa)) 

7498 

7499 def _cdf(self, x, kappa): 

7500 return _stats.von_mises_cdf(kappa, x) 

7501 

7502 def _stats_skip(self, kappa): 

7503 return 0, None, 0, None 

7504 

7505 def _entropy(self, kappa): 

7506 return (-kappa * sc.i1(kappa) / sc.i0(kappa) + 

7507 np.log(2 * np.pi * sc.i0(kappa))) 

7508 

7509 

7510vonmises = vonmises_gen(name='vonmises') 

7511vonmises_line = vonmises_gen(a=-np.pi, b=np.pi, name='vonmises_line') 

7512 

7513 

7514class wald_gen(invgauss_gen): 

7515 r"""A Wald continuous random variable. 

7516 

7517 %(before_notes)s 

7518 

7519 Notes 

7520 ----- 

7521 The probability density function for `wald` is: 

7522 

7523 .. math:: 

7524 

7525 f(x) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi x^3}} \exp(- \frac{ (x-1)^2 }{ 2x }) 

7526 

7527 for :math:`x >= 0`. 

7528 

7529 `wald` is a special case of `invgauss` with ``mu=1``. 

7530 

7531 %(after_notes)s 

7532 

7533 %(example)s 

7534 """ 

7535 _support_mask = rv_continuous._open_support_mask 

7536 

7537 def _rvs(self): 

7538 return self._random_state.wald(1.0, 1.0, size=self._size) 

7539 

7540 def _pdf(self, x): 

7541 # wald.pdf(x) = 1/sqrt(2*pi*x**3) * exp(-(x-1)**2/(2*x)) 

7542 return invgauss._pdf(x, 1.0) 

7543 

7544 def _logpdf(self, x): 

7545 return invgauss._logpdf(x, 1.0) 

7546 

7547 def _cdf(self, x): 

7548 return invgauss._cdf(x, 1.0) 

7549 

7550 def _stats(self): 

7551 return 1.0, 1.0, 3.0, 15.0 

7552 

7553 

7554wald = wald_gen(a=0.0, name="wald") 

7555 

7556 

7557class wrapcauchy_gen(rv_continuous): 

7558 r"""A wrapped Cauchy continuous random variable. 

7559 

7560 %(before_notes)s 

7561 

7562 Notes 

7563 ----- 

7564 The probability density function for `wrapcauchy` is: 

7565 

7566 .. math:: 

7567 

7568 f(x, c) = \frac{1-c^2}{2\pi (1+c^2 - 2c \cos(x))} 

7569 

7570 for :math:`0 \le x \le 2\pi`, :math:`0 < c < 1`. 

7571 

7572 `wrapcauchy` takes ``c`` as a shape parameter for :math:`c`. 

7573 

7574 %(after_notes)s 

7575 

7576 %(example)s 

7577 

7578 """ 

7579 def _argcheck(self, c): 

7580 return (c > 0) & (c < 1) 

7581 

7582 def _pdf(self, x, c): 

7583 # wrapcauchy.pdf(x, c) = (1-c**2) / (2*pi*(1+c**2-2*c*cos(x))) 

7584 return (1.0-c*c)/(2*np.pi*(1+c*c-2*c*np.cos(x))) 

7585 

7586 def _cdf(self, x, c): 

7587 output = np.zeros(x.shape, dtype=x.dtype) 

7588 val = (1.0+c)/(1.0-c) 

7589 c1 = x < np.pi 

7590 c2 = 1-c1 

7591 xp = np.extract(c1, x) 

7592 xn = np.extract(c2, x) 

7593 if np.any(xn): 

7594 valn = np.extract(c2, np.ones_like(x)*val) 

7595 xn = 2*np.pi - xn 

7596 yn = np.tan(xn/2.0) 

7597 on = 1.0-1.0/np.pi*np.arctan(valn*yn) 

7598 np.place(output, c2, on) 

7599 if np.any(xp): 

7600 valp = np.extract(c1, np.ones_like(x)*val) 

7601 yp = np.tan(xp/2.0) 

7602 op = 1.0/np.pi*np.arctan(valp*yp) 

7603 np.place(output, c1, op) 

7604 return output 

7605 

7606 def _ppf(self, q, c): 

7607 val = (1.0-c)/(1.0+c) 

7608 rcq = 2*np.arctan(val*np.tan(np.pi*q)) 

7609 rcmq = 2*np.pi-2*np.arctan(val*np.tan(np.pi*(1-q))) 

7610 return np.where(q < 1.0/2, rcq, rcmq) 

7611 

7612 def _entropy(self, c): 

7613 return np.log(2*np.pi*(1-c*c)) 

7614 

7615 

7616wrapcauchy = wrapcauchy_gen(a=0.0, b=2*np.pi, name='wrapcauchy') 

7617 

7618 

7619class gennorm_gen(rv_continuous): 

7620 r"""A generalized normal continuous random variable. 

7621 

7622 %(before_notes)s 

7623 

7624 Notes 

7625 ----- 

7626 The probability density function for `gennorm` is [1]_: 

7627 

7628 .. math:: 

7629 

7630 f(x, \beta) = \frac{\beta}{2 \Gamma(1/\beta)} \exp(-|x|^\beta) 

7631 

7632 :math:`\Gamma` is the gamma function (`scipy.special.gamma`). 

7633 

7634 `gennorm` takes ``beta`` as a shape parameter for :math:`\beta`. 

7635 For :math:`\beta = 1`, it is identical to a Laplace distribution. 

7636 For :math:`\beta = 2`, it is identical to a normal distribution 

7637 (with ``scale=1/sqrt(2)``). 

7638 

7639 See Also 

7640 -------- 

7641 laplace : Laplace distribution 

7642 norm : normal distribution 

7643 

7644 References 

7645 ---------- 

7646 

7647 .. [1] "Generalized normal distribution, Version 1", 

7648 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generalized_normal_distribution#Version_1 

7649 

7650 %(example)s 

7651 

7652 """ 

7653 

7654 def _pdf(self, x, beta): 

7655 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, beta)) 

7656 

7657 def _logpdf(self, x, beta): 

7658 return np.log(0.5*beta) - sc.gammaln(1.0/beta) - abs(x)**beta 

7659 

7660 def _cdf(self, x, beta): 

7661 c = 0.5 * np.sign(x) 

7662 # evaluating (.5 + c) first prevents numerical cancellation 

7663 return (0.5 + c) - c * sc.gammaincc(1.0/beta, abs(x)**beta) 

7664 

7665 def _ppf(self, x, beta): 

7666 c = np.sign(x - 0.5) 

7667 # evaluating (1. + c) first prevents numerical cancellation 

7668 return c * sc.gammainccinv(1.0/beta, (1.0 + c) - 2.0*c*x)**(1.0/beta) 

7669 

7670 def _sf(self, x, beta): 

7671 return self._cdf(-x, beta) 

7672 

7673 def _isf(self, x, beta): 

7674 return -self._ppf(x, beta) 

7675 

7676 def _stats(self, beta): 

7677 c1, c3, c5 = sc.gammaln([1.0/beta, 3.0/beta, 5.0/beta]) 

7678 return 0., np.exp(c3 - c1), 0., np.exp(c5 + c1 - 2.0*c3) - 3. 

7679 

7680 def _entropy(self, beta): 

7681 return 1. / beta - np.log(.5 * beta) + sc.gammaln(1. / beta) 

7682 

7683 

7684gennorm = gennorm_gen(name='gennorm') 

7685 

7686 

7687class halfgennorm_gen(rv_continuous): 

7688 r"""The upper half of a generalized normal continuous random variable. 

7689 

7690 %(before_notes)s 

7691 

7692 Notes 

7693 ----- 

7694 The probability density function for `halfgennorm` is: 

7695 

7696 .. math:: 

7697 

7698 f(x, \beta) = \frac{\beta}{\Gamma(1/\beta)} \exp(-|x|^\beta) 

7699 

7700 for :math:`x > 0`. :math:`\Gamma` is the gamma function 

7701 (`scipy.special.gamma`). 

7702 

7703 `gennorm` takes ``beta`` as a shape parameter for :math:`\beta`. 

7704 For :math:`\beta = 1`, it is identical to an exponential distribution. 

7705 For :math:`\beta = 2`, it is identical to a half normal distribution 

7706 (with ``scale=1/sqrt(2)``). 

7707 

7708 See Also 

7709 -------- 

7710 gennorm : generalized normal distribution 

7711 expon : exponential distribution 

7712 halfnorm : half normal distribution 

7713 

7714 References 

7715 ---------- 

7716 

7717 .. [1] "Generalized normal distribution, Version 1", 

7718 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generalized_normal_distribution#Version_1 

7719 

7720 %(example)s 

7721 

7722 """ 

7723 

7724 def _pdf(self, x, beta): 

7725 # beta 

7726 # halfgennorm.pdf(x, beta) = ------------- exp(-|x|**beta) 

7727 # gamma(1/beta) 

7728 return np.exp(self._logpdf(x, beta)) 

7729 

7730 def _logpdf(self, x, beta): 

7731 return np.log(beta) - sc.gammaln(1.0/beta) - x**beta 

7732 

7733 def _cdf(self, x, beta): 

7734 return sc.gammainc(1.0/beta, x**beta) 

7735 

7736 def _ppf(self, x, beta): 

7737 return sc.gammaincinv(1.0/beta, x)**(1.0/beta) 

7738 

7739 def _sf(self, x, beta): 

7740 return sc.gammaincc(1.0/beta, x**beta) 

7741 

7742 def _isf(self, x, beta): 

7743 return sc.gammainccinv(1.0/beta, x)**(1.0/beta) 

7744 

7745 def _entropy(self, beta): 

7746 return 1.0/beta - np.log(beta) + sc.gammaln(1.0/beta) 

7747 

7748 

7749halfgennorm = halfgennorm_gen(a=0, name='halfgennorm') 

7750 

7751 

7752class crystalball_gen(rv_continuous): 

7753 r""" 

7754 Crystalball distribution 

7755 

7756 %(before_notes)s 

7757 

7758 Notes 

7759 ----- 

7760 The probability density function for `crystalball` is: 

7761 

7762 .. math:: 

7763 

7764 f(x, \beta, m) = \begin{cases} 

7765 N \exp(-x^2 / 2), &\text{for } x > -\beta\\ 

7766 N A (B - x)^{-m} &\text{for } x \le -\beta 

7767 \end{cases} 

7768 

7769 where :math:`A = (m / |\beta|)^n \exp(-\beta^2 / 2)`, 

7770 :math:`B = m/|\beta| - |\beta|` and :math:`N` is a normalisation constant. 

7771 

7772 `crystalball` takes :math:`\beta > 0` and :math:`m > 1` as shape 

7773 parameters. :math:`\beta` defines the point where the pdf changes 

7774 from a power-law to a Gaussian distribution. :math:`m` is the power 

7775 of the power-law tail. 

7776 

7777 References 

7778 ---------- 

7779 .. [1] "Crystal Ball Function", 

7780 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crystal_Ball_function 

7781 

7782 %(after_notes)s 

7783 

7784 .. versionadded:: 0.19.0 

7785 

7786 %(example)s 

7787 """ 

7788 

7789 def _pdf(self, x, beta, m): 

7790 """ 

7791 Return PDF of the crystalball function. 

7792 

7793 -- 

7794 | exp(-x**2 / 2), for x > -beta 

7795 crystalball.pdf(x, beta, m) = N * | 

7796 | A * (B - x)**(-m), for x <= -beta 

7797 -- 

7798 """ 

7799 N = 1.0 / (m/beta / (m-1) * np.exp(-beta**2 / 2.0) + 

7800 _norm_pdf_C * _norm_cdf(beta)) 

7801 

7802 def rhs(x, beta, m): 

7803 return np.exp(-x**2 / 2) 

7804 

7805 def lhs(x, beta, m): 

7806 return ((m/beta)**m * np.exp(-beta**2 / 2.0) * 

7807 (m/beta - beta - x)**(-m)) 

7808 

7809 return N * _lazywhere(x > -beta, (x, beta, m), f=rhs, f2=lhs) 

7810 

7811 def _logpdf(self, x, beta, m): 

7812 """ 

7813 Return the log of the PDF of the crystalball function. 

7814 """ 

7815 N = 1.0 / (m/beta / (m-1) * np.exp(-beta**2 / 2.0) + 

7816 _norm_pdf_C * _norm_cdf(beta)) 

7817 

7818 def rhs(x, beta, m): 

7819 return -x**2/2 

7820 

7821 def lhs(x, beta, m): 

7822 return m*np.log(m/beta) - beta**2/2 - m*np.log(m/beta - beta - x)
